documents.commentText: I first started using kratom in the summer of 2011. I have had post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) for most of my life because of childhood trauma. I have also had major depressive disorder, recurring because of the same profound childhood trauma. I had lost my teaching position at a community college in the spring of 2011, because the position itself had been eliminated (downsizing, if you will). I had sunk into an abnormally deep depression, which was so severe that I was plagued with suicidal ideation. While I fought this with everything I had, it seemed to be a losing battle. Kratom was recommended to my by a friend and colleague. I was told I could buy it at a local tobacco shop. I took a small dose of the kratom to see if it would help me get out of the depression. It worked instantly, and without side-effects. I had never had any luck with antidepressants, or psychotropic medications of any kind, but the kratom worked, and it worked well. In addition, I found an online business that supplied an affordable and high-quality edible kratom powdered leaf in bulk. When mixed with orange juice, this 100% organic herb did wonders to alleviate the symptoms of my depression. Once I was exhumed from my severe, debilitation, life-long depression, I found the strength to face my unemployment. Within a week, I had found temporary employment. Today, I am a full-time professor at a major university. Over the years, I have found that the only side-effect of kratom that I ever experienced is nausea that occurs only if I take too much, or if I take it too often. I consider this to be a benefit, because it keeps me from taking larger doses. Really, any medicinal herb should not be taken in large quantities. I find that a moderate dose in the evening, 2 hours after supper, is about right for controlling my symptoms, and it helps with my insomnia (the insomnia is related to my PTSD). While I am not addicted to kratom, I do find that the depression will immediately return if I stop taking kratom for an extended period of time. This is true of all psychotropic substances; the benefit will disappear if you stop taking it. Please note that this depression was a diagnosed, preexisting condition, and it is not a result of the kratom itself. I simply would not be able to function as a full-time professor if I did not have this herb to treat my depression. I do not take any other psychotropic or psychoactive substances. I don't even drink caffeine, as I find that it irritates my PTSD condition. The type of kratom that I take is called "Green Malay", or "Green Vein Malaysian Kratom Leaf". I have had no experience with other types of kratom, and I make no claims about them. I can only speach for green malay. I ask you to please not take this herb away from me. I have never broken a law in my life, and I never will. If kratom is outlawed, I will have no choice. In my mind, the law is what maintains order and structure in our society, and it must be followed even if it means returning to my depression and PTSD. There are no other alternatives that have helped with my condition. I could list the treatments I have tried over the years, but it would simply take up too much room. The kratom that I take helps with both my major depressive disorder, recurring and my post-traumatic stress disorder.

documents.commentText:
Banning kratom expands the war on drugs, while the public overwhelmingly supports ending it.
If kratom is added to any one of the five drug schedules, people who use it will be criminalized and locked up behind bars.
Kratom has been used safely by millions of people in the U.S. and evidence supports kratom's potential as a pain reliever and opioid replacement.
Many people struggling with opioid addiction have turned to kratom to help them cut back or quit, but now all promising scientific studies on kratom's role in opioid treatment could be immediately shut down.
Side effects of kratom are minimal, and its withdrawal symptoms are weak and nearly inconsequential compared to the suffering of people trying to quit opioids.
Prohibiting kratom will worsen the country's problems of opioid addiction and overdose.

Dear DEA,

I oppose the decision to make kratom a Schedule 1 drug. I believe this is a hasty decision made about a benign plant which needs further medical research into it's many beneficial properties. I'd like to share my story with you.

I personally use the plant as an alternative and addition to over-the-counter and prescription pain medications, as I was born needing many surgeries on my feet simply in order to walk, due to club foot. Kratom has given me a better quality of life, without the terrible toll that opiates can take. The plant has been used for thousands of years with little to no side effects. There is no logical reason to schedule kratom in such a harsh way, and this matter has given the appearance that the government and DEA don't have the best interest of US citizens in mind. The information spread in the DEA's request is blatantly incorrect and malicious.

If you have any sway in this matter, please make the case that this is an herb as innocuous as caffeine (or moreso), does NOT create a 'high' like prescription and illicit drugs, and helps millions of people worldwide deal with their pain and opiate habits. I am personally devastated by this news.

Why should kratom be in the same class as heroin? This is a hasty decision that needs more time and delicate consideration.

Sources:
jaoa.org/article.aspx?articleid=2094342

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3670991/

Thank you for your consideration,

documents.commentText:
Let's compare the War on Drugs to Alcohol Prohibition. The latter lasted for less than 15 years. People realized it was a mistake. The former has gone on for a century. The time to recognize that it too is a mistake is long overdue. 

We can begin to correct the mistake by not making it worse.

If kratom is added to any one of the five drug schedules, people who use it will be criminalized and locked up behind bars.

Kratom has been used safely by millions of people in the U.S. and evidence supports kratom's potential as a pain reliever and opioid replacement.

Banning kratom expands the war on drugs, while the public overwhelmingly supports ending it. Kratom should be legally regulated, allowing for quality control measures and product labeling requirements.

Prohibiting kratom will worsen the country's problems of opioid addiction and overdose. 

This time, let us remember and pay heed to the lessons of history.

documents.commentText:
To whom it may concern:

 My initial signing of the petition concerning kratom, and this further reply, is based on facts I've found during research on the herb. 

 While I do understand precaution being taken regarding a lesser known substance, in quite a bit of nonscientific research I've personally done, it appears that there is only one known death with a high probability linked to kratom use. Again, that is ONE single death that has most likely been tied to a single user/abuser of a natural substance that actually has a number of medicinal benefits to those with medical need. 

 Before I compare that health risk with those associated with legal pharmaceutical opioids and other drugs, I'll mention claimed health benefits: Non-narcotic pain relief has the potential of being the most widespread use to the general public. That alone deserves more research. Perhaps the most important consideration might be in the care of opiate dependent patients. Kratom has been used to help individuals break their addiction to lethal but legal hard drugs. Natural opium derived drugs and the synthetic counterparts have been useful to mankind for centuries, but the risks are considerable. The addiction rate is well documented. The death toll is staggering. A set of chemical compounds in a plant that show potential to break the cycle is absolutely worth clinical research. As a schedule one danger, much research will not happen. 

I suggest a rational approach of encouraging research while following reports of problems incurred. Monitoring emergency room reports of possible overdoses would log abuse issues, if a problem develops. As of yet, there appears to be no real danger to the general public. If facts and data show that a problem exists, a scheduling change would be merited at that time. Of the many who find use in the chemicals ("drugs") in the plant, one has abused it to the point of death. That is absolutely not worthy of a widespread restriction. Please do more research and make an informed consideration. What this writer found was easily available online. If there are considerable dangers associated with kratom, more would be available to those looking. It appears that the vast majority of kratom users are not looking for a mindless high. These people deserve medicine that helps them. 

Thank you for taking time to read this, and I'm certainly open to being corrected, if what I'm repeating is not fact.

I have struggled with opiate addiction since 2007. I graduated high school with honors and a 4.0 as well as being an athlete in which I had scholarships for bsseball in JUCO. Then, I was the type of person that didn't like taking ibp after pitching 7 innings. I was prescribed Lortab due to a double ear infection and I ended up wanting to feel that way every day. I quickly graduated to IVing oxy contin and fentanyl and went through my first program in 2007. From 2007 up until July of 2015 I completed a a total of 6 programs, with the last one being a year long. Even after the year in that program plus 9 months I was unable to stay clean. I was unable to hold a job, keep a relationship, and be a father. Due to my addiction, I no longer have parental rights to my 7 year old son nor am I able to even speak to him. Unfortunately, I suffer from real issues such as chronic pain(due to a fractured back), sever anxiety, ADHD, and depression. I never thought I would ever be able to live a normal productive life until Kratom. Kratom relieves me of all of those i issues. Thanks to Kratom, I have became an HVAC mechanic, I'm getting married to a very successful woman April 1st, and am finally able to be a father to my 20 month old son (a great father at that). Sure I could go get prescribed medications for these issues but they all come with a euphoric feeling that I'm unable to keep myself from chasing. Kratom is by far the safest way for me to deal with my issues and there's no euphoric or high as people have. Even misinformed. I believe that all of this nonsense started due to Vivazen which did cause a "rush"  but also had many other things in itt such as California poppy, kava kava, etc. but Kratom in its natural form does NOT. If this ban goes through, those of us that found relief in Kratom will turn back to the drugs that will actually kill us. So signing this ban will be the same as signing death certificates.

documents.commentText: Kratom should not be illegal. It is a much lighter alternative to drinking alcohol, which is already legal and has been for years and years. Kratom does not cause anywhere near the amount of impairment that alcohol does. Although there haven't been sufficient studies to speak on the level of addiction of kratom, I'm willing to bet that it's much less addictive than the legal drugs alcohol and nicotine. I've been drinking kratom-infused beverages once or twice a week for the past year and have not noticed any withdrawal symptoms. I do not "NEED" more than one glass. I don't need any of it, actually, but I find that it's a lot better on my body than alcohol. I was diagnosed with ulcerative colitis in 2014 and I've been told time and time again by doctors that alcohol will upset my stomach. In my own experience, I've found that it is extremely painful to drink alcohol. Kratom has no adverse effect on my stomach. I don't get a hangover from ingesting kratom like that of alcohol. The effects are extremely mild and wear off quickly. It goes without saying that kratom is effective in tapering addicts off of heroin and opiates. I've known many people to use kratom to take themselves off of detrimental drugs. To assert that kratom is as dangerous as heroin is insane. I've never seen anyone "nod out" on kratom. It's a social drink that is a lot more positive than getting loaded on alcohol and hurting someone in an accident or hurting yourself. Please, please, PLEASE reconsider your position on kratom. It's much better for you than the already popular social drug, alcohol. Thanks.

documents.commentText:
Your name, age, and profession.
Chris P. Buhr / 27 / Attorney

A clear statement of your view about opposing the DEA putting kratom on the list of schedule 1 controlled substances
It is my view that the "Maeng Da" strand of kratom should not be made illegal, while strands with opioid-like properties such as Bali should be available by prescription only.

When you started using kratom.
Approximately 09/2016

How you came to start using kratom.
The worker at a "head shop" recommended the substance as a "morning after" substance (a hangover cure).

How kratom has helped you & and why you think it should remain available. Unless you are a doctor or other health expert, avoid making any medical-related claims.
The Maeng Da strand of kratom is pretty similar to coffee or other mild stimulants when used in small-to-medium doses.  Unlike caffeine, however, I find that when I take Maeng Da I do not experience the anxiety/jittery feeling that other anxiogenics (such as coffee) are known for.  I have had a similar experience with something known as the stem-and-vein powder, which in my experience has energy and mood-lifting effects.

Any links to research or news articles that support your thoughts.
I have done a fair amount of research on the substance and have found information supporting the idea that Maeng Da promotes energy/stimulation while the Bali strand has more of a sedative effect.  However, I have not read articles from medical experts and I think one of the best sources for credible, presumably unbiased information is the Wikipedia page:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mitragyna_speciosa

A concluding point.
Like many other office workers, I often find it difficult to stay energized.  I find that the Maeng Da strand of kratom provides energy and mental clarity, while having none of the anxiogenic side effects that are common in other stimulants such as coffee, energy drinks, or adderall.  When I use caffeine, it makes me feel anxious and sometimes even worried.  I believe Maeng Da is a safe way to stay focused and positive throughout the day.
  
I would like to finish by making a cautionary statement in regard to the Bali strand of kratom, which I believe is dangerous and should not be available on the open market.  The Bali strand of kratom causes a strong sedative effect, and  I have experienced first-hand the feeling of "nodding off," the "wobbly" sensation where your eyes don't want to focus, and worst of all, the inability to wake up even when a very loud alarm is right next to your head.

This is a page detailing various records of Wikipedia. Some of them may never be fully known, but it's worth listing the ones we know. Please fill in the gaps, and add your own records (as long as they are sensible)!

Beginnings[edit]
See also: Wikipedia:Wikipedia's oldest articles, Wikipedia:2001
First page: HomePage created on 15 January 2001
First edit: HomePage on 15 January 2001
First named user: January 17: First known named user: User:ScottMoonen [1]
First featured article: TheCanonofScripture, MathematicalGrouP, and NewZealand, tied on 23:53, January 21, 2001. However, Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart was first to be featured on the main page, on February 22, 2004
First Did You Know: Pencil sharpener, posted on February 22, 2004 (created by user:Raul654 on February 15, 2004)
First Picture of the Day: Virgin River Narrows, Friday May 14, 2004[2]
The English-language Wikipedia's first picture of the day
The Virgin River Narrows in Zion National Park, located near Springdale, Utah, is a 16-mile long slot canyon along the Virgin River. Recently rated as number five out of National Geographic's Top 100 American Adventures, it is one of the most rewarding hikes in the world.
Photo credit: Jon Sullivan, pdphoto.org
Articles[edit]
Oldest surviving edit (older edits have existed, but have since been lost because of the way UseModWiki worked): UuU (20:08 UTC, 16 January 2001)
Longest article: List of all National Historic Landmarks ?(Over 1 million bytes as of 11 September 2016)
Longest article that is not a list: India-European Union relations ?(483K bytes as of 05 October 2016)
Longest biography article: Mary Hanford Ford (328K as of 11 September 2016)
Longest featured article: Barack Obama (272K as of 15 March 2016)
Shortest featured article: How Brown Saw the Baseball Game (8K as of 15 March 2016)
Articles with the most references/citations:
That is a list: List of cult films has 1605, as of May 22, 2016
That is a biography: Bobby Fischer has 663 as of May 22, 2016
That is neither a list nor a biography: Turkistan Islamic Party has 1499, as of May 22, 2016
Most references for one sentence: 172 in 21 May 2010 version of Educology.
Longest time an article had no references: Rapport congruency. Unreferenced from September 24, 2004 to August 28, 2015.
Largest article talk page including archives: Talk:Intelligent design (18.1 MB as of 11 March 2016)
Most archives of a main namespace talk page: Talk:Jesus (127 as of 15 March 2016)
Most archives of a non-main namespace talk page: Wikipedia talk:Requests for adminship (240 as of 15 March 2016)
Most archives of a non-main namespace non-talk page: Wikipedia:Administrators' noticeboard/Incidents (916 as of 15 March 2016)
Most successful FA nominations: 137 by Wehwalt (see Wikipedia:List of Wikipedians by featured article nominations)
Most DYK (Did You Know?) articles: 1656 by Dr. Blofeld (see Wikipedia:List of Wikipedians by number of DYKs)
Most views:
The most visited page is probably the Main Page, followed by Special:Search and Special:Random.[3]
The most viewed article of all time is unknown, though the multiyear ranking of most viewed pages gives views for top-100 pages since 2007. In addition, stats.grok.se/ gives statistics for specific months in the same years.
The most visited article on a single day is probably Steve Jobs, which had 7.4 million views on 6 October 2011 and 1.6 million on 7 October.[4] The previous record was probably Michael Jackson, which had 5.9 million views on 26 June 2009.[5] In both cases, the record views were set one day after the subjects' deaths.
One of the most visited articles on a single day that was not just after the subject's death was 2.5 million views of Sarah Palin, on the day she received the 2008 US Republican Party Vice Presidential nomination.[6]

in any namespace: Wikipedia:Administrator intervention against vandalism (1,147,976 edits as of April 2, 2016)[7]
in Main Article namespace: George W. Bush (45,922 edits as of March 30, 2016)[7]
in Talk namespace: Talk:Main Page (133,724 edits as of April 2, 2016)[7]

documents.commentText:
To the U.S. Drug Enforcement Agency:
    Hello, I am a regular and responsible user of the plant "Kratom". I have been using this substance for over a year without any negative side-effects or withdrawal symptoms. I am writing because I want kratom to remain legal for people like me. 
     I notice that kratom has many benefits for me. It gives me energy and enthusiasm to go to work and make a living. It works as a great analgesic for chronic pain ( I have chronic foot pain and neck pain ). Without kratom I believe I would have to take an opiod pain killer or 800 to 1600 mg of ibuprophren everyday which I dread. Kratom has helped me greatly with anxiety disorder and clinical depression (both of which I am diagnosed with).  Although I am prescribed medications for these disorders, I feel that kratom is more effective than any of them. 
    If Kratom becomes a scheduled 1 controlled substance I would be devastated. No other substance has alleviated so many of my physical and psychological problems. I cannot see how this plant is said to have no medicinal uses. It is also said to help people with opiod addiction can use kratom to  wean themselves off of it. 
     Please consider my letter in making your decision. Please listen to the many thousands of responsible users like me who rely on this substance to get up and go to work (similar to coffee in that way). Please do not make another substance illegal. This is a completely naturally occurring think - a plant leaf. Making Kratom illegal would be worse than making oxycodone illegal. Thank-you for your time.

Please make Kratom legal so that we do not lose this valuable alternative to prescription painkillers.

documents.commentText:
Banning kratom expands the war on drugs, while the public overwhelmingly supports ending it.
If kratom is added to any one of the five drug schedules, people who use it will be criminalized and locked up behind bars.
Kratom has been used safely by millions of people in the U.S. and evidence supports kratom's potential as a pain reliever and opioid replacement.
Many people struggling with opioid addiction have turned to kratom to help them cut back or quit, but now all promising scientific studies on kratom's role in opioid treatment could be immediately shut down.
Side effects of kratom are minimal, and its withdrawal symptoms are weak and nearly inconsequential compared to the suffering of people trying to quit opioids.
Prohibiting kratom will worsen the country's problems of opioid addiction and overdose.

Robert Charles

Hello,

I am a husband of 10 years, father of a beautiful 5 year old daughter, and Director of Sales - with 12 direct reports across the Mid Atlantic / Mid West U.S. - for one of the globe's largest industrial products companies. I am a fitness enthusiast, sports fan, former collegiate athlete, and former high school baseball head coach.

To whom it may concern - I was a severe (30+ drinks daily, full dts) alcoholic, polydrug abuser - I injected opiates, cocaine, suffered from multiple chronic pain injuries and generally was a complete mess, on my way to death. Kratom, a simple herb from Indonesia, gave me a window - away from the booze/needle - to focus on myself, and my health. Not to mention created a buffer for me to taper slowly out of opiate use. If this plant was not commonly available - I would be dead. I owe it my life.
     We live in a nation of Liberty - the right to pursue health and happiness as we see fit. This is part of that ideal. We say we are in the midst of the greatest opiate epidemic we've ever seen - this plant is a valuable tool, used by millions. We already went down this road with marijuana - and the people have spoken. We do not want to be jailed for herbs that are not dangerous. We want to treat our problems with medicines that work, and don't come from a lab who's only motive is profit. Please, do the right thing - and remember the people using this are mostly responsible - ex-LEO, ex-military, working moms in pain. 
     The CDC says: 
Drinking too much can harm your health. Excessive alcohol use led to approximately 88,000 deaths and 2.5 million years of potential life lost (YPLL) each year in the United States from 2006  2010, shortening the lives of those who died by an average of 30 years.
Kratom has lead to 0 years of potential life lost. Kratom got me OFF the alcohol. If we aren't going to seriously talk about banning alcohol, we have NO BUSINESS banning kratom. Alcohol ruins productivity, makes people temporarily insane and unable to feel physical pain AND is tremendously physically addictive, carcinogenic ... yet adults can get/use that. Going through with a ban will confirm your bias re the pharmaceutical and legal drug industries. That isn't doing the right thing - that's protectionism of an industry that is LITERALLY a clear and present danger. Also good to note: ibuprofen/NSAIDS cause at LEAST 3000 deaths with a top estimate of 15000 yearly. THAT is available over the counter, to children and anyone. Be sensible.
     One last thing to think of - everyone who uses Kratom heavily for pain will be in minor opiate withdrawals - if you cut them off, they WILL seek out other things - most of which are contaminated with fentanyl. They have no tolerance, and hundreds if not thousands will die. So - to date we have 6 people dead of kratom in combination with illicit drugs so that NO ONE can produce a death certificate of specific kratom toxicity OR hundreds dead trying to get pain relief. You have a choice, please don't sign these death warrants.

documents.commentText:
To whom it may concern, 

I am a 35 year old responsible adult consumer of Kratom and I work in the retail grocery industry. I've been consuming Kratom for a little over a year and a half to help improve the quality of my life as I suffer from Crohn's Disease.  Crohn's Disease is an auto-immune disease that can and does cause inflammation throughout the entire digestive system. What Kratom does for me is to help alleviate some of the anxiety and depression that goes along with a flare up. It does NOT prevent flare ups and is by no means a cure for Crohn's, but it does help to improve my general outlook when these flare ups occur.  I take Kratom in conjunction with St. John's Wart to improve my overall mood during these times.  Before I discovered Kratom, when my condition would flare up, I would get so overwhelming depressed from the pain associated with intestinal inflammation that it would cripple me, physically and emotionally. Kratom has changed that for me.  It's allowed me to go about by day to day even during flare ups. Another benefit that I found is that it does help alleviate some of the pain associated with a flare up, similar to that of Tylenol.  

Placing Kratom into Schedule I is, in my opinion, an extreme measure that has no foreseeable benefit to the general population. The DEA claims that there is high potential for abuse and no medicinal value. I would argue that the same can be said for alcohol, tobacco, Caffeine, and even chocolate.  There is very little logic in this decision, and it ignores all the benefits that Kratom has shown to provide. 

The DEA states that there have been over 600 calls to the Poison Control over a 5 year period, though it does not state the nature of these calls. Were they a result of actual poisoning or simply to get information? In comparison, the Poison Control received 6,843 child poisoning calls for laundry detergent pods in a seven month period(www.aapcc.org/alerts/laundry-detergent-packets). 

The DEA initially sited 15 deaths attributed to Kratom, however since that time the have retracted that number to one death.  In comparison, According to the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, alcohol causes about 88,000 deaths a year in this country(www.cdc.gov/pcd/issues/2014/13_0293.htm#table1_down), while 28,000 deaths were attributed to heroin and opioid painkillers in 2014(https://www.cdc.gov/drugoverdose/). Kratom looks pretty benign by comparison.

In conclusion, the DEA's decision to place Kratom into Schedule I is extremely short sited is is not based on factual or scientific information, but rather a lack of understand of what Kratom is and actually does. I would advocate for further government funded research into the benefits of Kratom, while keeping it open to use for those who have benefited from it. Thank you for your time and for your service. 

Sincerely, 

Ryan Leighton

Name: Michael Tay
Age: 27
Profession: Backend Web Developer / Programmer

I want to make it very clear how much I oppose the DEA's decision to put kratom on the list of schedule 1 drugs. I have been taking kratom for 4 years now. Not once has this life saving plant altered my state of mind in the way that a schedule 1 drug would. Drinking a cup of Kratom tea is more akin to drinking a cup of coffee. 

Current drugs on the DEA's schedule one list include:
Heroin (diacetylmorphine),
LSD (Lysergic acid diethylamide),
Marijuana (cannabis, THC),
Mescaline (Peyote),
MDMA (3,4-methylenedioxymethamphetamine or ecstasy),
GHB (gamma-hydroxybutyric acid),
Ecstasy (MDMA or 3,4-Methylenedioxymethamphetamine),
Psilocybin

All of these drugs seriously alter the state of mind of the user. Some can even render the user completely incapable of moving or thinking for hours at a time. I cannot believe that kratom may potentially get put on this list. It's simply not a drug that can affect the user in a way comparable to any of the schedule 1 drugs.

Every one of my experiences with kratom have been positive. But to be honest, if the drug does become a schedule one drug. It will not be impossible to give it up. I ask you how hard would it be for you to give up caffeine? Coffee? 

If kratom deserves a spot here, then maybe we should put caffeine and nicotine on the list too.

I implore the DEA to NOT put kratom on the list of schedule one drugs.

documents.commentText:
I wish to voice my opposition to classifying mitragynine and 7-hydroxymitragynine as schedule 1 controlled substances - effectively banning kraton.

I have personally found kraton to be a an effective, safe, and nonaddictive alternative to opiates for pain management. I am not an uninformed young long haired doper. I am a 61 year old businessman, a biochemist with several patents.  

Twenty years ago I shattered my ankle after falling 40 foot in a hiking accident.  Four surgeries later I lived for years on a constant regiment of 4-8 # 4 codiene/Tylenol, and up to 2 grams of ibuprofen a day.  It was destroying my liver, causing gall stones, constipating me, interfering with my mental capacities, and over time losing its effectiveness in managing my constant pain. Because synthetic opiates such as demerol are not effective for me, my doctors solution was to suggest morphine. This had to change. 

Having also studied ethno-botany at Cal State Northridge in the 70's I decided to investigate herbal and nutritional treatments for pain and inflammation. After studying the liturature extensively I found many potential alternatives for pain management and inflammation. I tried many plants and combinations, Kratom was the most effective for pain management. I found that kratom was very effective at controlling pain (more effective than codeine), eased my withdrawal from the opiates, did not interfere with my mental capacities (did not get me high), had none of the side effects, and was not addicting.

After a year of daily kraton treatment I was able to exercise my ankle to the point I went from 5% range of motion to 15-20%.  After two years I was able to reduce my use of kraton so now I only take it for two or three days when my pain flares up (usually then the weather is changing, or if I have had to stand on concrete for extensive periods.) I may use it a couple times a month and sometimes go months without needing it. I never had ANY withdrawal symptoms. I have never had cravings.

Kraton is a safe, effective natural substance and alternative to the opioid epidemic that is sweeping America today.  Its availability as a home remedy should not be interfered with. Banning it makes as much sense as banning chamomile tea, or steaming eucalyptus leaves because toxic chemicals can be extracted and concentrated from them which would be dangerous in high enough doses.

As a scientist who has studied the literature and experimented personally, I want to state for the record that the desire to ban kraton by classifying its component alkaloids as a class 1 substance is NOT based on science or on a public health crisis.

documents.commentText: I strongly encourage the DEA to pursue a science-based, freemom-first approach to drug policy in America. From the inclusion of cannabis in Schedule I drugs (along with heroin) to the recent flip-flop on the scheduling of Kratom, the DEA has shown its inability to make smart, informed decisions on the natures of psychoactive chemicals in our society. The three main drugs in America are tobacco, alcohol and caffeine (found in high concentrations in coffee, and markedly less so in tea). All of these drugs pose a high risk of addiction, dependency and death if over-consumed. Yet, these are the most accepted drugs in American society today. DEA policy ignores basic science on drugs and claims drugs like kratom and cannabis have no place in society due to their extreme danger and lack of medical benefits. Yet, this is simply not true. The Dea ignores the fact that alcohol acts on neurotransmitter receptors in the brainstem, critical for life-sustaining functions like heartbeat and respiratory function and this is remarkably capable of ending human life at relatively low doses. Cannabis and Kratom on the other hand are, profoundly so, drugs that act on cortical brain regions, and thus are incapable in the traditional way of ending someone's life, in the way that alcohol and heroin can.

documents.commentText:
I am a 51 year old licensed therapist, with a BA in psychology, an MA in Clinical Social Work and over 25 years in the mental health field.  I also run a part-time dog training business and am the Founder of a non-profit animal welfare organization. I am hard working, independent, active, passionate, and I live to help others.  I also take Kratom to help with my Fibromyalgia, so that I can continue to lead an independent, productive and benevolent lifestyle.

About 12 years ago, Fibromyalgia, a chronic, debilitating pain condition, began stealing my life from me.  While I once worked 50+ hours a week, making an annual income of $50,000 and led an outgoing, active lifestyle, Fibromyalgia gradually reduced me to a "shell" of my former self, mentally and physically.  I eventually had to quit work, spent all of my financial assets to survive, and almost lost my home. From day to day I literally never knew if I could get out of bed.  Just going to the grocery store took the effort of running a marathon. I couldn't imagine spending the next 10, 20, 30 years in such misery.  

I was near seeking governmental disability financial assistance when I found Kratom a little over a year ago.  That discovery started my ascent back to a life of functioning and actually enjoying life.  I am now working 20-25 hours a week, have re-energized my volunteer efforts, and I feel "normal" much of the time.  I still have Fibromyalgia, and some days are harder than others, but Kratom helps with my pain and chronic fatigue, allowing me to be productive (and happy) more days than not.  I am back to being the person I was meant to be.  

At the end of the day, dont we ALL just want to be happy and productive, and live our lives relatively free from pain?  Losing access to this naturally occurring, affordable, herbal supplement would take that away from me and from so many others trying to live with, yet suffering from, chronic health issues.  As a well-educated, conscientious and productive citizen who benefits from Kratom, I ask that you not place it on the Schedule I controlled substance list.    Thank you.

documents.commentText:
Banning kratom expands the war on drugs, while the public overwhelmingly supports ending it.
If kratom is added to any one of the five drug schedules, people who use it will be criminalized and locked up behind bars.
Kratom has been used safely by millions of people in the U.S. and evidence supports kratom's potential as a pain reliever and opioid replacement.
Many people struggling with opioid addiction have turned to kratom to help them cut back or quit, but now all promising scientific studies on kratom's role in opioid treatment could be immediately shut down.
Side effects of kratom are minimal, and its withdrawal symptoms are weak and nearly inconsequential compared to the suffering of people trying to quit opioids.
Prohibiting kratom will worsen the country's problems of opioid addiction and overdose.

documents.commentText:
I am a 54 year old female with a Master's in Science, a high school science teacher, and a mother of 2 home-schooled children who are now in college. I have suffered with chronic pain, fatigue, migraines, depression and anxiety for 40 years. I have PTSD and panic attacks as a result of dealing with my daughter's life-threatening disease for the past 8 years. Kratom has helped me cope with these issues and I am staunchly opposed to its scheduling, at any level.

At 14, I began using alcohol and drugs to cope with anxiety and depression. My use of these substances lasted for 18 years and had expectedly negative consequences. I am lucky to have survived those years. I never wanted to have children if it would mean having them see their mother under the influence of alcohol or drugs so I quit cold turkey on October 23, 1993 and have never used since.  

Soon after, I had my first child. The chronic fatigue, pain and debilitating migraines (from what would later be diagnosed as fibromyalgia) made it hard to be the kind of mom I wanted to be. I averaged 60 days a year lost to this illness, days where I could not get up and my toddler would have to call my husband home from work. 

I spent the next 20 years desperately trying to find something that would help me with my symptoms, but had little luck. Prescription drugs made me feel sicker and were not safe for me to be taking while I was driving or caring for my children. The depression and guilt from being in bed was overwhelming. Getting through each day was exhausting. As my children got older I realized they too were exhibiting the same symptoms and my search for a safe treatment was even more important.

Then I learned about kratom on the internet. I had tried so many things over the years, that it was hard for me to get my hopes up. But because of the testimonies of hundreds of people, I decided to try it and the results surprised me. Within 30 minutes of consuming kratom, I actually felt good!  Not drugged, not high, not impaired in any way. Just pain-free!  Anyone who has suffered from chronic pain knows that feeling 'normal' is the best feeling you could ever ask for!  And the fact that a natural supplement can provide this is very important to me. 

Kratom is not a cure for my illness, there is no known cure. What it is, is something that takes away my pain, safely, naturally and affordably. It is something that helps me to be productive. It is something that allows me to focus on the things I need to be doing to improve my health, like exercising, preparing healthy meals, getting enough sleep.  In addition to the pain relief, it also has helped tremendously with my depression and anxiety. It is the first thing that has ever worked like this, without negative side-effects. I have never had any withdrawal symptoms. If I don't have kratom on a given day, my symptoms simply return as before.

To wake up one morning and find out that this plant, which I enjoy as a relaxing tea, could now be a Schedule 1 substance, is devastating!  Especially after so many years of searching for relief. The very thought that I could go to prison for treating my pain with a completely safe and natural plant is mind-boggling. It would make more sense to schedule coffee, something that I do have side-effects from when consumed!  

As the past few months have gone by, I have seen hundreds of stories shared by others whose lives have been improved by kratom, and I am deeply saddened and completely ashamed that my government would ban this plant!  I am so scared for those who will return to prescription opiates or heroin. I have talked with people who would rather end their lives than return to those days of addiction. I am terrified to wake up one day to find out that they are gone because the help they had found was taken away from them.

Our government needs to listen to the thousands of people telling their stories of how kratom has changed their lives. They need to listen to the voices of the people who are telling them they do not want the criminalization of a safe herbal supplement.  We must not take disabled vets, cancer patients, moms, dads, grandparents, college students, and prescription opiate and heroin addicts that are finally turning their lives around, and turn them into criminals. Consuming a plant, rather than taking a synthetic pill, is something we should all have the freedom to choose.  Additional benefits of this plant may only be discovered if it remains legal and completely accessible. If the DEA truly cares about getting people off of dangerous drugs and back to productive lives, they will reconsider this decision and leave kratom legal as it should be.

Thank you for taking the time to review and consider my personal story.  I hope you will come to realize what the rest of us have experienced to be true in regards to this safe member of the coffee plant family.

Julie Thalman

documents.commentText:
Hello, my name is Catherine Craig. I am a 26 year caregiver and a mother of two year old twins. I am writing today to express my opposition to the proposal to classify kratom as a Schedule I Narcotic. I have been an almost daily user of kratom for almost a year to help control my chronic pain. In 2015, I had a full hysterectomy for the painful disease of endometriosis. It was supposed to end my pain and give me quality of life back. Instead it resulted in two more emergency surgeries to control bleeding. The amount of surgeries I had in such a short period has affected my healing and now I am living with painful scar tissue in my abdominal area. Now I am in living in constant pain, many days are as bad or worse than before my surgeries. I realized about a month after my surgeries that I didn't have options for pain management. Physical therapy barely helped, the narcotic medicine that I was given immediately after my surgery was only a short-term solution, and no pain clinics will take me because of my condition. It was after I started to research natural alternatives that I came across kratom. I learned that Kratom is a completely natural substance; it is a tree indigenous to southeast asia that has been used traditionally for centuries, and most of it comes into the country in powdered leaf form. I read testimony after testimony and thought that this plant was too good to be true. But I had no other options, so I ordered some. Within 15 minutes of ingesting a small dose of the powdered leaf, my pain was nearly gone. Instead of struggling to do the simplest tasks like make bottles or change diapers, I was rolling around, laughing, and playing with my kids on the floor. I also noticed that I didn't have the fog or feeling of intoxication that came from narcotic pain medicine. I was clear headed and nearly pain free, and almost in tears with that realization. The days that I don't take kratom, I don't have withdrawal as I would if I was taking narcotic pain medicine and suddenly stopped.

I am depending on this safe, natural, plant, to live a quality life. If I am not longer able to use kratom to combat my pain, I will no longer be able to hold a position that fits my skillset or experience. I will have difficulty finding and keeping work, which will lead to financial hardship and potential loss of housing. I won't be able to chase my toddlers around and be the carefree mother that can keep up with them. I will become what I hope they don't remember of me: a woman struggling to take care of them, spending much of her time lying on the couch. Kratom makes me a better mother and member of society. I'm begging you to take my story and others' into consideration.

Thank you very much for taking the time to read.

documents.commentText:
I don't feel my story is as riveting as many, but I would like to tell it because kratom is an important part of my regimen for maintaining my health. I think it is incomprehensible that this herb would be scheduled at all. Please do NOT schedule this herb as a schedule 1 drug.  
It is not a drug at all. It is an herb that is beneficial to so many people in so many ways and for the DEA to do anything to hinder its availability to consumers, I feel would be detrimental.

For my personal situation... I am 50 years old and have several auto immune conditions. I work full time managing two restaurants, and a typical day requires a minimum of 10 hours of standing, walking, and various physical activities, all while engaging with customers. A couple of the conditions are easily controlled and do not interfere with these activities. However, I have TWO types of arthritis - osteoarthritis and rheumatoid arthritis that originally manifested itself as juvenile arthritis when I was a child.   A while back, I began taking licorice root, as well as a few other herbs to control inflammation, and this helped me reduce the amount of NSAIDS and Cox 2 inhibitors that I have to take, and this was great because both of those medications can be detrimental to an intestinal issue I have and I had to take ADDITIONAL medications for my stomach to tolerate the OTHER medications.
I also had to take Tramadol for the pain, and as time went on and as the long days wore on, the dosage had to be increased. 
I had several concerns about this.  I discussed stronger pain medications with my doctor, but I really did not want to move in that direction.  Fifty years old is not young, but the average white female has a life span of 81.2 years, and arthritis is not going anywhere any time soon. I could conceivably have over 31 MORE YEARS  of increasing pain medications to manage my conditions, and I have no desire to become part of the opioid epidemic.      
I researched and tried multiple herbs without much success until I tried kratom. I found kratom was incredibly helpful in controlling and reducing my pain throughout the day, and on most days I don't feel I need pain medications to complete my tasks. Kratom and reduced pain has the additional benefit of giving me the energy to get through the day without interfering with cognition in any way. 
It was a relief when the emergency ban was halted and I appreciate the opportunity to offer my opinion on the availability of kratom.
Please do NOT schedule kratom.  It is an amazing herb with the potential to help so many people. 
Thanks so much for considering my input.

documents.commentText: To whomever this may concern. I want to say this herb is saving my life and my family. I'm a recovering heroin addict and pain pills addict. Let's be totally honest I would take any opiate to get high or just not be sick. I used to think I had my addiction under control and that I wasn't like the others the true junkies. I was in for a real shock because in fact I was just like all the other addicts. I thought I had it under control because I'd get high go to work and pay my bills and get things done. I had been hiding the fact that I was using heroin to everyone around me. I would sneak off to go get high and think that everything was just fine. I'd keep as many pills around as I could for the times I couldn't get any junk so I wouldn't get sick. I never realized until it was too late that I didn't have this under control that in fact I was in a vicious downward spiral. Everyone except me could see something was wrong they just didn't know what was wrong at the time. I kept on lying all the way up until it all collapsed around me. My wife took my kids and left me and my friends were all upset and didn't want to talk to me. That's when I came clean about my heroin abuse and tried to quit the first time. I tried to just quit cold turkey and let me tell that was brutal so very brutal. I was sick all the time and angry at the world. I couldn't function without being high anymore. I was freaking out like my world was coming to an end. All I wanted was to not be sick any more. So I took a hydrocodone one day because I was in so much pain it was unreal and I felt great. It was wonderful I wasn't sick I didn't hurting I didn't have the crazy thoughts or shakes or nothing. Then I said to myself hey I can do these and feel good but not have to do the h. I thought it was a great idea and didn't feel I had to hide it from anyone. So I got high again but on pills this time and sine it was pills and not the junk and I wasn't using a needle and not hiding it I thought everything was fine again. I was wrong everything wasn't fine. I just kept doing more and more started with just hydros or vicodin at low doses then started doing more and more. Then I found perckocet then moved on to oxycodone. I loved the oxy maybe more than the heroin. I was doing more and more and more to get high. I would do a lot in just one sitting just to get that rush by this point I was snorting them. I kept this up for a few years thinking I'm so brilliant that I found a way to stay high that's not bad for me and not causing all the problems I had with heroin. I was lying to myself again. Everything was not OK I was still getting high. I figured that out when my wife told me there's a problem after she realized I buying drugs instead of paying bills. Then she threatened to leave me again. So I started trying to quit using again. I was on day four some of the worst brutal withdrawals I've ever had and started looking for some way to get high. That's when a friend told me about kratom. I went and found some and took the dose my friend recommended. It was amazing how it worked it didn't take away all the symptoms of the withdrawals but I felt much better. I didn't have the cramps and diarrhea. I wasn't feeling lost and depressed and I wasn't so stupid high I couldn't function. I felt like I might have found help getting of the stuff with this natural herb. Then right after I found it there was a ban placed on it. I was shocked like damn I just found something to help me and there taking it away. I felt lost and ran right back for some pills. Now I hear the ban has been temporary lifted and that it's underconsideration to not ban. I for one am in favor of not banning this herb because I am great full for the help it started to give me and would like to pursue more of it in help with my path to sobriety. I hear stories all the time of how it's helped people and honestly feel it could help me. So please do take this life changing herb from those of us who could really use it to get free and clean.

documents.commentText:
My name is Mary Jonsson and I am a 38 year old resident of Ohio. I am writing in regard to Docket No. DEA-442W which concerns the scheduling of mitragynine and 7-hydroxymitragynine, two alkaloids of the plant kratom, under the Controlled Substances Act. I would like to voice my strong opposition to the scheduling of kratom's alkaloids which would effectively ban kratom in the United States.
     Ground kratom leaves prepared as herbal tea have become an important supplement in my daily routine over the past two years after a prescription antibiotic left me in severe pain and with lasting joint and tendon damage, among other issues. Kratom, along with my other supplements, has helped improve my mobility and quality of life.I have had periods of time in which I refrain from drinking kratom tea, when traveling for example, and suffered no ill effects or withdrawal symptoms. Based on my two years of personal experience kratom has proven to be a safe supplement with no major side effects and very low risk of dependency. Since implementing kratom tea into my regimen I have not experienced any negative changes in my overall health, and if I remove kratom from my routine the only negative effect is that my tendon and joint pain become apparent again. I am grateful to have this herb as an option to help manage my symptoms and I strongly feel that as a responsible adult I should continue to have this option for myself. 
     Kratom helps many like me, but it has also been shown to be an effective and safe means for those who are suffering from opioid dependency and addiction. There has been bipartisan support to halt the scheduling of kratom for this very reason. Representative Brad Wenstrup of Ohio's Disctrict 2 wrote to me that kratom can be a useful harm reduction tool in the fight against opiate addiction that plagues my state and so many others. Heroin use is at epidemic proportions and so many addicts began as pain patients receiving prescription opiates. If others were aware of the non-opioid option of managing chronic pain symptoms with kratom there would be fewer people becoming addicted to prescription drugs in the first place. Edward Boyer, professor of emergency medicine and director of medical toxicology at the University of Massachusetts Medical School, spoke to Scientific American magazine about a patient who consumed kratom tea daily. Boyer stated about the patient, "After his stay at Mass General, he went off kratom cold turkey. The fascinating thing is that his only withdrawal symptom was a runny nose. As for his opioid withdrawal, we learned that kratom blunts that process...awfully well." 
     The studies on kratom's alkaloids are few but very promising. University of Mississippi's School of Pharmacy faculty member Christopher R. McCurdy and his colleagues found in research on lab rats that mitragyna speciosa prevented the animals from self-administering cocaine when given the opportunity. The researchers also observed that rats who had been accustomed to morphine did not suffer typical withdrawal symptoms after stopping morphine and being administered kratom. This important research validates the anecdotal evidence of the many testimonies from former addicts who have found relief in kratom and have been able to go back to productive lives. 
     Leaves of the mitragyna speciosa tree have been safely used in Southeast Asia for centuries, and in the United States for at least two decades. The deaths in recent years that have been attributed to kratom are misleading because each case when examined closer involved a poly-pharmacologic mixture of chemicals known to cause fatality and there is no reason to assume kratom, of all of those found, was the cause of death. For sake of debate, if we take the number of deaths attributed to kratom at face value we see that 15 deaths over a span of years is a remarkable safety profile for any consumable product. Let's compare those numbers to other everyday "safe" products. According to FDA data, over-the-counter analgesic acetaminophen is associated with deaths even at recommended dosing and is responsible for 213 deaths one year. In the same year data shows NSAIDS tallying up 3,443 deaths in the same year. As of 2014 there have been 34 deaths from energy drinks. This proves that kratom is indeed not an imminent public heath crisis.
     Please consider this information and keep kratom unscheduled and available for responsible adults. Scheduling will result in suffering by the many people whose pain is made manageable by kratom, and those who have found a path out of addiction with kratom. Scheduling kratom will stifle research on the plant which has shown so much promise in the fight against our opioid epidemic. Scheduling kratom will have untold economic effects. Besides directly affecting thousands of kratom vendors and their employees, but what will become of the thousands more who credit kratom with allowing them to go back to work? Thank you.

I considerably oppose the DEA attempting to make Kratom a schedule I substance, as it clearly show just how corrupt the government can be to take an herb, a plant, and try to classify it as an illicit "drug"  - and for all in fear of big pharmacies losing money because this natural remedy actually helps people come off prescriptions.

I started using Kratom about a year ago, after being diagnosed with bi-polar II, severe depression, and anxiety. The medications thrown at me were useless and did nothing but make me a zombie. I was unable to work some days because of the negative side-effects of these medications. I am big into organic and all natural foods and products and knew there had to be something else out there.

I found Kratom and did a lot of research. Hours, really. I wasn't just going to put anything in my body until I was 100% confident of what it entailed. Kratom changed my life. On top of my mental stresses, I also suffer from debilitating migraines. Migraines in which I have been prescribed pain killers to help fight...I have been able to reduce, if not, eliminate pain killers now that I have the supplement of Kratom. It pains me to know that it's statements like these, will be seen more as a negative for big pharm companies over the sheer thought of losing money in the pain killer industry more than a positive statement that involves the well-being of the people in this country. 

Kratom needs to stay available - to me, it is no different than herbal supplements that you find at GNC, or anywhere else. Damiana, for example, is another leaf-based plant that is used for anxiety, even pain. Found at GNC, online, etc. Kratom should not at any point need federal or state regulation. It has been around for nearly a hundred years, used in many different countries (and still is) - and it has no reason to be monitored or regulated by anyone but the people who farm and sell it. This is not a new product, it's just new to the wrong people/companies- the people who don't want to see a product like this being popular. By making more of  a scene, Kratom is getting more attention. The product should have been left alone and it should continue to be left alone - it has helped so many people come off of pain killer addictions and so many people get their lives back. That is not up to the government to take away. I'm from New Hampshire, where it's live free or die - I choose to live free.

documents.commentText:
The War on Drugs has had a catastrophic impact on the trust between law enforcement and the communities they serve. We need to restore that trust, and allowing for research and regulation of drugs like kratom will be a significant step. 

Banning kratom expands the war on drugs, while the public overwhelmingly supports ending it. If kratom is added to any one of the five drug schedules, people who use it will be criminalized and locked up behind bars.Kratom has been used safely by millions of people in the U.S. and evidence supports kratom's potential as a pain reliever and opioid replacement. Many people struggling with opioid addiction have turned to kratom to help them cut back or quit, but now all promising scientific studies on kratom's role in opioid treatment could be immediately shut down.  Side effects of kratom are minimal, and its withdrawal symptoms are weak and nearly inconsequential compared to the suffering of people trying to quit opioids. Prohibiting kratom will worsen the country's problems of opioid addiction and overdose.

Kratom is something that helps people who are suffering from pain, insomnia, opiate addiction, and other ailments.  It is asinine to allow it to be banned based off of vague research and nothing substantial in terms of damage.  The fact that alcohol, tobacco, and other various herbs and substances remain legal yet cause multiple times more damage than kratom speaks volumes about the dangers of it.

Kratom has helped me with pain management ever since I've started taking it because my doctor doesn't want to put me on anything stronger than I'm taking for servere arthritis in my knee. I was taking 50mg of Oxycodone a day before I started kratom and now I'm taking tramadol as well as 5-6 grams of kratom that help more and it doesn't make me feel high.  It's not a recreational drug as you'd like to claim it to be, it is in my personal experience, an herb like so many others that provides relief when it's needed most. 

If anyone uses kratom as a way to get high they will reap no benefits from it besides possible sleepiness and upset stomach.  In any case, it would be far more detrimental to schedule it as a drug when it has almost nothing in common with the drugs you are planning to classify it alongside of.  Please do not schedule it as a drug when it is not.

documents.commentText: In reference to Docket No DEA-442W. I am a 34 year old Mom, wife, MBA graduate and responsible Kratom consumer.  Kratom helps me better manage my sobriety from alcohol.  I cannot understand how the government can consider making Kratom a schedule 1 narcotic when people are allowed to drink alcohol every day.   Alcohol kills 88,000 people a year in this country not including the 9,967 deaths attributed to drunk driving.  Alcohol  can cause the consumer of the beverage to be violent, increases the transmissions of STDs, causes blackouts, greatly lowers inhibitions which can cause terrible decision making, and results in many health problems such as cirrhosis of the liver, and many cancers.  Alcohol is also the number one drug that teenagers use, and is the number one cause of death by drugs used by teenagers.  I know alcohol is not on trial here, nor do I think it should be unavailable for people, but it can be very dangerous, and it is directly related to me and my life, and therefore a big part of my story.  Alcohol almost killed me, and I mean that quite literally.  It not only ruined my liver (which luckily has repaired itself), but it also turned me into a person that I did not know or even want to know.  I have severe anxiety and depression.  That is what made me originally want to drink so much.  When trying to get sober and work on my anxiety, I tried many pharmaceuticals that were supposed to help with both of those problems.  WOW!!  They make you crazier then you were to begin with, or at least that is the way they worked on me. I believe each persons body makeup is different and he/she should be able to have access to many options to help with the betterment of their health and well-being.  I am now a big fan of naturally occurring substances to supplement my general well-being, and I believe we, not only as American citizens, but as humans on this earth, should be able to have access to these plants and herbs.  I feel God put these plants and herbal substances on this earth to help us, and we should be able to do so without paying a doctor or pharmaceutical company for something that grows naturally.  Also, with the health care system as it is today, many cannot afford insurance or medicine.  I am the only person who knows how a supplement or pharmaceutical works or doesnt work for me, my life, and my body. After giving up on pharmaceuticals to help with my alcohol addiction and anxiety, I looked online for something natural and safe that would not only help with these problems that were ruining my life, but also allow me to live my life with a clear head.  I found Kratom six years ago.  When I was drinking alcohol, I could not live a normal life.  I could not work, did not talk to family or friends, and just sat secluded in my room drinking and killing myself.  Since I have found Kratom, my life has greatly changed for the better.  I am married with two young children, work out every day, and I am rebuilding the parts of my life that alcohol took from me.  Kratom helps me maintain my sobriety as well as helps to reduce my anxiety and depression.  Kratom does not lower my inhibitions, or fog my head the way alcohol did.  It simply helps me feel better so I can live a healthier, happier, and more productive life.  I feel I am a good mom, wife, and productive member of society now.  I have not had any negative side effects from consuming Kratom.  Kratom does not cause psychosis, hallucinations, anger, or even dulled intellect as some have claimed.  I have had well doctor checkups and blood work, and am the best and healthiest me that I have been in my adult life. Kratom is not something that kids take (although I would not object to making it available for only 21+), or that people use to get high.  Kratom has been in America for 20 + years and many had never even heard of it prior to this proposed ban, which in itself should prove its safety profile.  It would not have been able to fly under the radar for so long if it was a dangerous herb or a legal high. The people who take Kratom are Moms, Dads, Grandmas, Grandpas, professionals, stay at home parents, educated, and productive members of society, who have found Kratom to be a good addition to the supplements they take to better their general health and well-being.  Kratoms safety profile is wonderful compared to all other readily available substances including but most defiantly not limited to, Tylenol, ibuprofen, alcohol, cigarettes, energy drinks, and caffeine.  Tylenol is in fact, the leading cause of poison control center calls in the United States each year and is responsible for 56,000 emergency room visits, and 458 deaths per year.  Cigarettes are responsible for an astounding 480,000 deaths in the US each year.  Kratom alone has not been proven to be the cause of any overdoses or deaths.  Please do not schedule this tea leaf.  We should have a say in what we can take into our bodies.

documents.commentText:
I was raised and lived in the Belmont/Laconia area of NH from 1972 until 2012. Below you will find my Sons and my journey from addiction to life. Please do not ban or criminalize Kratom.
I knew in 2005-2006 that prescription drug abuse was rampant among the students in Gilford High School. My children and their friends would openly talk about it. They werent hard to come by they just took them from mom and dad's medicine cabinets. That is how it starts, right under your nose. 
Seven years ago my oldest son was working at a local pizza shop in Gilford, NH. He and his friends would work 12 hour shifts. It started out as just a way to get a little pep in your step for the long night ahead, you know a little buzz. The first time he snorted a  of Percocet he immediately vomited. But boys will be boys and they egged each other on. The second time, it hit the Sweet Spot.  Work was fun, nothing bothered him and he never had a bad day. He was emotionally numb.  But what he didnt realize was it was then he also lost himself and I lost my son. His girlfriend and soon to be mother of his children lost the love of her life. Soon his only focus was finding a way not to get sick. He couldnt keep a job because he was always taking time off or being late because he had to find a fix so he could feel normal. I cant tell you how many things have been stolen, pawned, borrowed, and lost unexpectedly. The lies and deceit, the hurt and pain for those of us who love an addict is palpable. The relationships that have been ruined, the time in jail, and the costs associated with trying to fix them, Ive lost count of. If you are a single parent with no real resources you are own your own. Rehab is expensive, Im his mom and even for me, he couldnt stop. It is so easy for people to point fingers and say things like they choose to use, and what losers they are but I can tell you that most addicts were real, good and loving people before they started using and they still are but they and their brains have been hijacked. He was lost. He welcomed his first born into this world HIGH. He spent all of their money and they lost several apartments because of his addiction. I moved them in with me and that is where I saw firsthand what Opiate sickness/withdrawals will do to someone. They lived with me for several months and as always he would appear to be getting better. A month or two would go by and you could finally start to breathe again and then there would be $20.00 missing from your purse or his sisters. Or people would come by the house looking for him because he borrowed their PlayStation and I would know he was using again. That was my life for close to seven years. He would sober up form weeks at a time but it always ended the same way.  I ended up moving to OK in 2012 because I could no longer help him and was physically and emotionally sick myself. I had to abandon my first born because I didnt have bottomless pockets to send him to a 30 day rehab and had nowhere else to turn.
In November 2015 he called to tell me if I couldnt get him out of there he was going to end up dead just like the other dozen or so of his friends who had overdosed.  I flew him to Oklahoma the week before Thanksgiving. I held him while he convulsed, wiped his tears as he mourned the loss of his children again, forgave him while he cursed me because I wouldnt give him the keys to my car so he could go buy smokes.  I knew better. 
 I also knew that he needed something to help with the sickness so I started doing research into holistic withdrawal treatments. Thats when I stumbled upon Kratom. I read everything I could find about it. I joined a Facebook page dedicated to its use. I spent days and nights reading everything I could find, I got myself educated. 
He was now 5 days into withdrawals.  I ordered 4 ounces of Red Vein Kratom and gave him his first dose, about two teaspoon mixed with water. He gagged and almost threw up but he managed to keep it down and within 20 minute his legs were finally still. The color returned to his face and the strained look of withdrawal was lessening its grip. I ordered more! He looked at me and started crying. He didnt have to say anything, I knew it was working. He is now 361 days clean, has a full time job, has paid off the $800.00 plane ticket that got him here and is paying his child support weekly. We can talk about his addiction now, where before it was an untouchable subject. He tells me that he no longer even thinks about heroin and that Kratom doesnt get him high, it evens him out. He also has ADD and he is able to focus  He has told me that he knows without Kratom he would have gone back to street drugs. 
I have been seeing all the negative news about Kratom and can tell you from personal experience they do not ring true for me and my son. Kratom is not the monster, Opiate addiction is. Please do not ban or make criminal the ONLY substance that is ORGANIC and works.

documents.commentText:
I have been using Kratom for almost six months now. I discovered Kratom after going through a very long and drawn out process of recovering from a back injury that I sustained in 2014. The issue consisted of bulging and herniated discs. I tried addressing it with a chiropractor, epidural shots, and multiple surgeries - all of which were unsuccessful in treating my condition to where I still currently live in pain. Throughout the two plus years that I have been dealing with it, I was on an assortment of drugs from painkillers to muscle relaxers to anti-nausea medications that got rid of the side-effects of the others. The opioids I was taking - Oxycodone, Hydrocodone, and Soma all made me unable to function as a normal person. They dulled me and made me an unproductive member of the US working force. I've been unemployed since the injury because of it.

However, since discovering Kratom I have been making great strides towards recovery and have been able to come off of all of the painkillers I was on previously. It does not get me high. I do not take it recreationally. It allows me to function as a normal person without as much pain. Without Kratom I would still be on the drugs that nearly killed my liver and made me unable to work at all. With the herbal supplement, I am almost able to look for work again but that may change if the DEA goes through with the Schedule 1. If they do, many people like me will have to turn back to the opiates that we got off of and many will be unable to continue to be taxpayers into our system. This decision has also harmed businesses, families, and loved ones. 

I know of several small businesses that had to close their doors due to the DEA's Scheduling announcement and may never open again. I know of families who now are now in fear of an age without Kratom because it allows their providers to be able to go to work and interact with them. And worst of all, the government will lose out on extra tax revenue generated by the regulation of the herb and will instead turn to drug companies or to the black market for even harder, more damaging substances. 

The DEA's decision to Schedule 1 Kratom will have profound effects on the users, their families, businesses, and the country should they go through with it. I urge you to delay and reconsider this course of action.

Thank you.

documents.commentText: My name is Eric Hutton, and I'm a 37 year old Doctor of Pharmacy working in a retail setting. Ever since graduating school and assuming a full-time position (an "upright" one, at that), I've dealt with a significant amount of back pain--significant not in its severity, but in its unrelenting presence--as well as the fatigue and stress that come with any job where your entire day is spent on your feet, often with the phone pressed between your shoulder and your ear. After several failed attempts to find something "wrong" with me (X-rays, MRI, ultrasound, etc.), I was starting to consider seeing a pain management specialist (and there are several in the vicinity of my work, so I was familiar with the types of treatment they offer). Still, I was hesitant, because without an official diagnosis, and an unwillingness to "play up" my pain level on command, I doubted they'd take me seriously. Plus, I got to see the cycle of dependency on a daily basis--patients who started out with a broken arm or some surgical procedure being prescribed short-term opioids, which gradually turns into long-term use, until they're referred to pain management where regular, around-the-clock opioids become a staple of the patient's regimen indefinitely (unless they're weaned off with an expensive prescription of suboxone, which often turns into an indefinite treatment itself). Luckily, it was right around this time that I discovered kratom. I was extremely skeptical that it would do anything, but within 30 minutes or so of consuming it for the first time, there was a mild but noticeable lift in my mood and energy, which then seemed to make the nagging pain more tolerable. After an initial period of finding the right level for me, I was able to take it at work, and get reliable relief that was just enough to enable me to smile and be engaged with our patients, even at the end of a 12 hour shift. The effects are about as noticeable as a strong cup of coffee (maybe two), but instead of being solely a nervous, jittery buzz, it provides a balanced sense of clarity and well-being. I've been taking kratom for nearly four years now, and have not had to escalate my usage to achieve the same effects. I've discussed it with my primary care physician, and he is thrilled that I've found something natural that alleviates my discomfort without putting me at the unnecessary risk associated with prescription pain killers. If a kratom ban were to go into effect, my quality of life would be significantly reduced without access to this safe, beneficial herb. Beyond that, I fear the quality of my care towards others would likewise be diminished--it's hard to be a truly good listener and problem-solver when all you can think about is how badly you want to sit down. With tobacco-related health care costs in the billions and ~480,000 deaths annually (CDC figures), I cannot understand why *this* harmless plant would be seen as posing an "imminent threat" to public safety. Additionally, considering the scope and severity of the current heroin/opioid epidemic, in my professional opinion it would be significantly *more* harmful to make a safe, natural alternative unavailable. I urge the decision-makers to look at the science, look at the data (not just in isolation, but as part of the bigger picture), and ask yourselves where the imminent threats to public safety TRULY lie. Thank you for your time.

documents.commentText:
I began using kratom in 2006 as a workout supplement after reading about its energizing and pain relieving properties on the internet.  It quickly became a coffee substitute, helping me power through my morning classes at the university without the jitters or crash of espresso.  

It wasn't long before I realized another benefit of kratom: it alleviated my severe menstrual cramps caused by endometriosis, as well as helping curb my migraines.  Both of these ailments would cause me to miss at least 2 days of work and school every month.  With kratom I still had to take it easy, but I was able to make it to class and carry out basic responsibilities rather than being stuck on the bathroom floor in agony, vomiting and fainting from the pain.  

Doctors have been reluctant to prescribe narcotics to someone my age for a recurring pain condition due to the risk of addiction, so I'm stuck with NSAIDs like ibuprofen which didn't work then or now.  Kratom is literally the only thing standing between me and disability.  I have regular blood tests and physicals, and there are no signs that kratom has damaged my body in any way.  My physician is fully aware of my use of kratom and other supplements.

I now have a full-time job that offers very limited sick leave and am responsible for maintaining a household with my partner.  If kratom becomes unavailable, I will have to take unpaid leave several times a month and potentially risk losing my job due to excessive absences.  Please consider the impact that banning kratom will have on working people like me.  I do not want to end up jobless and on welfare after working so hard to get where I am.  Chronic pain is a crushing burden to live with, and losing my livelihood to it would be too much to bear.  

Thank you for your consideration. 

Sincerely,

Tangi Haines

documents.commentText:
I'm a professional writer and editor who has worked for a variety of publications in New York. My degree is in public policy and I've worked in a state government department. I came across the notice of intent posted by the DEA in early September and heavily researched the medical and scientific studies about Kratom, interviewed Kratom users, applied basic policy analysis methods and reported on the issue in September. 

The DEA's conclusion that Kratom is a threat to public health does not appear to be substantiated by the references provided in the notice of intent. At least, not adequately enough for the editors of this particular publication to agree that it poses a great risk to public health.

I really would like to urge the DEA to reconsider scheduling Kratom and instead allow the FDA to regulate it as a dietary supplement, much like Kava Kava or similar herbal remedies. My opinion is based on interaction with the public on this issue, the assessment of benefits and risks, and the overwhelming amount of success stories I've received from those who use this herb as part of an all-natural alternative medicinal routine. 

Thank you for allowing a public comment period. I believe this is an important issue to many people who would like to believe that the DEA is an agency that makes well-researched decisions based on science. The political culture right now is divisive, and I believe it would be in the agency's best interest, and in the public's interest, to allow the FDA to classify this as a supplement.
