documents.commentText: There need to be definite dosage limits if Kratom is available to the general public. A new user can easily ingest more than enough and not realize the serious side effects. My adult child took kratom in the evening and awoke several hours later to a severe headache, chills, nausea, dizziness and fever over 104 degrees. At 103.6 degrees she felt her fever had finally broken. Nobody in close contact received similar symptoms.  The extreme symptoms lasted for 3 days and nausea and weakness for several more.  I realize there can be benefits to using Kratom but the severe side effects of possible overdose can and should be avoided by monitoring through a health care professional. This perhaps is a rare instance but frightening enough to cause concern. As of right now, Kratom dosages are left up to the user.

documents.commentText: I'm not going to write an entire essay here. I just want to voice my opinions on and experience of using  kratom (mitragyna speciosa). I have been taking kratom off and on for roughly five years. Which is to say I will take kratom for several months then stop for several months. I use it to help alleviate severe anxiety and depression and find it helps me to "deal" with hard situations in life. Such as recently when my mother was diagnosed with cancer. I am unable to take most prescription anxiety medications due to the side effects such as lethargy and severe shakes. Kratom on the other hand alleviates my anxiety with virtually no side effects. In my opinion there are two things that make kratom superior to prescription anxiety medications such as Xanax. Firstly, when kratom is taken as directed, as an herbal supplement, it does not induce lethargy and an inability to function in daily life when enough is taken to alleviate my anxiety and the same can not be said for Xanax. Secondly and probably most importantly is I am able to take it for several months and stop "cold turkey" with no physical side effects. The first and last time I used Xanax to treat anxiety I only used it for a 2-3 week period. At the end of that several week period I experienced what I believe to be withdraw symptoms caused by the Xanax. I was unable to sleep and felt very uncomfortable physically for 3 or 4 days. Kratom has never had that negative effect on me and I expect it never will after 5 years of use. The fact that the DEA has determined there are no medical uses for kratom but there are medical uses for Xanax and other worthless addictive prescription anxiety medications is pure insanity.

documents.commentText:
To Whom it May Concern,

My Name is Mandi Li. I am 38 years old. I have suffered feom anxiety and depression since I was a child, including many periods of suicidal ideations. I have done a great deal of therapy including inpatient, group, and one-on-one, which has certainly helped me throughout the years but did not "cure" me of my condition. I have also been prescribed more types of psychiatric medications than I could not possibly list with great accuracy, but I will make an attempt.Some of these medications include, but are not limited to, Paxil, Zoloft, ,Seroquel, Lamictal, Valium, Xanax, Ametryptolene, etc. Each new therapist seemed to have a slightly different idea about my diagnosis, and therefore, how I should be medicated. All of the medications I tried had more negative effects than positive. Some might make me feel less nervous, but the trade-off was feeling heavily sedated and therefore depresed. I always felt drugged. 

A few years ago, after having weaned myself off of paxil, somebody suggested that I try Kratom tea. Since it wasnt something that I would have to commit to taking every day, I decided to give it a try. It worked great for me. I felt somewhat energized and my anxiety went way down. I have been taking it on a somewhat regular basis, ever since, and haven't had the need to try any new psychiatric meds. Since being introduced to kratom, my life has become a great deal more enjoyable to me. I am happily married, have several close and healthy friendships, and have been at the same job longer than ever before. 

I do not see kratom as a drug to get high because it doesn't make me feel high. It makes me feel like a normal person, for the first time in my life. I finally feel able to do the things that normal people do, such as keeping a job, using the phone, going new places, going outside to exercise, having solid relationships, and even talking with new people, when necessary.

Kratom is a natural supplement that has made a very positive impact in my life, at a price I can afford. Please do not take this option away from me and the thousands of other people whom it has been helping.

documents.commentText: Hello, my name is Ed Quiggle, Jr. and I am commenting as an individual and as the founder of Pennsylvanians for Rational Drug Policy. I also have experience as a law enforcement officer, as I currently serve as a Pennsylvania State Constable. I strongly urge the DEA and FDA to keep kratom and it's chemical constituents, mitragynine and 7-HO mitragynine, regulated as a dietary supplement, and to not control them under the Controlled Substances Act. Kratom has a long history of human use, which establishes it's safety. Not a single death can be attributed to kratom use alone. Turning kratom users into criminals will not benefit society. documents.commentText:
I am firmly against the scheduling of Kratom.

I am not a drug user.  I am not trying to beat a heroine habit.  I'm a software engineer who suffers from chronic back pain.  I don't like to take acetaminophen because it's very bad for the liver, and I also hate to take ibuprofen because it gives me stomach aches.  A nurse friend of mine recommended that I try an herbal solution - kratom.  I rolled my eyes at the time because I assumed that a plant couldn't offer me any real pain relief.. otherwise I would have heard about it by now, right?  

I take two caplets in the morning and two after lunch, and my back pain is gone.  Incidentally, I also found that it was a more effective stimulant than coffee, which offers much more severe side effects.  I have been living caffeine and pain free since I discovered this supplement and I am truly floored by the idea that we are even considering a ban.

I had no idea that my government could reach into my cupboard and unceremoniously decide for me that I should have to live with liver damage, nausea, or back pain... because.. ?  I'm still not clear on the because part of all this.  Because it might act on the brain in similar ways to opiates?  Is this some horrific sin on its own, when it causes no demonstrable harm?  It was my understanding that the privilege of emergency scheduling was afforded to the DEA in order to combat the rapidly produced synthetic drugs that pose a clear and present danger to our public.  This is not happening right now... public opinion on kratom ranges from "What's that?" to "That literally changed/saved my life."  The number of deaths that are 'linked' to kratom is laughable to anyone with a college-level statistics class.  

I have done nothing wrong by availing myself of this natural form of pain relief.  You are not better than me because you use Advil instead... Or caffeine, for that matter.  The number of people killed by eating dishwasher detergent pods last year is much greater than the number (inconclusively) linked to kratom.  And hey ok.. folks are less likely to want to eat detergent pods so let's get away from the substance itself and talk about usage... You allow us to kill ourselves with alcohol and cigarettes, but you want to forbid us from the mild stimulant/pain reliever offered by kratom.  How in the world can you logically justify this ban?  

I am not a criminal.  Please don't make me one.

documents.commentText:
To Whom It May Concern,

I write because I am a kratom user who suffers from anxiety since I was a child, depression, and suicidal thoughts. After I graduated law school, my anxiety accelerated. A friend introduced me to kratom a year ago. I use half a teaspoon in a day to stay calm, focus, and be a productive asset to my job and to my family and friends. I use half a teaspoon at night to help me sleep and it has been more effective than drugstore pills which have side effects.  There are no side effects that I have experienced aside from nausea if I took too much kratom. You cannot overdose or die on kratom because your body will simply reject what it does not want in the form of vomiting. 

Kratom has helped me foster better relations with my co-workers. Instead of allowing my anxiety and depression to control me and keep my in my cubicle, I am more likely to have healthy face-to-face conversations with people which positively impacts my work products. I feel like I can interact more easily with people. I have a healthier relationship with my family now because I am able to open up more instead of hiding inside my shell. 

Thoughts of suicide are not as strong anymore. I feel like I have a place in society and a purpose and that's all because kratom keeps my mind calm enough so I can focus on what really matters. I don't focus and dwell on the negative thoughts that used to consume me.

Before kratom, I almost committed suicide when I was in law school.  The pressure was too much. I was already an anxiety-ridden person when I started law school and it got worse. I could not deal with the pressures my peers were okay dealing with. Kratom has changed my life since then.

Now, I take a mild anxiety medicine, Buspirone, which is prescribed by my doctor. In conjunction with kratom, I feel like I have control over my brain. I have never felt more in control before this. 

There are many students and young professionals like myself suffering with similar mental health issues and to take away the benefits kratom provides would deprive a lot of us of easy access to instant help when we need it. Taking away kratom also deprives the poor, who cannot afford to see a doctor for medication, access to this simple supplement. It would deprive people with chronic pains the ease of access to a harmless plant. 

We do not use this herb for fun, recreational purposes. We use it because we need it and it makes a positive difference in our lives. Regulation of the kratom industry would be wonderful. However, a complete ban or a pharmaceutical take-over is extreme and uncalled for. My life was saved thanks to kratom. I fight to keep it legally over-the-counter.

documents.commentText: Kratom is a very benificial and safe plant. I am 100% confident that simple research can prove this. Given the opiate epidemic in our country, it would be very irresponsible to not do the research first before making this decision. I believe if kratom is made illegal, it will have an immediate negitive impact on public health / our national opiate overdose statistics. To get an idea on the potential negative impact of the decision to schedule kratom, you can look no further than statistics of states which have made kratom illegal - whose rate of opiate overdoses has went up much more than normal. If you have been around an opiate addict who has been helped by kratom then you know that is a direct correlation and not a coincidence. I personally believe (and so do many others) that the number of opiate overdoses will skyrocket even higher in the U.S. if kratom is made illegal at the national level. I have seen kratom used with much success by opiate addicts as a safe alternative when matentance therapy is needed immediately, for example before finding a suboxone doctor (which can be a lengthly process sometimes), or in situations where the recovering addict is having difficulties getting on regular maintenance meds or maintaing their regular prescription for maintenance medication. Maintenance therapy is statistically the best chance an opiate addict has at beating the addiction to opiod medications and I believe that research would show that kratom is safe for theraputic maintence of addiction or even for maintenace of pain. I feel it's very irresponsible to make kratom illegal given that it is a non-dangerous subtance that simply provides theraputic maintenance for the many addicts struggling around the U.S. For instance, some users deal with pain or other similar triggers that seriously effect their quality of living and they simply cannot take normal opiate meds because that has the real potential to start a dangerous spiral of addiction for them. Also, in the event that the addict chooses to use a substance and there isn't a safe, theraputic substance like kratom to turn to then there is a very high likelyhood that they could turn to heroin or some substance that is much more dangerous instead. Also, regarding statistics on safety of substances, I have searched independently through datasets available through the poison control center call data and there is emperical evidence to show that kratom has less far less incidents than many over the counter medications and in cases where incidents were reported, the side effects of kratom were almost always reported to be "very mild" meaning not serious or in no way life threatening. In contrast to kratom, I think it should be considered that many simple substances such as "tylenol", or "energy drinks", or "diet supplements", or "coffee" (which are all deemed legal) show show a much higher rate of incident statistically with regard to ER visits or poision center calls and said incidents almost always carry along worse side effects and a significatly higher risk of use with regard to the seriousness of the side effects these OTC subtances have when taken improperly (again, in comparison to kratom). When I look at the benifits of kratom along with it's great record of the consumer easily being able taking a safe dosage versus the drastic consideration to just simply schdeule the substance as if it were dangerous... I start to worry that the sole incentive to schdule the substance is just based on greed being pulled at by the cogs in the patent system and I honestly worry that the overall public health of the U.S. with regard to opiate addiction is possibly not even being considered. Name brand companies can still profit without patents by selling kratom as a name brand supplment in pill form. A benificial plant doesn't need to be patented. At the very least, the growing opiate addiction issue should cause any scientific minded person to take notice and out of concern for the health of our nation's population consider that we should first do some research with kratom before just automatically making it schedule I. It's hard for me to believe that kratom is being considered dangerous without any actual research to back that claim. I hope that you will reconsider making kratom schedule I and do some research first before the significant opiate problem that our country faces grows even worse. I have see hope for the opiate crisis that our nation is facing in kratom... I've seen it with my own eyes... It is very useful and very safe. Please, let's not just discount it as some dangrous, illicit substance as a kneejerk reaction without any research similar to what happened with marijuana. We don't have to repeat history and keep making the same mistakes that we did almost a century ago. I would like to think that the scientific minded individuals and those who care about the health of the population have learned something over the past century.

  One primary benefit of kratom is that it has been shown to be very effective at increasing energy levels, which is one of the main reasons it is heavily used by many manual laborers in Thailand. Which shows why it would make a great natural way to reduce the effects of Chronic Fatigue Syndrome.

Kratom seems like a solution to a number of issues, including various forms of drug addiction and chronic pain. Plus, it can perform the pain-killing work of morphine without dangerously depressing breathing -- the way opioids do.

It uses a pathway that mediates many of the undesirable effects of traditional opioids such as constipation, respiratory depression. In fact, this knowledge is spurring additional research by pharmaceutical companies.
http://bit.ly/2c8UTI6

About Kratom, a leading researcher notes...
Thailand is considering legalizing kratom as a safer alternative for meth addicts. U.S. researchers are trying to study its potential to help opiate abusers kick the habit without withdrawal side effects.
http://bit.ly/2c8SI7v

There are anecdotal reports of addiction risk. But it appears the addiction can be broken without withdrawal symptoms. Meanwhile, the painkillers currently being used are more addictive, dangerous, and harder to kick. Yet...

documents.commentText:
I personally have found kratom, and it's active alkaloids, very therapeutic. I've been clean from heroin (and sober) since April 2013, and kratom, while not 100% essential to my recovery, has been a very helpful tool that helps with pain and sleeplessness without having to use dangerous and habit forming prescription, controlled substances such as opiates and benzodiazepines. If kratom becomes unavailable, my quality of life will greatly deteriorate, and I may be forced to talk to my doctor about alternatives that I left behind long ago.
One of the concerns noted by opponents is that the raw kratom could be "laced with other dangerous substances," which I find an absurd concern. Rather, it's absurd to think that banning kratom will somehow address that concern. If someone is going to sell legal plant matter laced with dangerous chemicals, the fact that kratom might be that vehicle makes no difference. If you ban kratom, they'll just lace something else with whatever dangerous chemical they're trying to sell. You saw this with the synthetic cannabis; you don't ban the smokeable incense on which the dangerous chemicals are sprayed, you ban the dangerous chemical. This argument is a straw man that makes no sense (not to mention the fact that no one has shown this actually happening).
I understand that everyone involved just wants to do what's best for everyone, and potentially locking people up for possessing a plant in the coffee family will do far more harm than good.

documents.commentText: It is absolutely in the best interest of Americans that Kratom remain legal and be removed from the DEA schedule 1 list of controlled substances. It is no secret that opiate addiction is an epidemic in this country, due to over prescription on the part of doctors and profiteering motives by the pharmaceutical industry. Kratom is a natural pain reliving alternative to opiate drugs and is available to individuals suffering from physical pain that are unable to afford health insurance. Criminalizing kratom would result in even more of an increase in heroine and prescription drug abuse and fill our already crowded for profit prisons with more nonviolent offenders.  It is important that our government recognize the failure of the war on drugs as well as the failure of prohibition that preceded it. Experts agree that drug abuse in this country would be far better handled if investments were made in rehabilitation treatment programs and Kratom is a healthier and safer alternative to opiate withdrawal drugs such as methadone and for that reason it should be researched and supported by our government.

documents.commentText:
I loved it best when I was working and having a full life.  I would still be doing so, if I could.

Now I am 70 years old and battling numerous difficult and life-threatening conditions.  Among them, I have Complex Regional Pain Syndrome, aka, Reflex Sympathetic Dystrophy.  It is known to be the most painful condition known to man.  

In the course of trying to find what would help my pain from CRPS, plus Neuroborreliosis (Late-Stage Neurological Lyme Disease), I tried Kratom for my pain.  It did help the pain.  No medications have been made for this severe pain, and no medications that I have tried have touched the pain; they only make me more out of it.

Kratom did help the pain, although, frankly, it isn't strong enough for that level of pain by itself.  Which explains why it is not dangerous, as the FDA may think it is.  I may return to using Kratom, along with other herbs or medications, in an effort to find relief safely and with fewer side-effects.  The medications that I do take, only at night, not only don't touch the pain much, but the side-effects are terrible, including gastroparesis, ie, paralysis of the GI system, which is intolerable.

In many decades of fighting these battles, I have found that natural remedies, like Kratom, are extremely important, even if not always sufficient by themselves.  I cannot tolerate the side-effects of the pain meds, or many meds for other symptoms, so the natural remedies can allow me to take less of the more difficult medications.

Kratom is not a dangerous herb in my experience, and to my knowledge.  It is a very helpful herb for many people.  As you surely know, there are many different strains, which help in different ways.  I've used several different strains, one for pain, one for energy, one for a little of each, and so on.  

There have been numerous safe natural remedies that have helped me enormously over the decades that the FDA have banned, leaving me, and millions of others, to suffer mercilessly.  Please, allow Kratom to remain legal, unscheduled, and able to be studied, and able to be used by people, like myself, who have no other good options, and are trying to live their lives as best as possible with the least side-effects.  

If the members of the FDA who are considering Kratom had to live with the kind of pain and suffering that myself, and millions of others do, perhaps they might understand our position.  Please consider that you, or someone you love, may be in a similar position at some point, and deserve to have the possibility of using an herb that causes no harm to help relieve their suffering, if they so choose.

Thank you very much for your consideration.

documents.commentText:
I come from a family that has more than it's share of pain problems.  My brother is in pain management due to severe back problems, my mother has had major back therapy, and my sister needs strong narcotics to help with her back.  Add on to that my wife also has severe back issues from her military time.  All of these people at some point have gotten addicted to pain medicines and most have gone down some fairly dark paths because of it.  Banning this substance will take these types of issues and multiply if by a million.  When people are in pain and overtake medicines either purposely or for relief they are put in a tight spot.  No one likes to be tortured but thats exactly what happens to everyone of these people!  Withdrawals is torture, not having pain meds for whatever reason is torture.  They can't win!  

This tree is a win for anyone who has tried it.  It takes the pain away just like pills, it cures withdrawal from pills and most importantly it allows many people to get on with their lives!   The very first time I saw my wife use this product she was crying in pain and in severe withdrawals due to the VA changing her doctor who thought it was a great idea to cut her medicine dosage in half because "someone her age shouldn't' need such a high dosage".  This decision was made without current X-rays, without any examination, nothing.   I found this tree by doing lots of research in ways to help that we could afford.  She was locked into care at the VA so seeing another doctor wasn't an option.  We did not want to buy pills off the street, we had finally gotten off that path almost a year ago, so at wits end we tried Kratom.   Within 30 minutes her crying had stopped, she was able to walk around the house without doubling over in pain!  She was able to tuck her kids in bed for the first time in a week!    The next day she returned to work, again, after being out for almost a week.  Now for us both kratom is a safe and effective product when pain fares up.  It's not a everyday pill.  She still has those, but I do not.  Yet I have no withdrawals from kratom like some say.  I do not get high like Percocet.  I live a normal life and take kratom the same way I took aleive or advil.  

Aside from all the above there are many small business that make a living by providing this product to other members including myself.  It has become a second job for me and a greatly needed income boost.  Yes I pay taxes on it just like my full time job.  From myself alone the following business would be affected:  USPS, $500-$800 weekly for shipping, DHL thousands a month, Food Lion/Sam's for packaging supplies, cleaning supplies, and storage containers.  My helpers would loose their part time jobs.  This product has a industry behind it, banning it would affect so many people in so many different ways.  

Please look at the big picture and not a few random news articles.  For every one person who has commented there will be a 100+ that do not.  

I support regulating this product to 18+ which I truly believe 99% of our vendors already do.

documents.commentText: I do not believe Kratom should made a schedule I substance, as this plant has not been shown to be substantially dangerous for human consumption. To the contrary, Kratom has been used by hundreds of thousands of people to ease withdrawals from opiates. Although no formal studies have yet to be done, thousands of anecdotal reports have reported that Kratom helped them to get off of prescription opiates, which are far more dangerous and deadly than Kratom. Our country already has an epidemic of opiate abuse and fatal overdose. Kratom can used to stem the tide of this epidemic, and in this writers view, the DEA should focus on the prescription opiate epidemic rather than jailing those who are likely attempting to rid themselves of prescription opiates. Banning Kratom would be contrary to the interests of the American people and would represent a substantial waste of public funds in jailing those who are trying to help themselves.

documents.commentText: I am the spouse of a recently-retired soldier. I have Systemic Lupus Erythematosus, Rheumatoid Arthritis, and other illnesses which accompany autoimmune diseases, and have been in pain management for just over 20 years as a result. Each time my husband received a Permanent Change of Station, I was forced to start over with a brand new set of physicians who neither knew me, nor trusted me, so I ended up, on average, going without my medications for 4-6 months after each move. I am not a drug addict - I have never taken an illegal drug, taken a prescription contrary to its instructions, nor ever even smoked a single cigarette in my 42 years, however, I have had a dependency on opiate pain medication due to the number of years I have been on them, so you can imagine how many times I have experienced withdrawal because of moving from state to state while my husband served his country. In 2014, we were stationed in Texas. My withdrawal symptoms were particularly lengthy that time because it was more difficult than usual to get a timely appointment with a primary care doctor in order to get a referral to a pain doctor, so I checked around for LEGAL ways to abate my symptoms. I stumbled upon Kratom, and it not only alleviated my withdrawal symptoms, it also helped get my excruciating pain under control. I took it until I was able to get my pain medicine, then stored away what I had not used. My husband retired this past June, and we moved back to Florida. My first primary care doctor here not only refused to refer me to a pain doctor, but refused to prescribe a single one of the medications I rely on to keep my Lupus and RA symptoms at bay. Suddenly stopping ANY of my medicines can cause a flare up and potentially put me in the hospital. I am now back on Kratom while I await an appointment with a new doctor who will prescribe my maintenance meds and refer me to the specialists I need. The fact of the matter is that Kratom is helping take care of people who cannot afford the expense of a doctor AND medication, do not want to take opiates, or find themselves in situations like mine. It is also a fact that acetaminophen hurts and kills more people each year than Kratom EVER HAS, yet it is still sold over the counter like candy. Meanwhile, marijuana becomes legal in state after state...a drug known to cause addiction and make people high. I never want to have to take marijuana and at this point, I am deciding if I ever want to go back on opiates for my pain. As long as Kratom is legal and my doctors approve, I may keep taking it along with my autoimmune disease meds, but if you make it a crime to have it, I will have to continue taking opiates, which I will become dependent on again and have to continue to increase the dosage to keep the pain at bay. I appreciate you taking the time to read about me and for your consideration of keeping Kratom legal. Please contact me should you have questions or need verification of my medical history.

documents.commentText:
Banning kratom expands the war on drugs, while the public overwhelmingly supports ending it. 

If kratom is added to any one of the five drug schedules, people who use it will be criminalized and locked up behind bars. 

Kratom has been used safely by millions of people in the U.S. and evidence supports kratom's potential as a pain reliever and opioid replacement. 

Many people struggling with opioid addiction have turned to kratom to help them cut back or quit, but now all promising scientific studies on kratom's role in opioid treatment could be immediately shut down. 

Side effects of kratom are minimal, and its withdrawal symptoms are weak and nearly inconsequential compared to the suffering of people trying to quit opioids. 

Prohibiting kratom will worsen the country's problems of opioid addiction and overdose.

documents.commentText:
My name is Kelly, I am a 41-year-old Marketing Manager and am married with two young children. I was diagnosed with mixed connective tissue disease (One of the more well-known diseases in this group, Lupus, is just one I suffer symptoms from).  For over the past 2 years I have been prescribed a few different pain medications, all of which had dramatic side effects that caused various issues on a daily basis. Tramadol made me feel as if I could fall asleep at a stoplight and had brain fog all day long. It made it very hard to remember tasks at work and I became very demotivated. Hydrocodone, was next and while it helped more with the pain,  it had numerous negative side effects and was extremely hard to get in my area at many  pharmacies with my prescription.  I had to visit my doctor every month to get my prescription and would not be able to fill it until the day it was to run out. Every month I was faced with pharmacies that were out of stock and would have to take the prescription to anywhere from 3 to 5 pharmacies to get my medication, otherwise I knew the next day would be hell. Through a great amount of research on natural pain alternatives (Tumeric, St. John's Wort, Cinnimon, and the list goes on) I finally discovered Kratom and everything changed. I was able to completely stop taking the Hydrocodone without withdrawal symptoms or other side affects. All of the sudden my brain fog has lifted, I was happier on a daily basis and it managed my pain far better than anything I had been prescribed. Additionally, to my doctor's surprise, my blood pressure consistently began to go down. My rheumatologist took me off of the pain medication and suggested I continue on the Kratom while he did some more research.  He stated he had heard great things about it from other patients and that it had been very helpful to several. 

I would be faced with a 3 week wait to see my doctor to discuss what options I have if Kratom is taken away. My husband, and my children can attest to the fact this miracle plant has made me a happier, more productive and even healthier person.  I am fearful of what may come of my life again if forced to go back on these miserable drugs or anything stronger. 

I  strongly urge you not to schedule this natural plant making it virtually impossible for expedient and helpful research to be done. Any move to schedule this plant will  negatively impact many Americans including myself.   I appreciate your time and consideration. 

Kindest Regards,

Kelly

documents.commentText: Scheduling kratom into Schedule I seems to make little sense. Given its minimal observable side effects, weak withdrawal effects, and ability to curb opioid addiction, kratom does not appear to be a danger to public health or be easily misused. As the citizens of the United States reveal more adamantly their opposition to mass incarceration, their distrust of the failed War On Drugs (which is largely a war on people of color and leftist speech, by the admission of a former Nixon cabinet member), and the very real problem of pharmaceutical opioid addiction, this proposed ban appears to be little more than a solution seeking a problem. The DEA could, and should, better utilize its resources by pursuing known public health hazards such as commercial opioids, and go after the companies that market them aggressively and improperly, than to vilify the users of a substance which is relatively harmless and actually helps counter an addiction epidemic.

It improved my mood and reduced my pain as effectively as most prescribed medications which, I can no longer tolerate. After taking the Kratom, I have also increased my level of activity.
Based on my personal experience and the testimonials I have read by other individuals, I would highly recommend this supplement to anyone who is interested in managing their pain and improving their quality-of-life. documents.commentText:
The DEA should stop any and all consideration of banning the herbal supplement kratom. There should be no prohibition. While the FDA is looking into it as well, most Americans have never heard of it. Why? Because there's NO REAL PROBLEM with it! Quite the contrary...

Kratom seems like a solution to a number of issues, including various forms of drug addiction and chronic pain. Plus, it can perform the pain-killing work of morphine without dangerously depressing breathing -- the way opioids do.

Here's how Kratom works...
It uses a pathway that mediates many of the undesirable effects of traditional opioids such as constipation, respiratory depression. In fact, this knowledge is spurring additional research by pharmaceutical companies.
http://bit.ly/2c8UTI6

About Kratom, a leading researcher notes...
Thailand is considering legalizing kratom as a safer alternative for meth addicts. U.S. researchers are trying to study its potential to help opiate abusers kick the habit without withdrawal side effects.
http://bit.ly/2c8SI7v
There are anecdotal reports of addiction risk. But it appears the addiction can be broken without withdrawal symptoms. Meanwhile, the painkillers currently being used are more addictive, dangerous, and harder to kick. Yet...

The FDA and DEA both appear ready to ban kratom and effectively kill research to further develop this substance. Is the DEA is running cover for a Big Pharma company that wants to monopolize kratom?

As I consider these actions by the FDA and DEA I'm forced to wonder -- WHAT ARE YOU PEOPLE SMOKING?

documents.title: Comment on FR Doc # 2016-24659

documents.commentText:
I am writing to oppose moving kratom (Mitragyna speciosa) to schedule I. To do so would be premature and risky. Placing substances under schedule I makes it very difficult to study them (as a researcher I am especially sensitive to this). No strong scientific evidence exists to support banning kratom at this time. While the health benefits are similarly understudied, the identifiable potential harm from banning it outweighs the unknown, unspecified benefit.

What we do know is that kratom overdoses are rare to nonexistent, but that many consumers of kratom find major health benefits. Perhaps the most critical and well-known is its use as an opiod-addiction treatment. Opiod addiction is one of the most pressing health concerns in the US, killing some 47,000 people a year. Millions of kratom users might relapse if kratom is banned, and go back to using heroin, oxycodone, etc. And if they don't die of an overdose, their lives will certainly suffer as a result. If it is put into schedule I, then the kratom market will be driven underground. The cost will rise, and people will find what was a cost-effective remedy to be an extremely expensive medication--more expensive than cheaper alternatives, like prevalent opiods. Not only that, they will inadvertantly become criminals. And criminal sanctions may continue to deteriorate their lives, by disrupting their family life, careers, and finances.

In addition to combating substance addiction, millions of kratom users have found it useful for combating psychological disorders. Its mood-lifting and calming properties make it a powerful anti-depressant and anti-anxiety medication. It is especially popular among people suffering from post-traumatic stress disorder. To deprive these suffering people of a useful medicine is cruel. Many of these people had tried other medications (e.g., SSRIs) to no avail, but kratom helped change their lives for the better. Its stimulant properties also help people suffering from chronic fatigue.

While the desire to prevent people becoming addicted to a potentially harmful drug is noble, it is ironic because many of the people who use kratom to manage chronic pain do so precisely because they do not want to become addicted to opiods. Many find that their tolerance does not grow as quickly, it is less addictive, and the side effects are much less severe than those arising from habitual opiod use.

While to date evidence about the pros and cons of kratom is largely anecdotal, the vast majority is positive. The desire to ban it, meanwhile, is based almost entirely on speculation. I suspect it is largely due to political motivations, rather than health ones. Politicians face incentives to scare concerned parents and claim credit for preventing health epidemics. In addition, the pharmaceutical industry--especially those in the business of making anti-depressants, anti-anxiety drugs, opiod-based pain killers, and opiod-addiction treatment drugs--faces incentives to ban the plant's sale. In this instance, the goals of lobbyists and politicians are at odds with promoting public health, and should not be allowed to determine the legality of the herb.

I am diagnosed with bipolar depression and generalized anxiety disorder. For a long time I self-medicated with marijuana. I broke that addiction only to fall into alcoholism. All the while I've tried a host of anti-depressants, mood stabilizers, and anti-anxiety drugs. While they have helped, I've found kratom to be the safest and most effective remedy. I have not experienced the multitudinous side effects I did from the other drugs, and I've had much more energy and inner peace since using kratom. I know other people who have had the same experience, including a family member of mine. I fear that I might personally relapse into marijuana or alcohol abuse, and potentially end up in a psychiatric ward and/or self-harm. Resultant major depressive episodes would likely harm my progress in my graduate degree program, and hurt my interpersonal relationships.

In sum, I beseech the Drug Enforcement Administration NOT to place Mitragynine and 7-Hydroxymitragynine into Schedule I, as it will 1) seriously curtail necessary research into the drug's potential harms and benefits; 2) potentially worsen the opiod epidemic in the country, leading to more deaths and societal costs; 3) prevent many people suffering from a host of diseases from the relief they deserve; 4) add strain to our already overburdened justice system and overcrowded jails; and 5) reduce work productivity, thus harming the fragile economic recovery. While regulations may be a good thing, at the moment an all-out ban would be detrimental to society. The human and economic costs could be devastating. While the DEA is calling this scheduling temporary, the fact is that schedules are quite sticky; once a substance is scheduled, its class is very rarely changed. Indeed, its having been scheduled as class I might be used as evidence to keep it there.

documents.commentText:
To whom it may concern,

My name is Carmine and I am writing to tell you my story about how kratom saved my life.

About 3 years ago I broke my back in the work accident. I had a hairline fracture in one of my vertebrates after spending some time in the hospital the doctor prescribed me Hydro-morphine and let me go home. While I was at home I was taking the pills as prescribed but yet the pain wasn't going away so I kept taking more pills to manage my pain, 3 months later I was taking 5 times more than prescribed to me and that's when I realized I have developed an addiction to pills. I tried stopping taking the pills but I quickly realized that I was unable to do so, my addiction was getting worse and worse. 3 more months later I was shooting heroin and full blown junkie. How did this happen? I went from being normal human being not even drinking alcohol to full blown junkie in 6 months and its all because a doctor prescribed me pills without any care. This addiction went on for 2 years during that time I lost my wife, my kids, my family, my friends, my job, and my home (I was living on the streets). I contemplated killing myself and just ending all of my pain and suffering. On October 30th 2015 I met an ex heroin addict and he told me about this "miracle" herb called kratom. At that point I had nothing to loose, we met the next day and he gave me kratom to try and boy did that change my life. After taking kratom I noticed that I didn't get the craving to heroin and that was the first day in 2 years where I didn't use any heroin or opiates. 1 day turned to 3 days, 3 days turned to 10 days and 10 days turned to 1 full year of being clean and sober. 

For the first 4 weeks I was using kratom once or sometimes twice a day to eliminate the craving to heroin, after 4 weeks I was taking kratom every other day, after 3 months I was taking kratom about once a week and now I take kratom about once or twice a month as a "maintenance" if I get a craving to heroin. I am a recovering addict and I will always have craving to heroin and if I don't have something to help me cope with my craving then I am scared to relapse and get back to my old life. I truly can say that kratom has saved my life!!!! I am working on getting my wife, kids and family back. If you do take kratom away from people you will have a lot good people relapse because as an ex addict I use kratom as a supplement to help me with my cravings, I don't use it everyday, I use it once or twice a month. You don't get euphoria, you cant get high from kratom nor do you get addicted to kratom. Tobacco and alcohol has killed millions of Americans yet its still legal.

Please I am begging you DO NOT TAKE THIS AWAY FROM US!!!!

Thank you for giving me a chance to speak and I trust that you will  make a right decision.

documents.commentText:
To Whom It May Concern;

My name is Zac, I am a 34 year old husband and father of two.  I work hard to provide for my family and give them a better life.  I am opposed to the ban on Kratom.

About 5 years ago my body started to reject certain foods.  I started to suffer from severe gastro-intestinal distress, including gas, diarrhea and bloating.  I discovered from my doctor and through blood testing that I was allergic to certain proteins and could no longer eat the foods which contained them.  Foods such as dairy, eggs, beef, chocolate, bananas, grains, tree nuts, etc.  This all happened very quickly and I had no other choice but to avoid those foods, but even so, many foods contain traces of the proteins found in those foods and I would have very bad bouts of gastro-intestinal distress.  I tried many different treatments, including: probiotics, enzymes, homeopathic remedies and other natural or prescription treatments.  Nothing worked.  My quality of life degraded severely.  Our food budget skyrocketed due to having to use alternative foods.  My wife spent much more time in the kitchen preparing foods that I was able to eat and ensuring that she did not cross-contaminate my food with her or the kids food.  I was unable to simply eat out with my family and friends or take clients out to lunch or dinner, because the foods I am allergic to are in the majority of all restaurant dishes.  If I happened to eat cross-contaminated food, or not pay attention close enough or realize there was a certain food in a meal, box, etc, I would later suffer the consequences.  I can remember the pain and distress clearly, curled up on the floor clutching my stomach, sitting on the toilet for long periods of time, holding in painful gas while in public or having to find a private place to relieve myself.  Thinking about those times now feels like a nightmare and to go back to that lifestyle terrifies me very much.

About three years ago, I began researching on the internet, and stumbled upon an online forum where people were discussing success with their colitis and other gastro-intestinal issues using Kratom.  Some said it suppressed much of their diarrhea and was able to, for the most part, live a fairly normal life.  So, I began to do more research about where to get it, how to and how much to use and began supplimenting with Kratom.  

From that moment on, I could eat anything I want with little to no consequences.  I spoke to my doctor to ask him if he thought that it was harmful due to it simply suppressing the issue, and possibly still causing inflammation.  In my case, he said that if it works to keep the symptoms at bay, then to keep doing what I was doing as there should be no long term adverse affects from eating foods I'm allergic to.

I also reap other benefits of Kratom.  I have chronic whiplash, something I have been dealing with for over 10 years.  I rarely have to take prescription pain medication, ibuprofen, acetaminophen or other pain medications to curb my neck and back pain.  Unknown to me at the time, that Kratom helped with pain control.  Now I rarely go to the chiropractor, whereas in the past, I would see one 3 or more times a month.

I do not become impaired, physically or mentally, while using Kratom.  I take a consistent amount, just enough to tide my allergies.

The thought of the government banning Kratom terrifies me.  To go back to living the way I was before I discovered Kratom will completely degrade my quality of life again.  I believe the government should keep Kratom legal so that we may explore and test the benefits and detriments of Kratom use.  The illegalization of Kratom seems like a rash approach to dealing with a botanical suppliment that has many positive benefits with very little evidence of its harm.

I hope the DEA will consider all that has been said and choose to keep Kratom legal.

documents.commentText:
Re: DEA-442W

I am a kratom consumer. I have taken 2 teaspoons of kratom leaf powder with my vitamin regimen, every day, for 3 years. I am a productive member of society I am not a stoner or a hippie, as the DEA would like to believe.
I take kratom because it seems to help relieve the cluster migraines I use to experience after being involved in a rear-end collision 3 years ago. I received head trauma from the accident and my GP (General Physician) wanted to put me on Oxycontin as a 'solution' to my cluster migraines. 
This was never going to happen for me. I refuse to believe that pain medication does anything more than create addiction if used for long-term care. So I went back home and did my own research to find a 'solution'. I learned of kratom through a knowledgeable online community (the community was actually established for people with Lyme Disease). After taking my first teaspoon of kratom leaf powder I received relief of my migraines within an hour. I am not claiming that kratom (Mitragyna speciosa) cures, prevents or treats ANY disease or illness, but I do know that helped me feel a bit better. And because of this I have continued to use kratom daily. I have quit using kratom several times over the past 3 years, generally because I ran out of the leaf powder or forgot to re-order on time. But my point is that I have never had 'withdrawal' symptoms from NOT taking the kratom powder, even as a regular kratom consumer. I have heard the media & the DEA/FDA try to claim that Kratom is "highly addictive and has no medicinal value'. I have never heard of something so misrepresented in my life. I am here to say that kratom does help with mild pain relief, just like an NSAID pain reliever. It has never given me any type of 'euphoria' or 'high'. Kratom powder does help me to live comfortably and normally without the fear of being an addict for the rest of my life, or worrying about falling asleep and not waking up due to Oxycontin. 
I am thankful that the DEA/FDA has offered us a comment period. It is just. But I would like to see the DEA/FDA make Kratom LEGAL in our country. Other places such as Europe and Canada have made kratom legal to help its population flourish without opiates. We as Americans do have the right to choose our healthcare. If we choose natural solutions over prescriptions, then this is our God-given right as Americans. The opiate epidemic is overwhelming our country and to even attempt to make a plant, this beneficial, illegal is an outrage. 
Kratom, in its original plant-form, can help millions everyday- and to take this plant away would be a travesty.Even to take this plant away in order to make a prescribable medication would be an even greater travesty. God gave us this plant. And to take it away from millions of people just to alter it into a drug so that Americans without health insurance (like myself) won't have access to it, well, this would alter the course of the American opiate epidemic. A downhill spiral of thousands of Americans dying from opiate overdoses for No Reason At All.  
Please see all the good that Kratom does. I am sorry if 15 people died with kratom in their bloodstream over the past 5 years. I feel for their families. But what about the thousands of Americans that overdose weekly from opiates prescribed by Doctors? What about the thousands that die yearly from Asprin overdose? The list goes on and on. There is no real reason to make kratom illegal. The facts are readily available. I am writing purely out of opinion. I know that you will receive the 8-Point analysis and all of the other info provided by the AKA, BEA & DPA. I am just here to say that losing kratom would be a devastating awakening regarding the current opiate epidemic.

documents.commentText:
My name is Jean Fecteau, age 24. I hold an MS in biomedical engineering, and I am currently employed as a technician for microscopy systems designed for neuroscience research. I oppose the DEA's proposal to put kratom, the plant from which it is derived, or either of the two alkaloids mitragynine or 7-hydroxymitragynine (the active compounds in kratom) on the list of schedule I controlled substances.

I used kratom daily for about 6 months during my time in graduate school, and I have not resumed use at any point after my graduation 6 months ago. During my two years of graduate school, I fell into a deep depression that manifested in extreme lethargy, panic attacks, and suicidal thoughts. I sought treatment through antidepressants and therapy prescribed by my psychiatrist, but was still struggling to overcome many of the worst symptoms. I began to use marijuana against my better judgment to cope with my problems. This use began to interfere with my research and school work, almost to the same level that my depression had interfered before I began using marijuana. I sought treatment in herbal supplements to help me regain functionality, and I encountered kratom. The mental, emotional, and physical boost it gave me allowed me to stop using marijuana and get back to my work. By consuming a small amount of kratom every morning with my tea, I was able to pick up the pace on my thesis and complete on time, and I no longer felt consumed by my depression. Once I graduated and left Rochester, all of the stress of graduate school lifted from me, and I no longer needed to use kratom. I was able to stop by choice. I have been free of marijuana and have not used kratom for 6 months, and I feel I am living a happy life.

I have heard far too many success stories similar to mine to count. I implore you to allow this herbal supplement to continue to be accessible, not for the sake of myself, but for the sake of others who could benefit. Putting kratom on the list of schedule I controlled substances would not affect me in any way because I no longer use it, but I am concerned for the millions of others who are currently or will in the future see the same benefits that I have. Please do not deny those who are ill an avenue of treatment. Our list of options for treating depression and addiction is tragically short as it is.

documents.commentText:
To Whom It May Concern:

I believe there needs to be further research to verify the safety of this drug. From the majority of the testimonials I've heard, and the cursory research I've conducted, it seems that Kratom offers a wide range of benefits to a variety of populations, especially those dealing with withdraw symptoms from addiction to opiates. 

At the minimum, it's potential for abuse and adverse effects must be identified and clearly communicated before being banned for apparently no fundamental reason other than "we don't know what it is fully, so it ought  to be unavailable." Not sure if that logic makes total sense. Unless, of course, the DEA is being swayed by groups that have something to gain for Kratom being kept illegal, eg Opiate producers.

documents.commentText:
Please do not ban Kratom!

Banning kratom expands the war on drugs, while the public overwhelmingly supports ending it.
If kratom is added to any one of the five drug schedules, people who use it will be criminalized and locked up behind bars.
Kratom has been used safely by millions of people in the U.S. and evidence supports kratom's potential as a pain reliever and opioid replacement.
Many people struggling with opioid addiction have turned to kratom to help them cut back or quit, but now all promising scientific studies on kratom's role in opioid treatment could be immediately shut down.
Side effects of kratom are minimal, and its withdrawal symptoms are weak and nearly inconsequential compared to the suffering of people trying to quit opioids.
Prohibiting kratom will worsen the country's problems of opioid addiction and overdose.

documents.commentText: I'm a 47 year old old wife, mom and grandmother. I was diagnosed with RSD after an on the job injury in 2003. While I was on insurance they threw all sorts of treatments my way that were ineffective and dangerous. After spending 5 years trying to manage my pain condition and finding no relief I found myself with no insurance and unable to afford treatment. So my search for something natural to treat my condition began in earnest. Cannabis provided me some relief but nothing touched the unrelenting nerve pain and my depression grew to the point of being suicidal. A friend told me about kratom so I researched it for about 6 months before trying it. That was 3 years ago now. 30 minutes after trying kratom my nerve pain receded for the first time since my injury. Where before there was only hopelessness and despair now I saw light. I wasn't expecting that my life would improve so dramatically. Before kratom I spent a lot of time curled up in a ball wishing for death. With kratom, not only does it help with my pain, but the muscle spams, insomnia,depression, anxiety, fatigue and improved overall health. I'm still unable to work due to my health but I can now garden and help provide for my family by growing some of our food. I'm able to care for our home better. I can be a bigger part in my kids and grand kids lives. With kratom I found hope and a better quality of life. And I feel safe that I don't have medicines around that could harm my family. I have personally seen it help others regain their life by beating addictions, controlling pain from chronic diseases, mood support for depression, anxiety and PTSD. With kratom there is hope for a future not without pain, RSD is incurable, but a future of my symptoms of this nasty disease being manageable. And the thought of losing that light and hope that kratom provides me is terrifying. The thought that a plant that helped and continues to help so many people could be taken away when there is substantial evidence in favor of its safety and effectiveness in treatment of so many conditions it would be an injustice and infringement on our rights to use plant medicine as we have since the dawn of man. To be able to be a part of my families lives and to support my husband in starting to build a new business. 6 1/2 years ago we were homeless and hopeless. Kratom helped save me and my family and restored my hope about living with this condition. Kratom is ONLY thing that helps my nerve pain. Kratom and cannabis are the plant medicines that works best for me without harming my family or myself. Don't take that away from us. My doctors are aware that I take kratom and cannabis and are totally supportive of it. My doctor said the difference it has made for me is amazing and to keep doing what I'm doing. I don't have to have blood work done every 3 months anymore to monitor my kidneys and liver and cortisol levels. My blood work looks healthy.  And if I run out my symptoms return but I don't experience ANY withdrawal. If you take too much you puke so you can't OD on it. And with the number of OD deaths at an all time high the pulling of kratom from the market will cause that number to rise as it helps fight addiction. The research is there for you to read. Kratom is safe and effective and shouldn't be made a Schedule 1 substance. It's medicinal value is clear to see if you take the time to research for yourself. I did mine and my only regret about kratom is not trying it sooner! It made a life-changing difference in my quality of life and I don't want to lose that. I will never go back to pharmaceuticals. I am a patient not a criminal. The vendors I use for kratom are safe and provide good quality kratom at an affordable price. If kratom is banned who knows what you would get on the black market. This ban will block a invaluable plant medicine from improving countless lives. And make criminals out of ordinary law-abiding citizens just trying to mange their health naturally. documents.commentText:
While I've never used Kratom, as a cannabis user, I believe that people have an inalienable right to do what they want to their bodies as long as it doesn't harm others.  Indeed, we don't even know that this herb does any damage to the person imbibing it.  And don't we have a fundamental philosophy in our country of innocence until proven guilty.  I believe that this concept should be applied to other things besides people.

Conversely. we have legal drugs in our country that are undeniably detrimental to our health.  Both cigarettes and sugar are highly addictive and slowly kill us, yet these substances are completely legal.  Why aren't they schedule 1?  Everyone knows that you can overdose on alcohol, ALCOHOL POISONING KILLS 6 PEOPLE EVERY DAY! (www.cnn.com/2015/01/07/health/alcohol-poisoning-deaths/index.html).  How many people even supposedly died from Kratom?  An allegation that hasn't even been proven.

I've heard that this herb can be helpful for people trying to get off an Opioid addiction.  In the state the country is in, we cannot afford to outlaw any herb that may help people with this issue.  As someone who is currently addicted to prescribed Remeron, who has been trying since the beginning of summer to wean myself off it and still haven't managed to go completely off of it.  Remeron, I was using cannabis before as medication for my depression but got tired of being scared of doing something illegal so I decided to switch to a legal, prescribed drug.  It was one of the worst decisions of my life.  The doctor, my acting GP, wanted me to see him every month to get my refill.  If I didn't go in I would be basically immobile, huddled in the fetal position suffering from withdrawal, forcing me to go see him for more.  When did doctors start feeling like drug dealers/pushers?  When did herbal remedies which can be grown at home in a garden become illegal while prescription drugs with their paragraphs of side-effects and proven addictiveness are not only legal, but advertised and pushed upon the population.  

I have great sympathy for anyone with an addiction, an I can only imagine an Opioid addiction is even worse than what I am going through.

Finally, Governmental offices are offices of public service.  But somewhere along the line the government became something more akin to parents.  Telling us what we can an cannot do.  This basically reverses the roles and makes us servants or children.  It is taking away our freedoms for some false sense of security.  Decades of literal brainwashing people with complete lies about marijuana has made them so scared of anything not prescribed has made it easy to convince people to give up freedoms in exchange for "safety".  This is a thing that our one of our forefathers WARNED US NOT TO DO.

Thank you for your time.  I just want to finish by contemplating what a crazy society we live in where alcohol kills 6 people per day but no one even flinches.  Kratom, we don't even know if it's actually the cause of anyone's death yet everyone is so quick to make it illegal.

documents.commentText:
I have been using Kratom for occasional pain relief (and energy) since I donated a kidney to my little sister in 2009. Following the surgery, I was prescribed Oxycontin for the pain. After I had recovered from the initial trauma of the surgery, I stopped taking the Oxycontin both because it made me too groggy, and because I was concerned about its well known addictive potential. I still had a fair amount of pain, especially around the abdominal scars and I just tried to live with it, but the pain took a toll on my energy levels and appetite. 
I tried medical marijuana for relief, and while it helped with my appetite, it didn't relieve much of the pain, and it left me uncomfortably spaced out.
A friend happened to have a farm on which he grew a few types of Mitragyna speciosa. He sent me a packet of leaves suggesting it might offer some relief. It was perfect. It gave me energy instead of making me groggy. It soothed the pain and allowed my appetite to return. 
I used it every day for several months, but as I healed, the pain diminished and I stopped using Kratom. The only discomfort I felt upon discontinuation was a deep fatigue that lasted about two days after I stopped, and I never felt an overwhelming need to continue using it.
Since that time, I have always kept some around. Occasionally the pain flares up (usually when it's cold and damp out) and I use it for a short period of time. I also use it from time to time for long lasting calm energy, on days when I am feeling tired or unambitious. 
In my roughly 7 years of experience, I have not found its addictive or abuse potential to be any greater than that of coffee or tea, and if anything it should be regulated as a food product approved for human consumption, just like our favorite energizing beverages. 
Thank you for taking the time to listen to people who would be adversely affected by Kratom's prohibition.

documents.commentText:
Hello,
 My name is John Henderson. I am a Senior utility operator for the city of Phoenix water department, and I have  been a loyal city servant now for over 21 years. In 2008 I began to develop severe pain in my lower extremities. within a year the pain became so bad that it was almost intolerable. I was diagnosed with "compartmental nerve compression" caused by Charcot Marie Tooth disease". About that time my hips started going bad. I was diagnosed with "FAI" in both hips. Basically the cartilage inside both my hips is shredded due to genetic issues. I will need two new hips in the not to distant future.
  After 7 surgeries, and almost daily physical therapy, I am getting around pretty well, but my daily life is, and will be, spent in physical pain. When I get home from work each day my body is extremely stiff and sore. I liken it to an engine loosing it's oil. For years now I have been taking prescription pain relievers some evenings after work, just to be able perform normal  activities around home. I hate that I have needed to take them, but it's quite often necessary. 
 About 2 years ago a friend at work recommended that I give "Kratom" a try. I was skeptical because up to that point, nothing worked for my pain and discomfort except for the hard core pain meds. To my surprise, Kratom worked. In fact it has worked so well that I now take very few of the hard core pain meds. A nominal dose of Kratom not only relieves my pain and nerve issues, but it does so without any of the side effects I was getting from taking Vicodin almost every day. And Kratom is natural, not synthetic!
 Kratom has been nothing short of a miracle to me. My nerve issues in my lower legs can be so bad that at times my feet feel as though they are heavy bricks that I drag around with me as I walk. Kratom does an amazing job of relieving, or temporarily eliminating these symptoms. Kratom also controls the severe pain caused by my hip arthritis.
   Please keep this herb available to the public. Please keep it available for research as I believe it's potential is immense... I am a loyal public servant, Father, brother and friend. I hold an important position with the City of Phoenix Arizona Government. In my 22 years of service I have called into work sick only 5 times... My point is that I am an extremely responsible member of society. I take my health very seriously, and I believe strongly that Kratom should remain available to the public..

Thanks so much for your time,
John Henderson

documents.commentText:
I have suffered from fibromyalgia for 7 years, not long after my brother passed away in a car accident. I was put on anti-depressants, and we went through 8-9 specific drugs to find the right one for me. I wasn't seeing any relief, and after some visits with my primary physician I was referred to the pain center in my area. They did MRIs, X-rays, blood work; you name it. 

They couldn't give any reason I was suffering and diagnosed me with fibromyalgia. If you're not familiar with fibromyalgia, it is pain in the nerves and muscles throughout the entire body. It affects your daily life, your mental and emotional state, and your sleep patterns. There were nights I couldn't sleep more than 2 hours because of pain and restless legs. 

The doctor put me on Tramadol, Cymbalta, Lyrica, Pregabalin, Vicodin, Percocet, Diclofenax, Ambien, Cyclobenzaprine, and Celebrex. Not all of those were at the same time, but we had to rotate through quite a bit of them before we found a good balance. After about a year I couldn't afford to continue going to the pain center. My primary physician kept me on the Tramadol, but that was only enough to keep me from lying in the bed in pain all day.  It masked the pain so I could at least get my kids off to school and do a load of laundry.

A friend of mine mentioned this plant called "kratom". I thought "There's no way this is going to work." So I bought the cheapest option they had and gave it a shot. It was like night and day. After continual use, about three months in, I was able to get off EVERYTHING and just use the kratom. It helped with my anxiety, depression, AND pain. I was able to do so much more than my normal "one load of laundry". I was able to clean my house like I wanted to. I was able to do ALL the laundry. I was able to make meals for my family and spend time at the park with the kids. My kids were so appreciative of my newfound energy and pain relief.

When the risk was arising for scheduling the plant I tried to stop taking it to see what kind of effect it would have on my pain and anxiety levels. After three days without taking kratom, my fibromyalgia flared up worse than it has in years. I was stuck in bed with heating pads for my back, ice packs for my costochondritis, and Percocet and Tramadol for the muscle pain and spasms. If this miracle plant is blacklisted, I will have to start at square one again. Kratom has given me so much relief and ability to handle my daily responsibilities as I run my own business, and I'm married with four children under the age of 13. 

This plant has changed my capabilities for the better over the last couple of years and if it is placed as a schedule I, I will have to revert to toxic medications that could eventually destroy my liver, or kidneys. Please keep this plant legal. There are more people out there like me that rely on this amazing plant to function through their lives in their day to day.

Thank you for your consideration in this matter.

documents.commentText:
Kratom should absolutely not be scheduled as a dangerous drug. Kratom is not strongly psychoactive, and primarily used by opiate addicts as a safe alternative to methadone. There are zero recorded incidents of anybody dying due to consumption of Kratom, and methadone overdoses are responsible for around 5000 deaths every year in the United States alone. It would be a transparent act of pure pandering to corporate interests if the DEA decided to schedule one of the safest substances used to combat opiate addictions. It is paramount to the public interest that this substance does not become illegal, as it is very likely that addicts using Kratom to help themselves with withdrawal will turn to more dangerous alternatives, or even go back to using the opiate that they are addicted to. The likely result if this decision was made would be a noticeable increase in the number of opiate related deaths. If the goal of the DEA is to reduce the harm caused by narcotics and addictive drugs, scheduling Kratom is not the way to achieve it.

Thank you for your consideration of this issue, I hope that the decision that is best for the public will be made.

documents.commentText:
Banning kratom would be an enormous mistake and detrimental to so many United States citizens.  Banning kratom expands the war on drugs, while the public overwhelmingly supports ending it.  If kratom is added to any one of the five drug schedules, people who use it will be criminalized and locked up behind bars; contributing even more innocent individuals to the overcrowding of American prisons.  Kratom has been used safely by millions of people in the U.S. and evidence supports kratom's potential as a pain reliever and opioid replacement.  Many people struggling with opioid addiction have turned to kratom to help them cut back or quit, but now all promising scientific studies on kratom's role in opioid treatment could be immediately shut down.  Side effects of kratom are minimal, and its withdrawal symptoms are weak and nearly inconsequential compared to the suffering of people trying to quit opioids.  There are many harmful side effects of many other already legal substances, like alcohol, for instance and yet these remain legal because criminalization is simply impossible to enforce, and we shouldn't try.  I for one would rather see my tax dollars and my countries resources going towards sex trafficking and slave rings as well as ending hate crimes and legalized discrimination such as this insufferable War on Drugs.   In summation, Prohibiting kratom will worsen the country's problems of opioid addiction and overdose.  Based on all of this information, in what ways are you attempting to rationalize that banning kratom would enrich or aid our country as a whole?

Thank you very much for your time and consideration.

documents.commentText:
Hello, my name is Mary and I'm a twenty five year old bartender. A bartender who doesn't drink as ironic as that is. I'm actually, surprisingly, against letting any foreign substance into my body. We know alcohol, tobacco, fatty foods, etc are bad so I stay away from them. I'm one of those "all natural types" not a hippy or anything  like that. I just prefer to consume food, supplements, juice, etc in their natural form. I'm also a lover of tea and coffee. I have an impressive variety of tea in my cupboard, call me a collector . Some people have twenty kinds of liquor...I have twenty  kinds of tea. Along with chamomile, ginger, lemon, blueberry and mint I have kratom tea. To me, drinking a cup of kratom tea is very similar to drinking a cup of coffee, so I was baffled when I found out that the DEA was putting their efforts towards banning it. We have a heroine and prescription drug problem like the world has never seen and the DEA, who is supposed to be helping us, is focusing their time and our tax dollars on banning a tea. What is going on and why? 
 Being a bartender, I here alot of vented frustration. And there are a few things that come up day after day. The people, and this is an obvious one, do not trust our current government. This should be no surprise to you given the presidential election that just passed. They spew alligations of corruption and of our goverment being unloyal to the people. 
 For the longest time I had your back. I thought that the people's best interest was always in mind. But now I wonder, at least when it comes to the kratom dicussion, is that the case? Why is the goverment trying to ban a plant that has helped so many Americans ? Why are they so worried about the supposed handful of deaths that occured at the hands of kratom? It's a painfully small number compaired to prescription drugs, ciggarettes, diabetes,  and for the love of god, alcohol. It is to small to make sence.  Please leave kratom alone and focus your efforts on the real problems. The people have made it clear to you that we do not support you in the banning of kratom and now, as an institution governed by the people, you must listen. Thabk you for your time, please renew my faith in you.

documents.commentText:
docket No. DEA-442W

My name is Seth Brunson. I am a 28 year old male. I live with a chronic illness called hemochromatosis, which is a genetic disorder that causes my body to absorb too much iron. It can cause fatal liver disease, lung disease, and heart disease if left untreated. Even with treatment, however, I still suffer from crippling arthritis and fatigue when my iron gets too high. I take several medications, and I also take about 2 grams of kratom twice daily to help with the pain. Kratom has become an important part of my daily health regimen, which also includes coffee to help wake me up in the morning and combat my fatigue, and eggs, which reduce iron absorption. Like coffee and eggs, kratom has an impact on my overall wellbeing, but I don't treat it like a drug. 

I have been taking kratom daily for the past 6 months. In that time, I have not needed to increase my dosage to get the same effect. I have been taking the same dose since day one. I have taken more than 2 grams on two occasions intentionally to try increasing the pain relief, but only found that it made me tired

I have taken prescription opioids before (by prescription), and the effects of kratom are not equivalent to those in my experience. The effects are far milder, there is no sense of euphoria, and the pain relief kratom provides is less (although still stronger than most otc medicines I have tried).

Kratom does not treat my condition. It merely provides some pain relief for my arthritis. Without kratom, working would be difficult.

I do not believe kratom is dangerous, and it has not proven to be addictive in my case. I do not "crave" kratom. I have never feared having an overdose, nor becoming addicted. My only concern is that tainted kratom may be available on the market, and I make certain to purchase my kratom from reliable sources.

I would like to see sensible regulations that police kratom vendors and weed out unethical and unwanted adulteration of kratom products, similar to what is done with other herbal supplements. If kratom is approved as an herbal supplement then these regulations will be possible. Shady vendors that market kratom as a"legal high" feel the need to dope the herb to make it recreational and "fun". Kratom, by itself, is not strong enough to produce the high that recreational users seek. By regulating the herb, we can not only ensure that the US supply of kratom is safe for consumption, but we can stop peddlers from trying to sell tainted drugs to addicts and children on the premise that it's safe and natural, when really it's doped with designer drugs.

Scheduling kratom is a horrible idea. It is completely unnecessary, and will create the very sort of illegal smuggling market that the DEA intends to fight. This market will not be fueled by drug addicts seeking a fix, but by the chronically ill like myself who have found kratom to be a tremendously beneficial part of their daily health regimen. Banning kratom is a fool's errand. If it were actually dangerous then I could see the point, but why go through the trouble of dealing with all the negative consequences and enforcement costs of policing yet another illegal substance? Is kratom really worth that trouble? The overwhelming majority of citizens believe this ban is a huge waste of time and resources, and I among them.

Although I do not use kratom to help with opioid addiction, it is worth noting that this is another principle use of the herb. I have heard many stories of addicts using kratom to fight their addictions, and with frequent success. I don't have personal experience with this, but it is another strong reason why banning kratom would hurt rather than help the DEA's goal of stopping drug abuse. I cannot fathom why the DEA has come to the conclusion, on any reasonable grounds, that this herb should be placed in schedule I.

I disagree with the proposed ban on kratom and I will actively fight to stop it.

Sincerely,
Seth B.

documents.commentText: I discovered kratom as a freshman in college. As a chemist, I was wary of any problems that may occur during the use of kratom and it's effects on the body. I dived deep into toxicological reports and user reports on kratom to try to figure out the pros and cons of the plant material. My opinion thus far, even upon reading those reports where kratom toxicity was determined to be the leading cause of a death, is that kratom is fairly safe. The reports I have seen have mitragynine plasma concentrations that would only be achievable from ingesting kilograms of kratom leaf powder, given mitragynine's low bioavailabilty and low concentration in leaf powder. I have seen far more positive reviews, from mood lifting abilities and higher work output, to it's pain killing properties that have given many people a less addictive alternative to dangerous opiod painkillers prescribed in this country. I believe that scheduling kratom would not only be a mistake on the DEA's part, but would end up posing a great threat to public health as they deprive a free people of their choice in a more natural alternative to antinociceptive subatances.
