documents.commentText:
My name is Natalie Pickup. I am 24 years old, female, and I am a server at a family owned restraunt in Arvada, Colorado. I know my job does not show it, but I have actually come a long way from where I was  a year go. All my life I have struggled with anxiety and depression. Whether it was passed down to me through my father or I acquired it from years of peer bullying is unknown to me. I have seen many psychiatrists and counselors throughout my young life. I was put on many antidepressants,  all of which had horrible side effects and made me feel like a walking zombie. A couple years ago I decided that since these medications were not helping and the counseling proved uneffective, I was going to self medicate. I bet you can guess what I chose as my poison. Like many, I chose alcohol. It was convenient,  always available,  and even being under 21 at the time I could access it easily. My life spiraled out of control from the moment I picked up the bottle. Long story short, I lost my friends, my job, compromised the relationship between me and my family, I basically lost my young life. Not to mention my health declined   quickly and it showed through my pale and bloated alcoholic skin. 
I tried getting counseling, I tried the medications again, but nothing could keep me and my liquid lover apart. The anxiety and depression always came back and it was unbearable without alcohol. As I was reading an online blog about addicts and anxiety sufferers, I came across the mention of kratom. I read positive things about it and desperate to get relief from the agony of depression and the shame of alcoholism, I decided to give it a try. I do not abuse kratom like I abused alcohol, simply put, I can't. It would be impossible to abuse kratom in the way so many abuse illicit drugs simply for the reason that kratom is not well tolerated in high doses and you often just get a bad case of nausea if you go overboard. If you use it too regularly it has no effect at all which deters users from abusing it as well. Kratom has helped me in so many ways. It has releived my anxiety, helped with my energy levels from anemia caused by my drinking habits, and best of all it saved me from losing my life to alcohol. When I heard the DEA was planning on making it a schedule  1 drug I was stunned. This herb that barely alters one's state of mind is being deemed deadly and toxic yet alcohol and other prescription drugs are allowed to keep working their evil and wrecking the lives of those whose suffering probably is not well understood by the gentleman in his lab coat researching causes of addiction. I have always trusted the DEA and their decisions, but this movement to ban an herb that, by itself,  has shown may times to be quite harmless makes me doubt where the DEA's true interests really lie. With all do respect I do not mean to be accusatory but this ban has me scratching my head wondering what else that has been deemed " bad " is really actually quite harmless, and the opposite of that which is legal. Many citizens I speak to feel the same. Thank you for taking the opportunity to read and consider my thoughts on the subject. At least I can say I did my part.

documents.commentText: Based on my experience with this substance, it does not merit placement on the Schedule 1 list. Every 6-12+ months I purchase 1-2 oz of Kratom powder (various strains) online and consume it over the course of a couple weeks. I mix roughly a teaspoon or two of powder with 8-16 ozs of water and drink it. Chosen quantity depends on degree of effect I desire, although even when I have inadvertently taken a more liberal dose (an additional teaspoon or two), the effects have never been significantly impairing and I go about my day. I never felt the need to increase dosage due to tolerance,. I also never had difficulty stopping use beyond mild and brief cravings. I used it recreationally as a "treat" and mild relaxant during times I felt high-strung. However, I emphatically never felt dependent or compulsive about use and in fact usually felt satisfied by my use and content to enjoy it in this way. I was first introduced to Kratom circa 2012 by retail coworkers who recommended it recreationally and as a way to take the edge off a stressful day at work while getting a stimulant boost in order to have energy while working. During busy season, virtually all 8 or so sales employees used it throughout the day, often gratefully sharing with each other, and were able to function normally and never had issues with impairment or adverse effects in any way (including detection by customers or management who might have disapproved). To my knowledge, none of these individuals ever developed an addiction to the substance, nor have anyone else to whom I have introduced and with whom I have shared Kratom. A couple of the persons that first shared it with me I knew to illegally use prescription opoids and admitted to previous addiction problems with them; these individuals cited Kratom as an effective method of decreasing opoid dependence and to my knowledge successfully did so. Others did not have histories of substance abuse, and had no observable issues with Kratom,as well. I am addicted to nicotine and often depend on caffeine, but do not use other drugs and very infrequently drink alcohol (4 or less standard drinks per month). However, I have had an alcohol use issues in the past (ranging from mild to severe between 2006 and 2011) and have experimented with several other illegal substances without becoming dependent (none were IV drugs, frequency of use was fewer than 5 instances in my life for any one substance, except for marijuana which I smoked more frequently at times over the years). I never consumed Kratom simultaneously with other substances except occasional alcohol or possibly caffeine. My subjective experience of the effects of Kratom included an expanded sense of contentment, mild stimulation similar to caffeinated drinks (plus some physiological stimulation including: slightly increased perspiration, flushed skin, & sexual arousal). I mostly felt like I was in a relaxed "groove" while performing whatever tasks at hand or simply reclining & engaging in passive entertainment. I will also note that I perceived some inhibition of my ability to calculate or engage in complicated planning tasks while under the influence of Kratom (e.g. counting money, balancing a cash register, conversing about everyday logistical concerns over the phone while driving). In my chosen mode of delivery, the strong taste of plant material also discouraged overconsumption (sometimes I lost interest in even finishing the full dose I had prepared). I noted that some individuals who I saw try Kratom experienced nausea & abdominal discomfort that discouraged them f/ using it. I never had these effects, although I did once vomit a large amount of recently ingested mixture (large amounts of water w/ an amount of Kratom on the higher side of what I previously described as my normal intake) after a prolonged (2+ hours), strenuous hike (but was not nauseous & felt fine immediately afterwards). I wanted to describe this experience as accurately as possible to provide context for why it is inconceivable to me that this substance would appropriately belong in a class w/ drugs like heroin and cocaine. It is as benign as caffeine, in my opinion, &probably less problematic than alcohol/marijuana. So, in favor of my own sporadic, occasional enjoyment and empathy for opioid addicts who may find this to be a suitable path toward harm reduction & away f/ addiction. For further credibility re: my judgment, note that I have worked for 4 years in mental health & directly work w/ a lot of people w/ substance use disorders of all shapes & sizes; I am also currently a Master's-level student in the 2nd year of a Clinical Psych program & have interned for a year with a neuropsychologist in a hospital & medical rehab setting. Further and finally, I hope by openly disclosing less-than-perfect aspects of my related background, it conveys the strength of my conviction that Kratom is not inherently harmful and may even be useful as a legal alternative to other opioids.

documents.commentText: I have used Kratom for over a decade, with no side effects. Before I discovered Kratom I was in constant pain. It is a tool to help people deal with overwhelming pain both physical and emotional when western medicine does not work. Since finding Kratom. I graduated college and enrolled in an M.B.A. program. I have a 4.0 post finding Kratom. I had to drop out before it. I bought a house. I got married to my lovely wife. I have one boy, a three year old who I take great care of and provide everything he needs. My wife is pregnant with our second child. I have a great job that allows me to afford to support children and own a house. All of these things seemed as if they were just a pipe dream before Kratom. Now they are a reality I am afraid to lose. I am sure this website is full of 10,000 plus stories of people who are in less pain, emotional and physical. I am sure there are stories of people who kicked opiates with the help of Kratom. I will not go on and on. One last thing I will mention is please understand the consequences even if the D.E.A.'s intentions are pure. Opiates are either illegal or controlled depending on what form the come in. More and more people are dying of over doses now than ever. It is not from the drugs they are hooked on. It is from Fentanyl laced products. People who are in pain will always find away to reduce it. documents.commentText:
In reference to Docket No. DEA-442W
My name is Theresa W. I am a 56 year old female with a bachelor degree in business who works as an application analyst. Please do not make kratom illegal or take it off the market for responsible adults. I suffer minor aches and pains from osteoarthritis and the effects of getting older. I have been taking NSAIDS daily since 2009, of which known long term effects include kidney, stomach, and heart damage; to address these aches until I tried kratom about a year ago. I found that Kratom tea relieves my pain so that I can be more active and sleep better. In addition, it helps me feel more motivated and in a better mood. I drink it a few times a week after I do yard work or exercise, for example.
There is ample experience sharing and information available on the Internet to set proper expectations for benefits and minor adverse effects if too much is consumed by accident. Consequently, I have never experienced a bad effect from it. According to reports, adverse effects are minor and resolve in a few hours. On a positive note, the minor side effects of over consumption serve the purpose of discouraging attempts to abuse it. I feel more confident that I am not damaging my heart and kidneys from using it, than I was when I took ibuprofen. Since I have been drinking kratom tea a few times a week, I have not had any colds or allergy flare-ups either. I see my doctor regularly, and my labs are consistently in the normal ranges.
I encourage kratom to be studied in regards to its nutritional analysis, as I suspect it to be as beneficial as other green vegetables such as kale or spirulina. In addition to its nutritional benefits, it appears to have minor energizing and pain relieving effects similarly to coffee. A study to investigate its safe use would provide the scientific justification of what tens of thousands of users over hundreds of years already know. 
Kratom has the potential to be a great benefit to society. It helps people avoid dangerous prescriptions and expensive doctor visits. This relieves pressure on the health care system and lowers insurance costs for all of us. Please do not take it off the market because of a few unscrupulous marketers and their outrageous claims of a legal high that alarm the authorities and encourage abuse by the ignorant. Please do not punish the large number of people who would benefit from this herb because of the misuse by a few.

documents.commentText:
To whom it may concern,

I am 30 years old and I am an IT Technician and, as of recently, the father of a baby daughter. I could write down a flood of text explaining what kratom is, citing various articles on the safety of this plant and why the DEA's perception of it is wrong, but if you are in fact someone who has the knowledge and credibility to be reading this letter then I'm sure you are already well aware of the fundamentals of the legal battle for kratom. With that said, I'll jump right into it.

I come from an abusive upbringing, both physically and emotionally. When I was 22 years old, I was prescribed Zoloft, a serotonin reputable inhibitor anti-depressant. It helped the frantic anxiety I've dealt with for the better part of my life but it also completely muted my personality. At age 24, following a botched dental surgery, I found myself on hydrocodone, an opiate painkiller, for more than 3 weeks straight. Hydrocodone was effective at easing my physical pain but not nearly as well as it did my existential, emotional pain. I was young and ignorant. I had no idea that it was of the same drug class as heroin and morphine and I was unaware of it'a addictive risk. 

When the prescription ran out, I wasn't ready to let it go, to go back to that familiar hurt and depression... So I kept running and sought out more hydrocodone illegally on the streets. I was an opiate addict before I even knew it. I've never really been much of a drinker. I didn't partake in the typical recreational substances like cannabis. I never had a prior problem with a substance for there to be any kind of red flag or to even know what a substance problem looked like. That destructive habit went on for over a year, as it slowly evolved into me buying whatever opiate pain pills I could find. At it's climax I was buying heroin when I couldn't find pills. Using heroin intranasally allowed me to rationalize my use because, "hey, you know? It could be worse. I could be shooting up."

A friend of a friend, a few years younger than I was at the time, overdosed on heroin and died alone in his bathtub. That's what it took for me to quit opiates. I stopped cold turkey and managed to make it 4 months before I slipped up an drew nearly relapsed. I didn't want to go back to that life but the Post Acute Withdrawal symptoms made life so seemingly impossible to live. I couldn't function, I was lethargic, unmotivated and incapable of experiencing any shred of joy. Desperate for a solution, I searched online for an alternative or anything that could assist me in feeling ok. That's when I found kratom. 

The interesting thing about kratom is that I could tell that it was in a sense quieting my screaming opioid receptors, but in a way that didn't feel like an opiate. I felt like I could rebuild my life and recover all that I've lost in such a short time. Not only did Kratom allow me to not crave opiates but it made tapering down and quitting Zoloft significantly easier than it would have been without it. 

I've been taking kratom more or less daily for nearly 5 years now. I haven't had a single relapse and I have never been able to hold a job for as long as I have while using kratom. I feel healthier. Kratom is rich in anti-oxidants but what is incredible isn't that I've only gotten sick once in the entire period of taking it. On average, I've taken 5 grams of powder in capsules, 3 times a day for about 5 years. Last year, I had an EKG, blood work and a liver enzyme test, all which came back with results showing that I'm perfectly healthy. No abnormalities and above average results.

As with most substances, there is going to be an adjustment period when you cease to use after prolonged periods of time. Yes, daily kratom use does come with the risk of mild physical dependence if you don't rotate strains and take breaks at least once a month, but it is on par with the physical withdrawal of caffeine and sugar, things widely accessible, things we give our kids. I don't believe that that alone justifies banning it and putting it in the same classification as heroin and MDMA. 

I believe regulation would be fine. I'm not opposed to quality control, regulation or any type of research that would minimize risk and empower the consumer to know exactly what they are getting. But please... please don't make it a felony. Please dont make it next to impossible to obtain. 

I thank you for your time.

documents.commentText:
I have been studying opioids for over 10 years and have published multiple research papers in peer reviewed journals related to opioid medications and their potential for abuse. I have worked for companies that focus on developing the Risk Evaluation Mitigation Strategies (REMS) for pharmaceutical companies that develop schedule II drugs and have a deep understanding of risk management issues when dealing with scheduled substances.

Relating to kratom and Mitragyna speciosa, I have personally researched this plant and have used it myself. It is abundantly clear that kratom alone is exponentially safer than any prescription or illicit opiate that currently exists. Although the active ingredient is considered an agonist at the opioid receptors, the intrinsic activity at the mu receptor that causes respiratory depression is rarely, if ever, strong enough to cause respiratory failure (even with the strongest extracts available). There seems to be a ceiling in which kratom's opioid agonist activity peaks. Even when combined with other CNS depressants such as benzodiazepines, it is very rare for users to overdose on Kratom. To new users, it is more likely that the user will become nauseated or vomit when they take too much kratom. It is close to impossible for users to consume enough kratom to cause any significant life-threatening risk. 

I do believe the agonist activity at the opioid receptors (like any opioid agonist) has the potential to cause physical dependence, but it is also clear from years and thousands of anecdotal reporting that the withdrawal from kratom is mild compared to pharmaceutical opioids currently on the market. Kratom also has a very short half-life (as a plant), and thus the withdrawal is also known to be of a much shorter duration. It is also clear that kratom has provided many heroin or pharmaceutical opioid addicts a much safer and "organic" alternative and that it has undoubtedly saved many lives. Kratom dosing as a powder, which is the form most users take, also allows dependent users an easier way to taper off the herb.

As with all drugs that go through FDA scrutiny, the gold standard is "risk vs benefit." The benefit of kratom clearly outweighs the risk when you review the scientific literature and when you speak with thousands of users who find kratom a much appealing alternative than prescription medications to treat all sorts of medical ailments from pain to insomnia to depression.

Finally, if kratom does become a scheduled drug, the unintended consequences is what I am most worried about. If the argument is that kratom is addictive and that many people are addicted to this plant, then scheduling kratom as a schedule 1 illegal drug will force addicts to turn to heroin, much like how many prescription opioid addicts turned to heroin when their supply of pain pills were cut off in the past decade. No one can argue that heroin is the gold standard opiate that is the leading cause of opiate overdoses. If Kratom is banned, it is a guarantee that there will be another spike and increase in heroin overdoses/deaths as former opioid users who have turned to kratom are now forced to go back to heroin.

I implore the DEA to review all the evidence and think about the consequences of banning kratom. Kratom has not only helped addicts detox off harder opioids as well as provided hardcore addicts who are not ready to stop using a safer alternative, it has also provided medically ill patients a natural alternative to more dangerous prescription medications. Scheduling Kratom would prevent further research on this plant for future medical uses for diseases that we currently are not treating effectively with modern medicine.

I strongly believe Kratom should remain legal and that this is one plant that needs to be carefully researched and looked at for all the benefits it possesses. While all things can be exploited and used irresponsibly, kratom is one plant that should not be lumped into the same category as illicit drugs, if not only for the fact that thousands of kratom users will turn to heroin, but that this plant has dozens of known benefits in the medical literature with the benefits clearly outweighing the dangers.

Thank you for your time.

Sincerely,

Ace S. (pseudonym), Ph.D. 

About me:
I have a Ph.D. in psychiatry and have worked on risk mitigation strategies and plans for pharmaceutical companies that make tamper-resistant formulations of strong opioids currently on the market - specifically oxycodone and fentanyl. I have 6 peer-reviewed articles, including articles published in the Clinical Journal of Pain, Pain Medicine, JAMA, and the Journal of Substance Abuse Treatment.

Kratom seems like a solution to a number of issues, including various forms of drug addiction and chronic pain. Plus, it can perform the pain-killing work of morphine without dangerously depressing breathing -- the way opioids do.

Here's how Kratom works...
It uses a pathway that mediates many of the undesirable effects of traditional opioids such as constipation, respiratory depression. In fact, this knowledge is spurring additional research by pharmaceutical companies.
http://bit.ly/2c8UTI6

About Kratom, a leading researcher notes...
Thailand is considering legalizing kratom as a safer alternative for meth addicts. U.S. researchers are trying to study its potential to help opiate abusers kick the habit without withdrawal side effects.
http://bit.ly/2c8SI7v
There are anecdotal reports of addiction risk. But it appears the addiction can be broken without withdrawal symptoms. Meanwhile, the painkillers currently being used are more addictive, dangerous, and harder to kick. Yet...

The FDA and DEA both appear ready to ban kratom and effectively kill research to further develop this substance. Is the DEA is running cover for a Big Pharma company that wants to monopolize kratom?

documents.commentText:
I was addicted to various opiates for 7 years. I got on suboxone but it gave me withdrawels that were worse than heroin. I discovered kratom and took it every day to get me through withdraws. It 100% worked and gave me relief without impairing me like methadone and suboxone does. Kratom made me functional enough to hold a job and save my money. It improved my relationships with other people. I have been on kratom for two years and I have never relapsed. I don't even feel the need to take kratom every day. If I feel like I am close to relapsing, I simply take a low dose of kratom and it curbs my opiate cravings. Kratom has also saved me a lot of money. I take 3-5 grams every 24-36 hours. I will take a higher dose if I am trying to forget about  really strong opiate cravings or feel depressed. I will also use higher doses for physical ailments or if I am sick and can't afford to take off work. After 2 years of almost daily use I am healthier than I have ever been because I am off drugs and alcohol. I have never experienced and negative side effects from daily kratom use. Below, I will list the positive and negative effects of this plant. I will also discuss potential kratom withdraw symptoms. 

Positive Effects: 
-Elevated mood/motivation
-Relief from opiate withdraw symptoms
-An enjoyable, but not impairing, mild buzz 
-Attentiveness
-Pain relief
-Constipation relief (because of the fiber)
-Stress relief
-Sociability
-Makes me work harder at my job
-Faster reflexes

Negative Effects: (but only due to an overdose; which has been a single dose that is 12+ grams)
-Dizziness
-Shaky hands
-Nausea
-Blurred vision
(all negative effects subside in 3 or less hours and then I am back to normal)

Withdraw symptoms (due to kratom use)
If you are still in the process of abstaining from opiates, you can experience various withdraw symptoms for about 6 weeks. (This is from my personal experience)
If you are taking kratom during this time, it is very possible to confuse your prolonged continuous opiate withdraws symptoms with kratom withdraws. 

However, If you take kratom every day for a year or more and never take an opiate to set you back, then it is possible that you will experience kratom withdraws if you suddenly stop taking it. Long prolonged kratom use can cause certain withdraw symptoms. 
Kratom withdraw symptoms are no where near as bad as opiate withdraws and really only last 72 hours at the most. But these symptoms can be easily dismissed and ignored, unlike opiate withdraws. I have never considered doing crime to get money for kratom. I have never felt a kratom "craving" except for times I needed it to deal with opiate cravings. I have never made myself go broke to buy kratom. The withdraws simply are not bad enough. Yes, kratom withdraws are uncomfortable, but they don't make you completely unable to go to work or school or function. 

Kratom Withdraw symptoms:
-Runny nose
-Loose stool
-Increased body temperature
-Sweating
-Restless legs (occasionally)

The DEA should stop any and all consideration of banning the herbal supplement kratom. There should be no prohibition. While the FDA is looking into it as well, most Americans have never heard of it. Why? Because there's NO REAL PROBLEM with it! Quite the contrary...

Kratom seems like a solution to a number of issues, including various forms of drug addiction and chronic pain. Plus, it can perform the pain-killing work of morphine without dangerously depressing breathing -- the way opioids do.

Kratom uses a pathway that mediates many of the undesirable effects of traditional opioids such as constipation & respiratory depression. In fact, this knowledge is spurring additional research by pharmaceutical companies.
http://bit.ly/2c8UTI6

Thailand is considering legalizing kratom as a safer alternative for meth addicts. U.S. researchers are trying to study its potential to help opiate abusers kick the habit without withdrawal side effects. http://bit.ly/2c8SI7v

There are anecdotal reports of addiction risk. But it appears the addiction can be broken without withdrawal symptoms. Meanwhile, the painkillers currently being used are more addictive, dangerous, and harder to kick. Yet...

The FDA and DEA both appear ready to ban kratom and effectively kill research to further develop this substance. 

Is the DEA is running cover for a Big Pharma company that wants to monopolize kratom?

As I consider these actions by the FDA and DEA I'm forced to wonder -- WHAT ARE YOU PEOPLE SMOKING?

documents.commentText:
In spite of the incredible advances in medical science over the past century, the treatment of mental health conditions remains woefully inadequate and fraught with public stigma. Sufferers of Substance Use Disorder are imprisoned for non-violent offenses and a substantial portion of the 15 million American adults suffering from clinical depression can expect regular recurrences, shortened lifespans, and a decreased quality of life.

I am a 27 year old marketing professional and software developer living with depression, a few anxiety disorders, and Post Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD). Before the onset of these illnesses I was on track to have my doctorate in Computer Science from a fairly prestigious university in my early 20s, having begun college in my mid-teens. These illnesses have robbed me of the energy, confidence, and concentration that I once had, sometimes sapping my motivation to such a degree as to prevent me from reaching for a glass of water that is right in front of me. In fact, the stress related to my trauma is so bad that I sometimes have psychogenic seizures in response to certain stress-related triggers. Simply put, these conditions are devastating. 

After years of therapy and having tried numerous psychiatric medications, I was ready to give up on the idea that things would ever get better. None of the currently available medications even touch my symptoms. Fortunately, a friend introduced me to the dietary supplement kratom and convinced me to give it a try. The difference was like night and day. When I take kratom, I experience as vastly improved sense of health and well-being. Kratom is an amazing tool for combating feelings of low motivation and for promoting an overall sense of calm. I don't take it as a substitute for medical treatment, but rather use it in conjunction with diet, exercise, and other factors that benefit sufferers of mental illness. It is comparable to other dietary supplements such as St. John's Wort or Valerian Root, while being unique and irreplaceable. 

Having taken kratom regularly for 8 years now, I can attest to its effectiveness in improving my quality of life. Since starting kratom, I've gone back to school and am now working toward two Master's degrees, I've also held an amazing full-time job for the past six years. Being able to function again at a high capacity when I was otherwise unable to find relief is nothing short of miraculous.

Kratom is an herb in the coffee family that has been used safely for hundreds of years in its native Southeast Asia. Although there are a small number of deaths in recent history in which kratom was consumed by the victim, it would be unfair to attribute these to kratom. In all but one case these deaths can be attributed to the presence of other substances that were also ingested. In no case has kratom ever been shown to be the cause of death, or even a contributor. If someone had coffee earlier in the day and died of a heroin overdose later, you wouldn't blame the coffee. So why blame kratom when someone dies after having consumed several illegal substances alongside it? 

Not only does this make no sense, but banning kratom will turn its 3 to 5 million consumers into felons. America already has the world's highest prison population, with a substantial percentage being non-violent drug offenders. People like me, who are simply trying to cope with devastating health issues, will find ourselves with two options: continue taking kratom anyway and potentially share a cell with a rapist if we are caught, or go back to suffering from a disability that is otherwise unmanageable. 

Like most responsible kratom users, I am definitely in favor of regulations that would prevent adulterated products from being sold to consumers. Similarly, I can see the validity of arguments in favor of keeping kratom out of the hands of minors and ensuring responsible advertising. However, it is vital that kratom remains easily accessible to those in need. Scheduling kratom, much like scheduling coffee, would place needless restrictions on an important tool, making it inaccessible to a large number of people.

For these reasons, I strongly urge the DEA to avoid making kratom a controlled substance.

documents.commentText:
Hi my name is Malee Holt, I am 54 and work in retail.  I have had chronic back pain for over 12 years and anxiety and depression most of my life.  I have been on many prescribed medications for all three problems.  And yes I've had success from some medicines.  But all have come with severe side effects.  So I started looking for safer natural alternatives.  In 2014 I came a cross a magazine article about Kratom.  I began to reserch it to see if it might be an herbal supplement that might help with my back pain.  After 6 months of reading about this herbal supplement I decided to order some.  After it arrived I waited till I had a day off before trying it.  After about 30 minutes of my first time taking Kratom I noticed my pain had disappeared and I felt my mood had lifted.  I began to feel normal and wanted to interact with people again.  I was petrified of being with anyone, even my family for fear of having a panic attack.  
   So since the summer of 2014 I have been taking Kratom to help with my chronic pain and depression and anxiety.  It has been a blessing to me to have a natural alternative that works.  I do still have to take medications for my mental problems that are prescribed by my psychiatrist.  But I don't have to take strong pain medications anymore.  I know that if I need the stronger medication in case of an injury or illness that I will be able to use a lot less of it and not be afraid of becoming dependent on it.
   I pray you will make the correct decision and not make Kratom a scheduled drug.  I am not against it being regulated.  But Kratom should remain a natural alternative.

documents.commentText: Good afternoon, my name is Joshua, I am 25 years old, and I reside in Washington state. This comment is being written to address the proposed ban on mitragynine and 7-hydroxymitragynine. I am quite nervous about speaking directly to a government agency as I have never attempted such a thing before, but I felt it necessary to voice my opinion on the matter. I discovered kratom online as a result of a lengthy search for natural and safe plant based substances that could effectively ease my often times severe anxiety and panic disorder. This took place a little over 2 years ago and I can say with complete confidence that I succeeded, and found something that insistently but gently lifted me out of a seemingly infinite pit of despair. During the short but significant time that I have used this wonderful herb, I have seen a flowering community emerge! A community full of extremely kind and friendly individuals who have found what some would deem miraculous relief from a multitude of different ailments. The free market surrounding kratom has resulted in widespread access and a growing number of people recovering from these ailments and thus reclaiming their lives and thriving! As a matter of fact, I have had the privilege of witnessing this firsthand with multiple people and on more than one occasion! To list one example, my girlfriend, who suffers with frequent pain brought on by endometriosis, experienced profound relief after consuming kratom. This is not to say she was not apprehensive, but upon hearing testimonials from other women in a similar position, she agreed. Kratom has become a godsend for countless people and should absolutely under no circumstances, be prohibited! The ramifications of such an action could prove to be quite tragic as many hardworking and law-abiding Americans could be plunged back into misery. I wanted to keep this brief so I think on that note, I will conclude. I offer my deepest thanks to any and all who read this and I greatly appreciate the devotion of your time!

documents.commentText:
Hello,

My name is Dustin, I am 28 years old and I work in management at a corrugated facility. 

I am opposed to the ban on Kratom because I have first hand experience regarding the benefits to using Kratom.  The majority of my adult life I have suffered from anxiety, and in seeking treatment I have found that traditional medicines actually make the majority of my problems worse.  I  have been prescribed benzodiazepines in the past, the result's were not desirable and my actions while on these drugs only made my anxiety worse. I turned to self medication with alcohol which only works short term but causes more long term issues. The self medication turned into addiction. 

My fiance gave me the ultimatum to cease drinking or she would leave. After researching alternative medications for anxiety and a couple relapses I discovered Kratom.  I have not had any desire to drink since beginning Kratom. My fiance has made comments on how I am much more pleasant to be around now as well. My relationships with my children and family have become so much better as well. 

I don't have any first hand experience with negative side effects of use, and I feel I am benefitting significantly from having this in my life. Banning this I feel would be counterproductive to the current fight on dangerous drugs and those wishing to quit. I think regulations on vendors to ensure the safety for consumers should be the focus for the DEA and FDA. 


https://www.scientificamerican.com/article/should-kratom-be-legal/

https://www.scientificamerican.com/article/kratom-drug-ban-may-cripple-promising-painkiller-research/

https://www.botanical-education.org/research/

jat.oxfordjournals.org/content/35/4/242.long

Thanks, I appreciate the being given the chance to comment on this!

documents.commentText:
To whom it may concern, 
 I personally am an advocate for kratom and the beneficial affects on peoples lives. I work in a retail shop that currently sells this product and has for a long time now. I have watched kratom dramatically change lives of many from all walks of life. This includes mothers, fathers, grandmothers, grandfathers, school teachers, public officials, and so on. To hear these peoples stories and the reason they have turned to kratom breaks my heart for this product to be removed from the market. Even if it has to be prescribed in this country,  I honestly would much rather see that than for it to be banned all together.r. I did try this product to see what affects it would have on my own body and I honestly dont see the harm in it at all. I have a bad disc in my back and refuse to take pain medication myself for the side effects of these medicines render my ability to be a functioning person in society. I am all about natural remedies to relieve pain if needed. Kratom is a product i personally would turn to if i honestly needed it. I did not find this product to be addictive in any kind of way. I am am a strong minded person that deals with pain everyday and am surrounded by this product as well on a daily basis and still dont find the need to take it on a regular basis. But i too understand why some people need this product daily. I know myself in the future as i get older my disc in my back is going to give me more trouble and i hope this product is around in the future for when i cant stand the pain anymore and need some relief. I have heard the peoples voices and sincerely feel for each and everyones circumstances. The beauty of this product is they can go out of their house and fuction as normal people in society without pain and teach our children, and  run our offices such as police stations and court houses. Be mothers and fathers to our future adults that are to form and shape this country, and make them productive citizens as well. The range of people that I talk to that use this product blew my mind when I began to ask their stories and  retain feed back so i would have a valuable outlook on what some may call a product that is harmful to our loved ones. I have had people literally cry and tell me that the products that are legal for pain prescribed by our doctors, doesn't even begin to touch the pain that they endure everyday. What angers me most about the potential of the ban is to know that all of these upstanding people are going to have to go back to other alternatives from our pharmaceutical companies and become addicted to a substance that renders their abilities to drive vehicles, take care of our children, and simply just to function with a clear mind. I understand the d.e.a does their best to regulate harmful chemicals that clearly effect the body, mind, and soul of our fellow human beings. But kratom come on guys this is not a harmful substance. I am completely dissapointed that this even has potential to be a schedule 1 narcotic. Its ludicrous that it can't even be prescribed to individuals. But their is no ban on substances that are sold to people daily from pharmacy counters all over this country daily that really do turn peoples lives upside down. I have seen these very products ruin peoples lives and tear families apart. Yet kratom I haven't seen do this at all. Thing I have seen it do is turn peoples lives around for the better and improve their quality of life. So with this said please don't take this product away and make people turn to prescribed narcotics that actually are harmful to their quality of life. I hope the right decision is made for all of these individuals that are going to suffer in the long run if kratom is banned. At least control it through our pharmacies if anything and make this an option for people whom want relief from pain but dont want the side effects from pain pills that are prescribed. Lets fight the real issues at hand from the substances that have taken a hold of our loved ones and continue to fight the war on real drugs not kratom. I hope this may have shed some light from an outsider looking in to this so called harmful product. I stress again please let it be prescribed before you just take it away all together. Think about these individuals in the long run that have jobs, kids, and families to take care of. They are not causing anyone any harm nor themselves.

documents.commentText: I am new to Kratom. I suffer from cronic myofascial pain, neuropathy and connective tissue damage since the year 2000 due to a mva. I am 55 years old, have a full time job since for well over 35 years and am a law abiding citizen. After the MVA in 2000 I have been to countless physical therapies at local hospitals and independently run locations - it did not take the pain away but did help with range of motion. In 2008 I had surgery and a titanium plate installed at C4/C5 to help with the cronic pain and numbing in my left arm and hand- which it did not. Have been receiving Trigger point injections to my neck, upper back and shoulders on a regular basis since. I have taken different types opiates and have suffered the side effects. I came upon Kratom in September of 2016 and have to say "I have suffered zero side effects". I feel "normal" and am able to focus and not feel tired all of the time. I actually have energy and have not felt this way in years. Kind of like a new lease on life with a clear head. It would be a great dis-service to many to ban Kratom. From what I understand, Kratom has been used for thousands of years. Why all the attention after all of these years? It seems like a money making opportunity for the DEA and related organizations/pharmecutical companies. If that is the case, I kindly ask that, that notion be put aside and instead look at all of the different types of benefits it has for many different diseases. Do your homework like I did. If Kratom is used as directed - there are no health risks or endangering anyones life. We deserve to be comfortable in our own bodies without side effects and the huge price tag. Please leave Kratom distribution just the way it is. Thank you

documents.commentText:
I am writing this letter to ask to stop the possible ban or federal regulation on Kratom. I am 33 years old. I am a US Army Veteran. I have worked in the Middle East several years as both an Armed Forces Service Member and a DOD Civilian as well. I have currently worked for my local city government for the last 7 years. I am also a business owner and combined a combined 100 hour work week. I do not use drugs. I do not drink alcohol. I am a Conservative Republican. My general morals and family values may be much more strict when compared to others. I believe in hard work, respect and drive. I love my country and I love my fellow Americans. I will do anything to protect our citizens and do what it takes to keep them safe.  

That being said, I am writing this letter, standing on behalf of my fellow Americans and a large group of disabled veterans. This plant, Kratom, should NOT be banned or medically or federally regulated beyond FDA food standards. This plant has given me and my family quality of life we have never had before. It is a simple herbal tea leaf. I use to take up to 25 pills a day for nerve and back pain from injuries aquired while serving my country. I do not like taking prescription pain killers and drugs as they make me feel like I am "on drugs." They make me feel dirty and totally disgusted with myself. They make me feel "dopey." I now only use kratom powder and extracts and that is all I need. I have never felt better and do not feel sick and more importantly, I do not feel impaired, intoxicated or sedated. When I say "sedated" speaking in regards to narcotics I am referencing to being intoxicated and non functional. When people say "sedated" in regards to kratom, they mean "more sleepy" vs more "energetic", just like Green Tea vs Camomile Tea for promoting sleep, please do not forget that. 

I have personally seen first hand the good it can do as I work with many disabled veterans groups who now have used this bulk herbs for up to 5 years helping veterans with disability issues, drug and alcohol use. I personally have very good friends who are licensed botanist and chemist who have also assured me that the alkaloids are in fact very safe and they are not the same alkaloids as many dangerous drugs that kratom may be compared too. This plant cannot kill you. It does not cause respiratory depression like opiates. We ALL know this at this point. I trust kratom so much that I would feel safe giving it to any one of my family members including my mid-age children. 

I have also come to realize that Pfiver is already working on patented products using kratom alkaloids. Many of us group veterans are wondering what our government agencies are going to do to represent us and block us from these type of special interest groups? DEA, FDA, this first line of defense starts with you. We have vowed to give our lives for you, so please remember that when making your decisions regarding trying to ban something that is giving us life after suffering. Please do not let this fall to profit corporations like everything else has. We pray your hearts are in the right place. 

I am a red blooded American. I would not do anything to put harm any of our nations citizens in harms way. I would die to keep them safe. There is an extreme drug use problem as well as health care problems in America. People needs help. I know this product saves lives and have seen it work for drug and alcohol addiction. It is a cheap product and can be bought by the lbs for around $20 and even cheaper if the market is not afraid to expand. It leaves people in a clear and conscious state. It heals. Its an herbal miracle. Even in extract form, I know it is not dangerous. The most negative effect it can have is make you nauseous, which is what I get after only eating a general multi vitamin. I dont feel it is as addiction as some have said. I have so much experience with this plant. I have taken it for many years now. if I stop, it is no more then restlessness when trying to sleep. I feel much worse after not drinking coffee and caffeine since I am a heavy coffee drinker

This is a simple non toxic plant from the earth, our earth, please don't try to keep this one from us. To ban or even let pharmaceutical companies control this product would be extremely dangerous to your fellow citizens. It would push good standing citizens back into drug and alcohol use and citizens who use it for medical purposes would be back at square one.  Yes, thats right, people will be in pain, suffering and even dying, at your hands. That is how serious this is. Please consider what you are doing.

documents.commentText: I am a 23 year-old Legal Assistant by day and student by night. I have many ambitions, one of which is to continue my career, gain my very own Bar number, and  practice law as a prosecutor. I would not be anywhere close to where I am today without Kratom. Like many fresh-faced college kids at 19, I use to wait tables, this is where I got introduced to Oxycodone. Buying a few of them only once a month turned into spending all of my money, time, and energy into making sure I had enough to get me through the day, better yet even get out of bed. I ignored my responsibilities, failed classes, couldn't pay bills, went from a very extroverted fun-loving person into spending my nights alone and depressed. It got so bad I could barely get out of bed and wouldn't shower for weeks at a time. I can recall 2 times where I probably shouldn't have woken up the next day. Luckily I have a very caring family who encouraged me to get help. I tried many times to stop on my own and even went to the doctors who gave me medications that supposedly would "ease the WD." Finally went into detox for 5 days becaause that was the Cheapest way considering my insurance wouldn't cover out or inpatient. That helped me get the through the worst parts, and this was 6 months ago. I thought I would be good to go, but No the last 6 months I have been clean but experience the most severe anxiety, restlessness, and Would get conctant goose bumps all day. My friend told me about Kratom (she studies Naturopathy) and Kratom is the only thing that eases these minor but lasting WD symptoms. I have always had anxiety which is why I liked the pills initially. Because of Kratom I have stayed clean, successful,have my life together and love life again. Kratom is so natural I don't feel any sort of high At all, I take a very minimal amount and I just have less anxiety and can focus on doing well in life. I know many people have gotten clean for this same exact reason so I really hope that this stays legal. I know many people would feel forced to old ways without it.

documents.commentText:
My name is Paul Ross, I am 38 years old and work as a Creative Director for a design + build company in Austin TX.

I am sincerely opposed to the DEA putting Kratom on the list of schedule 1 controlled substances.  In my opinion, it's pretty obvious that Kratom is a threat to Big Pharma's bottom line and they are putting pressure on the DEA to schedule it so they can continue to profit off of the proliferation of prescription pain medication. I have found through research, and my own personal experience that Kratom offers a natural solution to pain management. Kratom helps people, including my wife, to free themselves from prescription pain medication and all the terrible side effects associated with them, including addiction.

My wife, Summer, has struggled with neck and back pain for nearly 10 years and had been told by multiple doctors to "get used to it" b/c she would probably be on pain medication for the rest of her life.  She tried nearly everything she could think of as an alternative to taking pain medication but to no avail; that is, until she found Kratom.  She started using Kratom about 6 months ago after hearing about it from a good friend of ours, Sarah, who had recently been diagnosed with fibromyalgia.  Sarah explained how Kratom had been a Godsend and that she was able to quit using her pain medication within days of using Kratom.  Summer was thrilled to hear this and tried it for herself a few days later. She too was able to stop using her pain medication within days of starting Kratom.  Summer and I were thrilled that she had finally found an answer to her prayers.

I don't believe the DEA should be able to make a decision like this when there is so much evidence to support the benefits of Kratom.  Kratom is a natural botanical that can be used as a viable alternative to prescription pain medication, the same prescription pain medications that are the source of so many deaths and addiction across our country. To blindly throw Kratom into the pool of schedule 1 narcotics would be irresponsible to say the least, and with the stroke of a pen no less.  I am whole heartedly against it.

documents.commentText: Banning kratom expands the war on drugs, while the public overwhelmingly supports ending it.  If kratom is added to any one of the five drug schedules, people who use it will be criminalized and locked up behind bars.  Kratom has been used safely by millions of people in the U.S. and evidence supports kratom's potential as a pain reliever and opioid replacement.  Many people struggling with opioid addiction have turned to kratom to help them cut back or quit, but now all promising scientific studies on kratom's role in opioid treatment could be immediately shut down.  Side effects of kratom are minimal, and its withdrawal symptoms are weak and nearly inconsequential compared to the suffering of people trying to quit opioids.  Prohibiting kratom will worsen the country's problems of opioid addiction and overdose.  Please do not ban this crucial element in the fight against opioid addiction!!!

documents.commentText:
I'm am now using anonymous to write my statement since contacting Dana Kirkpatrick's office. I was treated like a common criminal and my voice was not heard. All they wanted was my private information which I gave and then I was afforded  no response back. I also signed the Dear Colleague letter with my full name so I hope you take my comment seriously.
Kratom should no be categorized as a schedule 1 drug. It has many health benefits with none of the side effects of many anti-depressants and opiates. I wont go into all the benefits since you now know what they are.
I have been using Kratom in a tea for almost 4 years now. Before my naturopath told me about kratom I was taking 30mg oxycodone 4 times a day and 2 Soma muscle relaxers. Kratom came at the right time for me because I was in the process of signing up for social security disability. I have 3 bone spurs in my neck and osteoarthritis which keeps me in a constant state of pain. I already had surgery to remove one and I have a titanium plate in my neck. The doctor's advice for me now is pain management. After being introduced to Kratom, I went back to work full time and I can now take care of my family. 
The pain medication the doctors put me on had horrible side effects. I never felt like myself and had horrible bouts of depression. All the pain killers did was mask the pain for a bit so I felt nothing and when it wore off I was in  more pain than I previously was. Pain medication is a vicious cycle creating more rebound pain. 
Kratom does not get me high. It lessens the pain and doesn't take away my sense of clarity. It is very important for me to have clarity in my life and pain medication took that away from me. The feeling kratom gives me is a sense of well being which in no way impairs my ability to function in my day to day life. 
I thank you for taking the time to read my email and I hope you take to heart the thousands of people who this scheduling law would impact in many destructive ways. Kratom is a safe alternative to the powerful debilitating drugs that the doctors now prescribe.

My medical Dr. prescribed Vicuprofin 7.5/500 mg 4 times a day. After 6 yrs. of taking this amt daily, it also became to take it's toll. documents.commentText:
I'd like to voice my opposition to the DEAs Intent to Schedule the alkaloids Mitragynine and 7-Hydroxymitragynine, which would make Kratom a schedule 1 controlled substance with no medicinal value. 
DEA is quite literally "barking up the wrong tree"! Banning the plant will be completely ineffective in solving the very real problem of people taking illegal drugs or unscrupulous vendors adding illegal and/or dangerous substances to otherwise harmless plant matter, but will definitely hurt the many thousands of responsible adults who have been using kratom on a daily basis without incident for many years.
I was stunned to hear of this proposed scheduling! I began using kratom in spring of 2016 as an addition to my arsenal in managing long term chronic low back pain that has been a part of my daily life since the late 1990's. This herb was mentioned in a master's (aka geezer) powerlifting forum as helping with chronic pain and arthritis. I was very skeptical of this substance I had never heard of before, since it seemed like it was too good to be true. However, after researching the possible benefits and risks associated, I placed an order with a reputable online vendor. I enjoy the tea, it tastes a lot like green tea, and is very soothing!
Back in the 1990's when I first had really bad pain, my back specialist doctor said I had two options: 1) drugs. 2) surgery. I have a physically demanding job and cannot take narcotics or muscle relaxants. NSAIDS are not recommended for long term use. At that time the surgery was experimental, and he said there was very little chance it would help because the imaging tests did not show any structural defect that was the cause of my pain so would probably not be relieved by surgery. I left the office that day, went to my car, and cried. I felt so hopeless with the realization that my doctor could do nothing for me and that I would be spending the rest of my life in pain.
With no viable medical options, I sucked it up and just learned to live with the pain. The pain is not really bad most of the time, just constant low grade stiffness and pain, interrupted often with episodes of debilitating pain. 
One really important thing I noticed as I took on the responsibility for managing this was strong correlation between mental stress and the pain in my back. Stress monitoring and mitigation is critical to keeping the pain at a low simmer. Physical activity is a very effective stress reliever, so I stayed physically fit and active throughout adulthood. 
About four years ago I took up weightlifting (powerlifting). My progress has been very slow due to the pain and stiffness in my lower back. I kept running up into a wall and could not progress past it without injury. Pain is a major impediment to moving the most muscle mass through a full, effective range of motion under sufficient load required to build strength (especially abdominal strength). Getting stronger has been the real key for managing the pain. I have not had a bad flare up in like 3 months! And kratom has definitely helped me achieve my physical fitness goals!
The way kratom works for me is complete pain relief! The feeling is calm yet energizing and the intensity is about the same as coffee, but without feeling jittery. I take it two or three times a week and my pain is GONE. The pain relief it is not at all like opioids. With an opioid, you are out of pain, but in a stupor, laying on the couch. With kratom, I am out of pain and doing chores or tackling a project. Recently I installed an aftermarket stereo to my Toyota LandCruiser after taking kratom. Working on a car, especially in and under dash work requires a lot of bending and contorting which would normally tick off my lumbar in no time, but I was able to work productively all day, pain free, completing the installation plus several other household chores, packing for our vacation, and watching a little football. Being free of pain, after so many years, is such joyful relief! 
You may write me off as some nutty self-medicator who has willfully abandoned modern medicine. From my perspective, modern medicine abandoned me, long ago, and left me no option but to take care of myself as best as I can. As a scientist (BS in Chemistry), my hope is that modern medicine will learn more about pain response, especially chronic pain, and come up with a more holistic view of solving this complex problem.
While I can live without this herb in my pain management plan (and if the ban goes through I will reluctantly get rid of what I have left), I am asking that the DEA cancel this wrongheaded, misguided and senseless action.

I ended up quiting my job that I had for nine years due to the stress. I started taking kratom about two months ago.  Ever since then I have had no anxiety. I love my new job and kratom helps keep my anxiety and stress from getting the  best of me.  I do not feel sick on Kratom.  I have been happy ever since.

documents.commentText:
I oppose the proposed addition of kratom to any one of the five drug schedules. This substance has been found to be helpful to individuals who are in pain. If this substance is added to a drug schedule, those who use it will be criminalized and locked up behind bars. This is an imprudent use of taxpayer funds. 

Kratom has been used safely by millions of people in the U.S. and evidence supports kratom's potential as a pain reliever and opioid replacement. The government should study kratom rather than ban it. A ban on kratom expands the war on drugs, which has proven to be both costly and ineffective. The public overwhelmingly supports ending the war on drugs. Kratom should be legally regulated, allowing for quality control measures and product labeling requirements. 

If Big Pharma is behind the move to place kratom on one of the drug schedules, then this is wrong. The public needs more options for treatment, not fewer. Prohibiting kratom will worsen the country's problems of opioid addiction and overdose.

documents.commentText:
I am writing you in regard to the proposed temporary ban on mitragynine and 7-hydroxymitragynine to the Schedule I of the Controlled Substances Act.
The DEA is adding these two substances, from my understanding, so that they can research them and fully understand them. This is why they are being temporarily added. However, I feel that it is a clear act of overreaching in power and poor determination ability as the logic of that statement is as follows: We dont understand something so we are making it illegal. By applying this logic, the DEA is adding to the continued waste of the US taxpayers dollar towards the war on drugs that America has been losing since its inception. If the DEA feels that there is something to be learned from kratom and the substances within the plant, then it should be studied by an independent team first before adding it to Schedule I.
Kratom is helping so many people each day cope with a myriad of problems that otherwise would require turning to addictive prescription medications like hydrocodone or morphine. People have also used it as a way to beat addiction to other legal substances with high abuse potential like alcohol or nicotine products. Many use it to treat depression, including a large contingent of our military, and have found it a very successful alternative to their previous solution, suicide. Furthermore, there are still many Americans who are uninsured and will remain uninsured who can find a natural and safe alternative to expensive prescription medications that low-income families could never afford.
It also seems that the DEA is using false research and anecdotal evidence from the FDA and the CDC to come to this decision. Both have said that they have received reports of kratom intoxication. The CDC has reported US poison centers received 660 calls about reported exposure to kratom. Of those calls 50% had zero to minimal symptoms and only 41.7% had moderate effects that required some form of treatment. We have no evidence of what that treatment could be from their report, but many kratom users treat the effects with Ibuprofen and Pepto-bismol. So based off 5 years only 49 people have reported major symptoms that had been exposed to kratom, but we also have no evidence that kratom exposure was the cause for the effects. All we know is that they had exposure at some point. The report implies that they also could have ingested rat poison in addition to kratom. This is not qualification for a scientific determination and follows the same logic as the anti-vaccer campaigns. Furthermore, making a determination from a report from the Center for Disease Control implies that kratom is a disease. Kratom isnt a disease. Its a plant. The same logic can be applied to roses, or carrots, or pine trees. It is flawed and should not be a determination to further illegalize something misunderstood. I assume you have already but you can read the report from the CDC here: www.cdc.gov/mmwr/volumes/65/wr/mm6529a4.htm
The majority of kratom users whom I have spoken to have said that kratom is very difficult to abuse. Ingesting too much of it makes you quite nauseous and so your body forces you to stop ingesting it naturally. Our bodies have many built in blockers for such abuse and in this instance the DEA isnt doing anything our bodies wont do naturally, except for waste time, money and criminalize even more people who need a natural substance to help them with their problems.
I am not a kratom user. I ingested a significant portion one time and it had zero effect on me. I mixed it with some tea. A friend of mine was with me and also ingested the same portion. He also had zero effects from it. None whatsoever. I am not writing you as a kratom user or someone who is abusing it or at risk of abusing it.  I am writing you because I feel that the DEA is overstepping their offices duties. They are not representing the American people nor are they putting American interests first. I can see no motivation for their action except to protect their own budgets or represent the major pharmaceutical companies who do have something to lose from kratom remaining legal. We know that major pharmaceutical companies do not always have their customers health in mind as evidenced by recent Mylan actions. I urge you to consider opposing the DEAs intent to ban kratom or delay it until hard, indisputable evidence can be found that the ban is necessary. I urge you to propose independent scientific and medical research into the effects, positive or negative, of kratom. I urge you to listen to the outpouring of stories from people who have used kratom to treat problems from opiate addiction, to depression, to chronic pain. I urge you to help us block this unethical, immoral and unconstitutional action.

documents.commentText:
3 years ago I had my first child. I struggled with unexplainable symptoms during my pregnancy, some of which turned out to be the result of a brain aneurysm. Even after my sons birth, I still struggled with back & joint pain, along with severe headaches. But more than that, I fell into a deep post-partum depression; it kept me from having any desire to engage with life, or my new child. I stopped working, putting financial strain on my newly formed family. I did the bare minimum necessary to survive.

One night a friend offered me one of her prescription Oxycontin pills. I knew that without a prescription, taking it wasn't a good idea, but I was desperate, so I did. My physical pain was gone, and even more miraculously, my depression symptoms were greatly lessened. But of course, without a prescription, the only way I could access what seemed to be my only solution was to buy Oxy pills illegally. In addition to putting me at risk for arrest, doing so would have added to my family's financial strain. Even so, I continued to accept pills from a friend for a time. And though I was able to start working again, I was only able to function when on Oxy. If I ran out, all my symptoms came back full force, and I would either have to get more, or face withdrawl. Determined to stop using Oxy, I researched alternatives to narcotic/opiod pain relief. There weren't many options. Eventually I stumbled onto a forum discussing Kratom. 

It seemed too good to be true; a 100% legal option that could not only relieve my pain, but could also help alleviate my depression symptoms, AND help me detox from a dangerous & illegal narcotic? And the solution was a plant; not a chemical cooked up in a lab, but something natural produced by the earth? I was skeptical, but still desperate, so I tried it. 

And when I say that I believe doing so saved my life, I am not exaggerating. Kratom saved my life. I truly believe that. It has allowed me to become a full participant in my own life again. To connect with my son and husband again. To live pain free, and to do so without the crippling weight of apathy and other depression symptoms weighing me down. I take Kratom daily, and while a perfectly effective pain reliever, I want to be clear that it is only a part of the treatment plan for my mental illness. I take it daily, but I do so in conjunction with therapy. 

My life isn't perfect, but it's improvement since my discovery of Kratom is nothing short of incredible. I cannot stress enough the importance of having a safe, affordable, effective and accessible method of pain relief and mood support available. Please keep in mind that I am only one among thousands of people whose lives have been improved like mine by this miraculous plant. There are people who, like me, cannot afford or don't have access to healthcare from a Doctor who might be able to prescribe pain medications like vicodin or Oxy. For them, Kratom may be the only option. Not to mention that it is a much safer option than opiods. 

The damaging long term side effects of taking something like Oxy have been well documented, as I'm sure the DEA is aware. Kratom comes with little to no risk of adverse side-effects or overdose. The DEA claims that the decision to place Kratom on the schedule 1 substance list was in part due to the fact that there were 15 Kratom related deaths between 2014-2016; however it is important to note that in most of those cases (such as 9 deaths in Sweden) the victims had also taken other substances (figures taken from http://www.snopes.com/kratom-banned-by-the-dea/). Compare this with the alarming number of prescription opiod related deaths (14,000 in 2014 alone, according to the cdc's own website--http://www.cdc.gov/drugoverdose/data/overdose.html) and it becomes clear that Kratom does not present a problem for this country, but a solution to what has become a dangerous epidemic. 

I implore the DEA to reexamine its conclusions about the supposed risks associated with Kratom use. Consider those conclusions in comparison with the well documented dangers of opiod use and abuse (keep in mind that Kratom is also less addictive than such drugs). Consider that there are real people, like me, who depend on Kratom every day. And know that, should the DEA choose to place it on the Schedule 1 substance list, those people will be put into awful situations, facing hard choices. How many of us will wind up pursuing some other method of pain relief illegally? How many will bankrupt their families in the process? How many will instead feel they have no option but to live with crippling pain or mental illness? 

If the DEA truly cares about keeping the public safe, it will make every effort to ensure Kratom becomes more accessible, not less. 

Thank you for your time and attention. I offer my gratitude in advance, as I trust that after carefully reviewing all relevant information, the DEA will make the right choice, indeed the only moral choice; and keep Kratom legal.

documents.commentText: Hello, I am a 31-year-old stage 4 cancer survivor and a survivor of osteonecrosis caused by septic arthritis affecting both my shoulders, both my hips and my pelvis.  I live alone, work full-time and will be completing my bachelors in Sociology this December.  I also live with chronic debilitating pain; grinding, stabbing, arthritic aches that my physicians tell me is only treatable with mind-numbing opioids taking away my ability to think or actively participate in my life.  Kratom offers a better, functional alternative to the chronic opioid treatments my government deems legal.  I am baffled that drugs like oxycodone/oxycotin are still considered legal when the consequences lead to abuse, addiction and in many cases, a gateway to something far more evil.  I live in Cleveland and I see first-hand what happens when uneducated doctors irresponsibly prescribe opiates destroying lives and devastating families.  Kratom offered pain control without addiction, relief without stigma.  It you choose to classify Kratom as a schedule I substance you are continuing to promote the use of dangerous synthetic compounds over natural effective pain management.  Please dont let trillion dollar pharmaceuticals influence your decision on whether to allow me access to a life worth living.  I battle with pain alone and I should be the one to determine how I want to fight.  Remember, your decision could take mine away.

documents.commentText:
I'll get to the end quickly. Three days, that is all the time left for a drug that saved my life. I was a freshman, excited to start a new year, and leave all the middle school drama behind. So you can imagine my shock when my life was overtaken by migraines that left me sobbing in the hallway, crumpled in a ball as teachers did the only thing they could. 
Are you okay? They would ask. 
Y-yes 
I would reply, trying desperately to stop the tears for a matter of seconds. I'd tried all my options, taken Ibuprofen for long enough it made me sick, when my dad came across a new option, Kratom as a tea. He'd been through his own share of migraines, and usually ended up being the one shuffling me from appointment to appointment in search of better treatment options. 
The last drug had helped, but then my doctor freaked out when I told her it didn't do enough to stop the pain. At that point, I left tears streaming down my face, holding onto my dad and telling him, Hold me. Do not let go, I don't know what I'll do. Ready to throw myself in front of a passing bus to stop the pain and hopelessness, I fought through tears, coughing and choking, nauseated but somehow still living. That is when I tried Kratom. 
It was tea, dark and bitter green tea. My dad had read about it, then picked it up from the store. It was a life saver. I began to be able to stay in school, without having to focus solely on not allowing the pain to show. I began to enjoy living again, and actually go to school more than twice a week. Kratom ended the chronic insomnia, gave me the ability to think, the will to speak up about my needs. But now, they are going to ban it completely. Those people who are using it to be healthy, law abiding citizens will become criminals overnight. 
This is the end of a drug that has helped many, and an end for the people who need it to survive. The end of life, for millions who use a plant to work, to stay in school, to make the world a better place; millions who will commit suicide because they chose to follow the law no matter the cost. We need these people in this world, and we can not lose without a fight. 
Please do more research before baking a drug that has proven so useful.

documents.commentText:
I am a 34 year old man. I work full-time at a non-profit. I am a recovering alcoholic, and I have been taking kratom as part of my regimen of health supplements for the past 2 years. It has been tremendously helpful for me as I ween myself off alcohol. Alcohol was destroying my life. Kratom has been a god-send. I do not crave it when I do not take it. It provides a slight pick-me-up similar to coffee, and there are no negative effects from taking it, only positives. 

I also struggle daily with depression and anxiety. Often my depression and anxiety are so intense as to be debilitating, interfering with my ability to go about my daily business, go to work, attend social functions, etc. I used to use alcohol to cope with these issues, and the alcohol would just make everything worse. With kratom, I can cope with my depression and anxiety with no adverse side effects. Kratom helps me to be a productive member of society. Without it, my depression and anxiety will once again become unmanageable. 

Please have compassion for us folks who struggle every day, just to live our lives. We are doing the best we can. Kratom helps us tremendously and doesn't destroy our lives in the process, like alcohol, or legitimately illegal substances such as pain pills or heroin. Kratom is not at all like these substances and should not be made illegal. Kratom is simply a tea, related to the coffee tree. 

Again, when I do not take kratom, I have no withdrawal or craving. I simply begin to feel my chronic anxiety and depression again. Please, have compassion. Keep kratom legal for adults. Making this tea illegal will do nothing except make peoples' lives harder: people who already have enough on their plate just getting through each day in a positive and productive manner. 

This is my final plea: have compassion for people dealing with depression, anxiety, alcoholism, and drug addiction. Keep kratom legal for adults. Please do not take away one of the best tools I have in my arsenal for living a normal life, with no drawbacks or negatives. This tea is pure positivity; it helps me live my life well. Please keep it legal. Thank you.

documents.commentText:
TO: Drug Enforcement Administration, Department of Justice
ATTN: DEA Federal Register Representative/ODW
RE: Docket No. DEA-442W

To whom it may concern:

I am writing to express my opposition to both the permanent and temporary scheduling of mitragynine and 7-hydroxymitragynine and to urge the DEA to regard these as noncontrolled substances under federal law.

The principle motivation for my opposition to the scheduling of these substances is the reports I have received first-hand from friends and acquaintances who have escaped crippling addiction to opioids by using mitragynine and 7-hydroxymitragynine in their whole plant form, commonly referred to as "kratom." 

Like so many Americans, I have lost loved ones to the plague of opioid addiction and it is painfully obvious that national strategies involving law enforcement, prescription drug reform, and substance abuse education have not yet converged on a successful solution to this epidemic. The fact that a legally available product is reported to severely diminish opioid withdrawal symptoms and aid a person's genuine efforts to quit using dangerous drugs is acutely promising.

A corollary benefit to refraining from scheduling mitragynine and 7-hydroxymitragynine is that consumers are able take action on their own to combat addiction. The social stigma surrounding drug addiction and treatment cannot be overstated. Compounded by the consideration that substance abuse treatment is prohibitively priced and often simply unavailable to many Americans, the self-empowerment obtained from managing one's own treatment can profoundly contribute to a healthy, drug-free mentality. It is for this reason that I implore the DEA not to schedule these substances in a manner which would necessitate a prescription for their use: the efficacy of autonomy in one's own treatment can be powerful and emancipating. It is imperative that Americans do not lose a potential avenue by which to take control of their own lives.

The DEA's move to solicit public comments regarding scheduling of mitragynine and 7-hydroxymitragynine is extremely heartening and is a testament to the sincere intentions of the DEA to hold the public's health and well-being at the utmost primacy of importance. Looking into the future, federal policy regarding these substances must be sustainable and it is crucial that the DEA sends a clear message to the many current and recovering addicts in this nation that these potentially life-saving substances will be a viable long-term self-treatment option. 

Thank you for considering my comments as part of the DEA's renewed assessment of mitragynine and 7-hydroxymitragynine.

Respectfully,
Caleb Hicks, Ph.D.
