documents.commentText:
To whom it may concern,

   I am writing to ask you to please not place Kratom on the list of scheduled drugs. I am 47 years old & an animal welfare advocate. I'm also disabled. For almost seven years I was in and out of the hospital, dependent on a cane, walker, or wheelchair to get around, and in constant pain. Three years of pain management did nothing for me other than create more health issues due to the side effects. A little over a year ago, a friend suggested that I try Kratom. It changed my life. I am able to walk unassisted, perform basic every day tasks, even walk my dog short distances. My disabilities will not get better, I still have surgeries ahead, but I am no longer homebound. If Kratom is made a scheduled drug, my only option is to return to pain management, which scares me to death. I am under the care of doctors, where regular checkups and blood work have shown no ill effects from Kratom. I have never suffered withdrawals from Kratom. I support age restrictions for purchasing Kratom. I believe in purity standards, testing, and medical research. I do not think that Kratom should be sold in gas stations or smoke shops where minors could easily gain access. I am in favor of reasonable regulations. I am not in favor of a flat out ban on this beneficial plant based on fear of the unknown. Kratom has been used for millennia throughout the world and I deserve to be able to make decisions on what is best for my health. I thank you for your time and consideration in this matter.

I would request you not ban kratom for the following: 
-If kratom is added to any one of the five drug schedules, people who use it will be criminalized and locked up behind bars.
-Kratom has been used safely by millions of people in the U.S. and evidence supports kratom's potential as a pain reliever and opioid replacement.

-Side effects of kratom are minimal, and its withdrawal symptoms are weak and nearly inconsequential compared to the suffering of people trying to quit opioids.

My mother-in-law sent my husband some kratom after she read about it in a forum for people with Thoracic Outlet Syndrome and CRPS.  A physical therapist recommended kratom tea to one of his patients.  After reading about it, she decided to send him some, and much to his surprise, it took his pain level down a notch.  When one suffers from nerve pain, any reduction in pain is huge.

Three months after my husband started using the kratom tea, my father died suddenly which was and still is devastating to me as we were very close.  One day while being especially low and crying, my husband made me some tea, and it helped ease my anxiety and call me down.  It is a year later, and my husband was medically retired from the service, we moved in with my in-laws, and I am in school full time.  I make a hot beverage out of the kratom one or two times a day several days a week which helps me deal with the stresses in my life.  I don't drink alcohol as I don't like the effects.  Kratom has no side effects, and it has improved my well being.  

Please regulate it, study it, but don't ban this herb, please.  It is beyond me why this would even be considered being banned.  There are always going to be people that try to get high on something, be it alcohol, glue, gas, compressed air, and the list goes on.  I am a responsible adult with a family and want to be able to take an herb that helps me.

documents.commentText: Adults have the right to make decisions about their own bodies. Many wonderful things in life contain some element of risk, such as eating raw foods, sky diving, or just going for a drive in a car. documents.commentText:
Docket No. DEA-442W

To Whom it May Concern,

I am writing to state my opinion that Kratom should remain a legal herb, freely available to folks to purchase with no more regulation than chamomile tea, or at worst, tobacco.  

I have watched heartfelt testimonials online from productive members of society who use Kratom to wean themselves off prescription medications and relieve anxiety and pain.  It would be criminal to deny people their ability to heal themselves with this harmless beneficial herb. 

I have successfully earned two Masters Degrees, learned fluent German and Spanish, traveled extensively, and am currently a home owner and speech pathologist.  A few times a month, I experience heightened anxiety.  After researching Kratom, I discovered that if I drink a weak tea from kratom leaf powder with hot water, milk, and honey, I am able to breathe again and focus on my routine without experiencing the feelings of rising panic that otherwise make it more difficult for me to perform daily tasks on high-anxiety days.  I am grateful for the freedom I had to find an herb that could help me fight anxiety.  I have tried Kratom on a low-anxiety day, and it did not appear to affect me much, and I'm not interested in drinking it more often. 

I understand that unscrupulous sources of Kratom mix the ground leaf with harmful substances that have caused negative effects in a few dozen cases.  If Kratom needs regulation, it would be to prevent this type of fraud, but the solution is not to make Kratom leaf itself illegal.  For comparison, millions of citizens have died from using nicotine, alcohol, and legal pharmaceutical drugs.  Even laundry detergent has harmed thousands of children; Kratom has not caused this magnitude of problem, so to call it an "imminent hazard" is simply inaccurate.  On the contrarywhen Alabama made Kratom illegal, deaths from overdose increased!  

I suspect pharmaceutical companies are complicit in the anti-Kratom movement.  Please do not allow corporations' bottom lines to trump individuals' ability to make choices about their health.  Please honor our experiences.

Thank you for extending the commentary period.  I hope you heed the country's feedback and keep Kratom legal and easily available.

documents.commentText:
Hi,

I beg of you to refrain from repeating history. We only learn by studying from history what has and has not worked. Scheduling marijuana has had detrimental effects and essentially created a black market for a harmless drug (eg. Drug cartels, drug rings, etc) but more importantly impaired research to find the beneficial properties of the drug. I see a similar problem with kradom. 
While the adverse affects of the natural plant and it's benefits are not fully researched, scheduling it will lead to years of legal battles. Using simple logic and reason one can conclude that criminalizing a non lethal plant will lead to the incarceration of non-violent individuals. Criminals will be more enticed to deal kradom through the black markets because criminalization will undoubtedly increase its price. This invites dangerous individuals into a non-dangerous market essentially creating a problem that doesn't exists as of today. Incarceration for profit will surely be looked at more intensively if laws target non violent individuals and create laws that criminalize activities that don't harm others! Kradom causes no known side effects or consequences other than ones that closely resemble caffeine and ibuprofen.
Perhaps the largest case that can be made for not scheduling kradom is for its propreties as an alternative to opiods. From pain killers to heroine, kradom has been known as a non lethal, no adverse side effects, alternative for individuals addicted to pain killers and opiods. For this reason alone, an immense amount of research should be put into this plant to maybe help end the opiod addiction that is gripping America. Doing anything in the contrary may be deemed as inhibiting progression of cures in order to keep Americans addicted to prescription pain killers and herione. 
With the absence of adverse effects and a lack of research dedicated to the plant without a legitimate examination by the FDA, scheduling kradom is unconstitutional and has no just cause. Do not repeat the mistakes of the past. Please begin being the solution to healing the sick and fixing our justice system. LISTEN TO THE PEOPLE.
ps. I've never used kradom, only have known people using kradom. It's a miracle for those in pain. No addiction, pain relief and mood elation. Nothing wrong there.

documents.commentText:
We the people of the United States are tired of having un-elected bureaucrats act for special interests and against the people.  It is time the government worked for us, not against us.

The FDA and DEA both appear ready to ban kratom and effectively kill research to further develop this substance. Is the DEA is running cover for a Big Pharma company that wants to monopolize kratom?

The DEA should stop any and all consideration of banning the herbal supplement kratom. There should be no prohibition. While the FDA is looking into it as well, most Americans have never heard of it. Why? Because there's NO REAL PROBLEM with it! Quite the contrary...

Kratom seems like a solution to a number of issues, including various forms of drug addiction and chronic pain. Plus, it can perform the pain-killing work of morphine without dangerously depressing breathing -- the way opioids do.

Here's how Kratom works...
It uses a pathway that mediates many of the undesirable effects of traditional opioids such as constipation, respiratory depression. In fact, this knowledge is spurring additional research by pharmaceutical companies.
http://bit.ly/2c8UTI6

About Kratom, a leading researcher notes...
Thailand is considering legalizing kratom as a safer alternative for meth addicts. U.S. researchers are trying to study its potential to help opiate abusers kick the habit without withdrawal side effects.
http://bit.ly/2c8SI7v

There are anecdotal reports of addiction risk. But it appears the addiction can be broken without withdrawal symptoms. Meanwhile, the painkillers currently being used are more addictive, dangerous, and harder to kick. Yet...

As I consider these actions by the FDA and DEA I'm forced to wonder -- WHAT ARE YOU PEOPLE SMOKING?

documents.commentText:
Dear DEA,
 
Please remove Mitragynine & 7-hydroxymitragynine which is in Kratom from becoming a Schedule I substance.
 
I am 29 and suffer from a herniated disc, chronic neck pain, TMJ, arthritis in my neck. I support a family of four on a single income as a Help Desk Tech. I have been to many doctors with little success for treatment. I have found that Kratom improves my quality of life after a hard days work. It isnt comparable to any drugs, marijuana, alcohol or other stimulants.  Kratom helps to improve my quality of life that I suffer with chronic pain. Please dont make this herb illegal. Cervical injections, botox injections, chiropractic care, physical therapy, acupuncture, massage therapy, yoga exercises have not helped with my pain.
 
Kratom is a well-known, well-researched herbal substance drawn from the leaves of trees within the coffee family. The number of cases of documented harm from kratom use is remarkably low, both as an absolute matter and when considered against the extensive history of use of kratom, both inside and outside the United States
 
Mitragynine and 7-hydroxymitragynine are two of the primary alkaloids of this plant. These two compounds are not synthetic and should not be lumped together with  "bath salts" or "spice".
 
Kratom has been used as a medicine by many people for thousands of years. It is a potent remedy for physical pain, anxiety and depression, and could be used to aid with opiate withdrawal by those who would like to quit using illicit drugs such as heroin. Kratom is NOT a hallucinogen and should not be classified as such. Adding mitragynine and 7-hydroxymitragynine as a Schedule I substance is rash and unjustified prohibition, resulting in a foreseeable increase in street drug-related crime, as well as a punishment to those who are currently using it responsibly to treat various ailments.

The reason that there are no deaths solely attributed to Kratom is because Kratom does not affect your respiratory capacity. It does not slow down your central nervous system. It's potential to do harm is virtually impossible.

Kratom has very limited recreational capacity.  The White House petition has over 100,000 signatures for the "Please do not make Kratom a Schedule I Substance." 

The federal government has invested significant resources to develop alternative pain management strategies. This includes a study funded by the National Institutes of Health in partnership with the University of Massachusetts and the University of Mississippi to investigate the use of Kratom as a remedy for opioid withdrawal. This study led the researchers to apply for a patent identifying the Kratom extract, mitragyinine, as a useful treatment for other addictive drugs besides opiate derivatives. The DEAs decision to place Kratom as a Schedule I substance will put a halt on federally funded research and innovation surrounding the treatment of individuals suffering from opioid and other addictionsa significant public health threat. Remember the DDear Colleague Letters of Senator Hatch and Congressman Mark Pocan.
 
We hope you realize the threat this scheduling causes the people seeking legitimate use of this special plant to improve our quality of life. Attached are testimonies and facts about Kratom along with other facts listed below. 

Sincerely,
 
Anonymous

documents.commentText:
Hello,

I am writing today to announce my strong opposition to the proposed scheduling of kratom. Below I have outlined a few of the arguments that support my stance.

1) Kratom has already been legislated. This proposed emergency scheduling, while technically legal, is a gigantic misstep in the preservation of democracy. Numerous states have already made legislative decisions on the legality of kratom. This proposed scheduling plans to usurp those decisions and the will of the people who made them. 

2) Kratom is not an opiate. Kratom is an opioid, meaning it affects opioid receptors in the body. Endorphins, the chemical released during exercise, also affects these receptors. I hope this comparison makes clear just how big of a mistake it is to lump kratom in with opiates. 

3) Kratom is an unadulterated plant from the coffee family. It's not more of a "drug" than coffee. Most people make a tea with kratom and use it in the exact same way people use coffee. It helps them get through their work day by relieving minor aches and pains and providing a small pick me up. Hardly the demon it is being made out to be by uninformed people with no first hand experience.

4) Kratom is safe. The small handful of deaths that have been attributed to kratom are a classic propaganda technique. Anyone who actually reads the reports will see that those deaths were caused by ingestion of Tramadol, a dangerous narcotic that somehow is scheduled lower than kratom - a tea - is proposed to be scheduled. No overdoses or deaths have EVER been attributed to kratom alone, to my knowledge. The citing of CDC numbers for calls about kratom is preposterous - even simple, safe, household cleansing agents have received staggeringly large amounts of calls. Even when taking into account the proportions of people drinking kratom, it's an incredibly low number. People are calling for information - not because kratom should be illegal. 

5) Normal people use kratom. I am an executive at a mid size tech company. I drink kratom tea at work because it's helpful for focus and getting work done. It has impacted my life in a hugely positive way. You who are reading this - imagine if the DEA decided, for seemingly no real reason, to schedule coffee as schedule 1. That is how I feel about this proposed scheduling.

6) Kratom and opiate abuse - kratom's mild effects provide a small relief from the withdrawal of stronger opiates. It's not a replacement for opiates! By taking some of the pain and stress away from withdrawal, it allows people to quit without facing the full force of the most daunting aspect, the withdrawal. The unique properties of kratom, which gives a very mild uplift and pain reduction without the possibility of overdose, make it an incredibly valuable plant for our society. Kratom does not cause respiratory depression, which is what people die from when they overdose on opiates. Which makes sense, because it's not an opiate.

Thank you for reading my comment.

documents.commentText:
Docket No. DEA-442W - my comments

Dear DEA,
Thank you for allowing us this commenting period. I would like to ask you to please not place Kratom as a Schedule 1 substance. Kratom has allowed me to live a happy and healthy lifestyle. A sober life that I simply thought was not possible for me.

Between the ages of 13 and 19, I was prescribed a plethora of medications. Often prescribed to take a variation or combination of anti-depressents, anti-psychotics, mood stabilizers, and hypnotics. In college, I was passing withs A's but the side effects of these medications were so unbearable that I eventually had to withdraw from school just ween off off them. It's been over 2 years since I withdrew from school and have been working full-time since then. Although I quit those medications, the symptoms of my Anxiety and Bi-Polar disorders only grew worse but I wrongly thought I could just ignore them. I ended up working my self to the bone at minimum wage and to slowly find myself trapped in various addictions. Mainly Alcohol, Cocaine, and prescription Opiates. When I had finally moved away in hopes of quitting cold turkey, I endured the full effects of acute opiate withdrawal until I found out about Kratom. 

There was a convenient store nearby that sold the loose powdered form of Kratom and I found that even just a tiny bit of it (2-3 grams) could completely mask the pain and suffering I felt while withdrawing. In fact, I actually felt better. I was able to organize my room and search for jobs. With Kratom, I managed to pursue job interviews and actually secure two part time jobs within two weeks of being sober. A feat that simply could not have been possible with out the help of Kratom.

I am now 3 months sober and continue to benefit from Kratom. As I progressed in my recovery, I learned that I would still have to deal with my pre-existing psychological disorders. However, I've found that certain strains of Kratom have allowed me to cope with my anxiety disorders. I am able to hold conversations, remain realistic yet positive, and have been able to mend some broken relationships with friends and family members. Kratom has even allowed me to quit smoking cigarettes!

Thank you, again, for allowing people like me to express our stories and concerns. I respectfully ask that you not place Kratom as a Schedule 1 substance as I feel it may do more harm than good.

Sincerely,

Dylan Flanagan

documents.commentText:
Three weeks into unbearable pain that wouldn't go away. I broke down and went to the fastclinic on October 24, 2016 (I loath doctors and all medications). They immediately sent me to the EMERGENCY ROOM. Long story short they put me on Oxycodone and it didn't even touch my middle-ear infection pain. Four days later the pain was worse then ever due to the Oxy. I was given an antibiotic and an anti-fungal also but I would not take them after reading about their insanely harmful side effects. I was still bound to ice cubes in my mouth and an ice pack on my ear 24/7. On October 28, 2016 I was going to go to the regular clinic but instead, I read about Kratom online and got a small bag locally. It made the pain bearable and it allowed me to know where it was coming from exactly, and exactly why it was so painful. 

The pain was exactly like the pain you would feel if you were to squeeze a pimple, bump or lump on your body that isn't ready to come out through the surface of the skin yet. And the second that searing pain starts you stop squeezing and bounce around a few seconds until it is gone and say, "I am not doing that again." documents.commentText:
I am a surgeon who takes care of cancer patients on a regular basis, and I frequently prescribe Schedule II drugs for pain. There are two subsets of patients to whom I have recommended Kratom, usually as an extract. The first subset involves patients who don't tolerate regular opioids secondary to side effects or sub-optimal pain relief. To my surprise, many have done well using Kratom extracts, sometimes in conjunction with medical marijuana. The other subset involves patients who have a history or opioid addiction. From what I have seen this group appears to do well with Kratom without triggering relapse. Of course this is anecdotal, but research could show that this Kratom is a viable alternative to regular opioids in this group of patients.>>>>>

I work at a county hospital and many of my patients are low income which means that they have to pay for Kratom out of pocket. Despite this they continue to use Kratom because it has fewer side effects and seems to last longer requiring fewer doses per day and allows many of them to sleep through the night.>>>>>

I notice that there are very few comments from clinicians. I believe this is because the majority of physicians have no knowledge of Kratom and its effects. Making Kratom Schedule I will keep this knowledge from them permanently. I believe that we should be aiming for the opposite effect. At a time when opioid addiction is rampant we should keep alternatives available and do the proper scientific research to see if this drug is truly safe and effective.>>>>>

I urge you to refrain from scheduling Kratom at this moment. I realize that it can't currently be scheduled as Schedule II since it doesn't have a proven medical use, but if it is made Schedule I research will be exceedingly difficult to do. Making Kratom Schedule I will also deprive many patients of an alternative to Schedule II narcotics which have multiple documented serious and sometimes fatal side effects.>>>>>

Thank you for considering my comment.

documents.commentText: My name is Amanda and I am writing you to voice my story about Kratom and the effects it has made in my life and the life of someone I love. I have been in a relationship for over a year with someone who was addicted to heroin. Their habit controlled them completely, every aspect of his life was based on it. If he didn't have that drug in his system he was unable to cope with everyday life. Heroin has even killed him in the past and he still had to have it. The addiction was unmanageable and took a toll on him physically, mentally, emotionally and financially. He had tried the suboxone and subutex clinics and always ended up turning right back to heroin. Those clinics did nothing more than kept him addicted to opiates and after missing one appointment for a script he was right back at square one with withdraws just as bad as heroin. Reason for missing the script was because the cost of those doctor visits and prescriptions are very expensive and have to be paid in full at time of service. After reaching out to other recovering addicts on social media he came across 'kratom'. We did a lot of research on it and decided to try it out.. Its a natural plant grown from the earth, it had to be better than the alternative. Once he received his first order and started dosing the kratom the change in him was amazing. He could finally function. He got out of bed every morning and was involved in our daily life like any normal human being does. He didn't have any cravings for heroin, no withdraw symptoms of not having heroin, and was not high like heroin made him when he did it. It has changed him entirely as a person. Its made him feel like he can achieve what he deserves in life and he has a chance to be a model citizen in society. Heroin controlled him, it took away all his happiness and will to live. Even when he was high on it, it wasn't a pleasant experience for him. After being on it for so long it doesn't get you high, you just get the feeling of not hurting or feel sick.You still don't have the will to live like people not addicted have. Kratom gave him that will to live back. Kratom doesn't control him, it helps him control himself. Kratom removes all cravings for heroin, it releaves the body pain he has from being hep-c positive, it calms the symptoms from PTSD and helps him sleep better. Its also helped with his bi-polar 1 diagnoses and calmed down some of the mood swings and manic episodes. To lose kratom in his life would be devastating. For once over many years he has finally felt normal, hes finally progressing in life and even wants to better himself with schooling. He finally feels like he has control and can handle whatever life throws at him. Hes became very active in trying to help anyone who has an addiction to heroin or any other narcotic that has taken over their lives and teach them about the natural plant that helped save his life. Without this plant in his life I'm not sure where he would be, if he would even be alive. I know that being with him during his addiction to heroin and also being with him once he stopped the heroin and started the kratom was a difference like night and day. To take kratom away from him would be, honestly, life threatening. This all natural, God given plant has given this man his life back. Not once has he had any bad side effects from it, nor has he ever been unable to function because of it. I can NOT say the same about the alternatives like subutex or suboxone. I've seen with my own eyes over the past year of us being together what effects kratom has had on him and I cant even begin to put in to words the positive difference it has made. It was painful to love someone and see the hell they go through addicted to heroin. Not knowing if they were going to be okay, if they were even going to wake up to live another day. With kratom I know hes going to be okay, I know hes going to be here with me for many days, even years to come. I couldn't say that before, I honestly didn't know what each day held for us, if he was going to make it through that day or not. With kratom, there is no question, no worries, no more fear of what might happen. Kratom gave him life back. This plant saves lives. I ask of you to please not ban kratom, please do not take a God given plant away from people who are trying to better themselves the safest way possible.

documents.commentText:
I am a loyal American, 60 years old, veteran of 22 years active military service. After many long years of sacrifice on my part, over half my life spent separated from friends and family in order to do the bidding of the US Government; all of this wear, tear, and service related injuries have left me a chronic pain patient.  I have discussed my use of Kratom with my primary care physician AND my pain management specialist physician.  I have used this herb to manage my pain successfully for 15 years already, under a Doctor's care and monitoring.  The first 4 years I took Kratom my Doctor tested my blood and urine (first for a baseline test on my health) every 90 days in order to see if the herb was having any deleterious effects on my health. None were detected!  Since then I have been similarly tested every 6 months; after 15 years, no bad health effects from using Kratom responsibly.  My pain management specialist, in addition to spinal injections, prescribes me an allocation of (90) 7.5mg Hydrocodone pills each month.  However, he is constantly amazed that I only fill the prescription once every 3-4 months!  I can mostly manage my pain with the natural herb Kratom.  I personally know dozens of other veterans who use and prefer kratom to opioids.

If I loose access to kratom I'll have to fill that 90-pill prescription to hydrocodone every month, perhaps even ask for more. In addition, I would no longer be able to work, because I cannot drive while on the stupefying effects of prescription opioids. Scheduling kratom would  vastly increase your costs of keeping veterans healthy and pain free, because as it stands now, Kratom is not covered by medical insurance, so we (happily) pay the cost of the herbal medicine, rather than suffer the side effects of prescription opioid drugs. Once that option is taken away, you will experience an immediate and costly increase in expense to the American taxpayer to provide veterans with Tricare Military Retired  and/or Medicare medical benefits. There will be more doctors visits and more prescription drugs paid by taxpayers.

I am not a  kid trying to find a "loophole" in the "drug war" for a legal high. Kratom has many benefits and few to no side effects - making it illegal is the wrong move: 
	Banning kratom expands the war on drugs, while the public overwhelmingly supports ending it.
	If kratom is added to any one of the five drug schedules, people who use it will be criminalized and locked up. This is an unnecessary expense for taxpayers to bear.
	Kratom has been used safely by millions of people in the U.S. and evidence supports kratom's potential as a pain reliever and opioid replacement. Another benefit of taking the herb Kratom over prescription opoids, is that instead of causing me severe constipation (typical of prescription opoids), kratom the herb as taken whole (ground up plain dry leaf) has a LOT of fiber in it.  It relieves my pain; when water gets to it in my stomach, it becomes a large mass of fiber, helping to keep me regular.
	Many people struggling with opioid addiction have turned to kratom to help them cut back or quit, but now all promising scientific studies on kratom's role in opioid treatment could be immediately shut down.
	Side effects of kratom are minimal, and its withdrawal symptoms are weak and nearly inconsequential compared to the suffering of people trying to quit opioids.
	Prohibiting kratom will worsen the country's problems of opioid addiction and overdose. Even people like me who have a prescription to opioid drugs are at higher risk for accidental overdose by taking the pills, compared to using the herb kratom to manage pain. It's easy when under the stupefying influence of prescription drugs to "forget" you took a dose and take another pill. It's virtually impossible to forget you just choked down a bitter glass of kratom tea, and even if you do and take more kratom an overdose is almost impossible. 

I do believe that some minor regulation of kratom NOT involving scheduling, would be in the public interest. The following are my suggestions:
1) The minimum age for purchasing and using kratom should be 21, like for alcohol. It is unlikely that anyone below that age would truly suffer from the type of pain that kratom is so good at relieving.
2) Plain dry herb is very effective; high strength extracts (e.g. 50X or 100X) are unnecessary and ripe for abuse, and thus should be prohibited.
3) Outdoor cultivation of kratom should be banned in the USA in order to avoid the possibility of introducing another non-native invasive species.

Using the dried leaf of the kratom plant, either by consuming it whole and unmodified (i.e. powdered and in capsules) or by making a simple tea beverage of plain leaf, must remain legal methods of administration (making a simple water-based tea must not be considered "extraction" by any law).  Kratom is a tropical tree in the Coffee family, and no more dangerous than coffee when used responsibly.

documents.commentText:
To whom it may concern I would like to leave my comments regarding Kratom and how positively it's affected my life and my ability to function on a day to day basis.
I'm 64 years old, never abused drugs (except for occasional pot smoking in college) of any type and I don't drink alcohol.

 BEFORE  KRATOM I took 800 mg Tramadol, 1200 mg Gabapentin, 800-1200 mg of ibuprofen and 12 Excedrin and 50 mg of Topomax
daily.  This as well as various triptans ( or ergotamines if I couldn't afford the triptans ) during migraines.

CURRENTLY  I only take 120 mgs of Armour Thyroid and 3-5 gms of Kratom as a powdered leaf.

 I suffer from a chronic illness related to multiple sclerosis. Officially described as HHV6 of the CNS. Not only is the virus active but it's caused an autoimmune response. I've had it since 2003 and it is both painful and debilitating and has caused me great anguish.
I've been treated with Valcyte to reduce the viral load and Rituxan to mediate the autoimmune response. My current physician is Andreas Kogelnik, MD and infectious disease specialist who practices in Mountain View California.

 Because of my illness I have had to take pain relieving drugs for many years and struggle with the usual host of symptoms associated with their use.
 At one point I was taking OxyContin 10mg 2xd, but because of the need to increase the dose and how incredibly addictive I'd heard the drug was I discontinued its use. To replace it,  are used tramadol and gabapentin along with various other over-the-counter analgesics such as ibuprofen, naproxen sodium and others. For the migraines are associated with my disease, I used a variety of triptans and ergot based drugs. Also many preventative drugs, calcium channel blockers, Topamax etc were tried. Along with Excedrin which is oddly the one drug that's proved somewhat effective in aborting the migraine after onset.
All the drugs that I used were prescribed by various neurologists and rheumatologists etc, and I used them according to directions and never abused them.
 With constant pain from the disease as well as up to 15 migraines a month, the drugs barely kept me functioning at a very minimal level.
One of my physicians, the now deceased  Harvey Caplan, M.D., suggested that I try various herbal drugs since the pharmaceutical drugs I was using we're not working very well.
I tried various marijuana preparations and unfortunately they made my migraines worse. Then a very good friend ( a Rheumatiod arthritis sufferer) suggested Kratom. After several months I purchased some and tried it another several months later.
I'll try to shorten this as much as I can but the bottom line was until I found kratom my life was a living hell. My migraines are currently down to about 3 a month. Still severe but because of the relatively short duration they are bearable. My mobility is about 50% increased from its pre Kratom level. I can walk without assistance and no longer use a crutch or cane. I wish I could say Kratom cured me. Of course, this is not the case. But it has increased my quality of life tremendously. Although I know that the statement from one person can be viewed as anecdotal, I have heard similar stories from many people. My only regret is that it took me so long to find something that has helped me as much as Kratom leaves have.
Please enter my statement into your record and feel free to contact me at any time regarding my experience with Kratom.





Sincerely,

Barbara Brodsky
barbaralyn.brodsky@gmail.com

Kratom seems like a solution to a number of issues, including various forms of drug addiction and chronic pain. Plus, it can perform the pain-killing work of morphine without dangerously depressing breathing -- the way opioids do.

.
It uses a pathway that mediates many of the undesirable effects of traditional opioids such as constipation, respiratory depression. In fact, this knowledge is spurring additional research by pharmaceutical companies.
http://bit.ly/2c8UTI6

About Kratom, a leading researcher notes...
Thailand is considering legalizing kratom as a safer alternative for meth addicts. U.S. researchers are trying to study its potential to help opiate abusers kick the habit without withdrawal side effects.
http://bit.ly/2c8SI7v

I'm a 32 year old database administrator.  I have been taking Kratom for roughly 18 months.   I have a few painful medical conditions that prompted me to search online and see if there was anything that could help my quality life.  I didn't want to take deadly opiates, as I have seen quite a few articles mentioning that ~30,000 people die every year from taking opiates!  My loved ones depend on me too much to risk accidentally killing myself. 

As I approached my late 20's and saw that more and more Facebook friends were dying, I was horrified to learn they died from opiates.  As somebody who lives with chronic pain, I understand the desire to eliminate or reduce the pain.  For some, this desire truly is "at all costs".  

After doing more research on Kratom, I decided to give it a try.  It really did help my quality of life!  I urged my friends that take opiates to try kratom instead.  I have 3 friends that have switched from opiates to kratom, and they say they have never been happier! 

If Kratom were to be made illegal, I fear that it would actually increase opiate & heroin overdoses because people will desire to take something (anything) that can make their pain lessen.  

The best outcome for public health would be for Kratom to be regulated as a dietary supplement.  Age restrictions, labeling requirements, and purity/contamination standards should be adopted to help consumers make an educated choice.

To my fellow Patriots,

I'm a 36 year old stay at home mom (one child with cancer who is 7 she is Ella-Joe and another who is 2 he is Easton)  About 5 years ago I woke up one day, shortly after a miscarriage maybe, 2 weeks with this incredible neck pain.  I couldn't move my neck, I couldn't do anything.  I thought I was going to overdose on Advil!!  We were heading to Chicago from Kansas City the day this happened, so I had no time to go to my doctor.  And, what was suppose to be an amazing trip was horrible for me.  I hurt so bad.  And I couldn't do anything to get it to go away.  I was so upset about my ruined trip.  When I got home I went to my doctor.  He sent me for an MRI and found out that I had  6 buldging discs in my cervical spine.  Automatically put me on pain killers, and steroids and sent me to pain management.  I went to physical therapy, I had epidurals in my neck.  It was terribly painful, and none of it helped.  My daughter was diagnosed with cancer in July of 2014 and we were inpatient 6 months.  Sleeping in a chair for 6 months was terrible for me, and she had so many issues, I couldn't get to my doctors appointments.  I couldn't get the medicine or the rest I needed.  2 years later I heard about kratom when the ban was announced.  It's been a life changer.  I feel like I did before I got hurt and my daughter got sick.  I'm currently on a tolerance reset break right now.  But this plant has been amazing for me.  I don't know where I would be without it.  It calms my anxiety, helps with my pain, and all around helps me to be a better mom.  Please, please, please, hear the words of us that are trying to not take prescriptions and keep this plant legal.  Thank you and God Bless!

Jen Schultz

kratom. There should be no prohibition. While the FDA is looking into it as well, most Americans have never heard of it. Why? Because there's NO REAL PROBLEM with it! Quite the contrary...

It uses a pathway that mediates many of the undesirable effects of traditional opioids such as constipation, respiratory depression. In fact, this knowledge is spurring additional research by pharmaceutical companies.
http://bit.ly/2c8UTI6

About Kratom, a leading researcher notes...
Thailand is considering legalizing kratom as a safer alternative for meth addicts. U.S. researchers are trying to study its potential to help opiate abusers kick the habit without withdrawal side effects.
http://bit.ly/2c8SI7v

There are anecdotal reports of addiction risk. But it appears the addiction can be broken without withdrawal symptoms. Meanwhile, the painkillers currently being used are more addictive, dangerous, and harder to kick. Yet...

Banning kratom basically expands the war on drugs, while the public overwhelmingly supports ending it.
If kratom is added to any one of the five drug schedules, people who use it will be criminalized and locked up.
Kratom has been used safely by millions of people in the U.S. and evidence supports kratom's potential as a pain reliever and opioid replacement.
Many people struggling with opioid addiction have turned to kratom to help them cut back or quit, but now all promising scientific studies on kratom's role in opioid treatment could be immediately shut down.
Side effects of kratom are minimal, and its withdrawal symptoms are weak and nearly inconsequential compared to the suffering of people trying to quit opioids.
Prohibiting kratom will worsen the country's problems of opioid addiction and overdose.

documents.commentText:
To Whom It May Concern:  

I am writing in regards to plan the DEA has of possibly placing Kratom on the list of Schedule 1 drugs.  My hope is you will consider my testimony and the statements of testimony of many others before classifying this natural plant in such a dangerous and nonsensical category.  My story is as follows:  

I had a horrific motorcycle accident in 1997 where all the nerves to my left arm were severed at the left neck area.  Since then I have tried not only practically every opiate derived pain medication available but also surgical procedures and surgically implanted devices at having some hope of relief to the horrific, chronic pain I suffer.   Devices such as a spinal cord stimulator and a morphine pump we're both implanted and since removed. I had high hopes for both of these surgeries but both left me with the sign chronic pain issues I had before they're placement and therefore I had them removed.  Likewise, over the past 19 years I have been prescribed practically every man-made opiate that has been on the market. Many times I have suffered not only the humiliation of being treated harshly by not only the doctors but the community because I have had to depend on prescribed pain medication for relief.  That relief, such as it was, came at a very high price in that my concentration and my overall sense of well-being and self-worth became more diminished the more became dependent I became on the pharmaceutical methods of relief.  Furthermore, no matter what medication I was prescribed I was always left with a substantial amount of pain and found it mostly just dulled my senses. 
I have a sister that suffers from fibromyalgia and chronic fatigue who several months ago told me about a natural plant that she had found and tried which substantially decreased her pain, gave her energy and all without the side effects of pharmaceutical pain medications. That plant is known as Kratom.  Despite her having raved to me about the wonders of this plant I was hesitant to try it because I myself had fallen victim to believing the lie that only man-made pharmaceuticals could relieve my pain. This was in spite of knowing the dangers and pitfalls of these pharmaceutical drugs. Thankfully, she didn't give up on trying to convince me to at least try it and gave me some of her own to sample.  That small amount of Kratom set on my table for months after I received it until Monday I was in so much pain that I gave it a try.   Needless to say, after that first try of the plant I was sold on it! I hope someday that I will never again have to depend on the dangerous drugs prescribed to me by my doctor but can't solely rely on the relief of this natural, god-given healing plant. I beg of you to consider my testimony along with all of the others I know Who have written to you with testimony of their own life changing experience with Kratom.  I have faith and will believe until proven otherwise that there are still those who care about society enough not to take this natural life changing substance from us.  Thank you sincerely for listening to my story and my concerns.
Gratefully yours,

documents.commentText: It is highly unlikely Kratom is a real threat to public health; it has been used for centuries in Southeast Asia with minimal health repercussions. There is mounting anecdotal evidence that kratom provides significant relief from debilitating illnesses that modern medicine has thus far a very limited capacity to treat (fibromyalgia, interstitial cystitis are just two notable examples). It would be a mistake to take measures that would stall proper scientific research on something that may prove to help millions. However, more importantly, it would be potentially disastrous to the many lives that are currently finding help via kratom where other treatment options have failed. Removing this option will further devastate the lives of many people who have been unable to find relief elsewhere. Banning kratom would be the real threat to public health.

documents.commentText: To Whom it may concern..  My name is Jake Edgington. I am a 36 year old Marine Veteran, currently working for Gordan Food Service out of Springfield, Ohio. My job is very physical as I deliver food and restaurant supplies to restaurant chains ( Pizza Hut, Chipoltle, ect.. ).   I have done this type of work since being honorably discharged in 2001. Along with this, I have been obsessed with weight training, eating healthy and optimizing personal performance since the age of 12.                                                                                              Unfortunately, injuries are almost always certain sooner or later. Six years ago my shoulders reached a point where the pain was always there and nothing I did was of much help, including long stints in physical therapy. My physician prescribed Percocet to me and I reluctantly started to use them. At first I only took them when I was working and the pain got severe. Before I knew it I was taking them as soon as I woke up because I would feel completely miserable if it was not in my system.                                                                     Five years after filling the first bottle, having tried so many times to get off of them with no success, I heard about the Kratom plant. I actually heard Joe Rogan and another gentleman with a similar situation to my own discussing it on his podcast.                               I ordered a small bag of it the next day and finally felt like I had an edge this time to kick It for good.                                                                                                                                The Kratom worked wonders for me. I used it a couple times a day while tapering down the opiates. Today I am opiate free and there is no doubt in my mind this would not be the case had I not found out about this plant.                                                                                        I sincerely hope that Kratom remains legal and similar stories to this quickly multiply. I would have never predicted I would end up one of the millions of opiate addicted Americans. It was absolutely the darkest and most depressing years of my life. I would never wish it on anyone. Kratom was my way out, my way of getting back to who I am proud to be. I know there are so many other good people in the same situation and I am confident this plant can and will get their life back on track.                                                                                         Thank you very much for listening to me and others. I hope it shines a little light on the actual reality of kratom.                                    Sincerely, Jacob M. Edgington

documents.commentText:
My mom wrote this and I'm passing it in for her. Please think of people that need this for medical reasons.

"I have struggled with chronic pain from degenerative disc disease that causes constant muscle spasm for the last 12 years. I have tried all available traditional treatments, including over- the-counter and prescription medications, physical therapy, acupuncture, massage, cognitive behavioral therapy, meditation, and surgery. Many therapies like massage and physical therapy are no longer covered by my medical insurance and are very expensive to continue. I am also allergic to most medications that might improve my quality of life. I am permanently disabled by chronic pain, poor sleep, unrelenting fatigue and increasingly limited mobility. 
I decided to try Kratom two weeks ago and I'm happy to report that it does indeed relieve my pain and fatigue and has helped my sleep quality improve. It's inexpensive in comparison to other options and has fewer side effects. The only side effect I have noticed is minor constipation which is easy to treat. It improved my mood and reduced my pain as effectively as most prescribed medications which, I can no longer tolerate. After taking the Kratom, I have also increased my level of activity.
Based on my personal experience and the testimonials I have read by other individuals, I would highly recommend this supplement to anyone who is interested in managing their pain and improving their quality-of-life. This is not a dangerous substance when used appropriately. I think it would be a grievous error to ban this useful supplement."

The DEA should stop any and all consideration of banning the herbal supplement kratom. There should be no prohibition. While the FDA is looking into it as well, most Americans have never heard of it. Why? Because there's NO REAL PROBLEM with it! Quite the contrary...

Kratom seems like a solution to a number of issues, including various forms of drug addiction and chronic pain. Plus, it can perform the pain-killing work of morphine without dangerously depressing breathing -- the way opioids do.

Here's how Kratom works...
It uses a pathway that mediates many of the undesirable effects of traditional opioids such as constipation, respiratory depression. In fact, this knowledge is spurring additional research by pharmaceutical companies.
http://bit.ly/2c8UTI6

About Kratom, a leading researcher notes...
Thailand is considering legalizing kratom as a safer alternative for meth addicts. U.S. researchers are trying to study its potential to help opiate abusers kick the habit without withdrawal side effects.
http://bit.ly/2c8SI7v
There are anecdotal reports of addiction risk. But it appears the addiction can be broken without withdrawal symptoms. Meanwhile, the painkillers currently being used are more addictive, dangerous, and harder to kick. Yet...

The FDA and DEA both appear ready to ban kratom and effectively kill research to further develop this substance. Is the DEA is running cover for a Big Pharma company that wants to monopolize kratom?

As I consider these actions by the FDA and DEA I'm forced to wonder -- WHAT ARE YOU PEOPLE SMOKING?

documents.commentText:
I am writing to express my objection to the decision to place Kratom on the Schedule 1 Drug List, which would put it in the same category as heroin and MDMA. 
Kratom is an herb thats been used for 1000s of years, and while it helps increase my mood and energy level, any similarities to hard drugs end there. Putting Kratom on the Schedule 1 list akin to putting coffee on it.  
It astounds me that a substance which is primarily consumed by mature, responsible adults aged 30 and above, has no negative impact on mental acuity, coordination, has no abuse potential as a recreational drug as it lacks the intoxicating effects that commonly abused drugs possess, should be lumped into the same category. On the contrary many people find Kratom a safe substitute to opiate addiction. A case in point is a marked increase in opiate deaths after Alabama banned Kratom.

In contrast, Florida, in deciding on whether to place restrictions on Kratom found no reason to do so.  In a December 2015 report titled Kratom - Mitragyna Speciosa, The Impact to Florida it was determined that Kratom does not currently constitute a significant risk to the safety and welfare of Florida residents. Additionally, the report sites that the Florida Department of Health found that there are no pervasive health issues which can be attributed to the ingestion of Kratom products in Florida.

Arbitrarily placing a relatively harmless substance which has shown to be safer than aspirin does little to serve the wellbeing and best interests of our society which the drug war is allegedly designed to protect. If anything, it undermines the mission and leads to speculation about the true motives of such an action. 

In closing, Kratom should not be treated as a dangerous drug with a potential for addiction because it is it has so little in common with those types of drugs which are frequently abused, including prescription opioids. It does not produce a high of any sort, nor any of the withdrawal symptoms associated with alcohol or other drugs, and as such would be extremely unlikely candidate as a drug of choice for our nations youth. On the contrary, Kratom has shown to be beneficial help recovering addicts break their dependency on narcotics.  Considering this, and all the positive impact Kratom has had on so many lives, I urge that the proposed ban be reconsidered.

documents.commentText:
Docket # DEA-442w 
My name is Brett Blandino, I have been using kratom for one year now for my chronic pain and anxiety. I was taking Norco and clonopin every day And never had enough relief from my prescribed dose and started to take more. I knew I was heading into trouble but I needed some regular sleep and to not hurt as much. I tried other prescribed meds but they where worse and with horrible side effects. Also my career and ability to support my family was in jeopardy, you can't work or drive or function properly on powerful pain meds. When I found kratom I just couldn't believe it, no anxiety and my pain was gone. This herb was too good to be true, so I did a ton of research. With all the benifits this herb has and extremely few side effects I knew that this herb is what God intended for us to use. It is a divine intervention for opiate addiction, I have seen it work. We have too many people dying every day from opiates and if anyone knows those numbers it is the DEA. If you continue this attempt to make something as harmless as kratom illegal you will have more death and that blood will be on your hands. You have awaken the people to a problem with some of our federal agencies. If you want to continue to do business with my tax dollars why don't you concentrate on the reality that there is some bad stuff out there and we need it stopped. 99% of kratom users are law abiding citizens who just want to be normal. What am I going to tell my daughter when I don't have the strength to play with her, how many people face the same thing. I'm sorry honey but the DEA is trying to kill me with opiates because they don't make money from kratom. Make this your opportunity to do something good, be hero's, do the right thing for the children, especially the ones who now have a mom or dad because of a harmless herb. Don't you think that the children deserve this, or would you prefer a doped up bed ridden lump of flesh that is nothing but a burden on loved ones. KRATOM saves lives, please don't take them. In my year of kratom use I have never got high, in fact I try to stretch out my dosage for as long as I can. I take 2.5 to 3 grams 3 times a day so my mid day dose I wait until the pain is unbearable then I take it, that is not what an addictive substance does, and I know addiction having been a smoker for 40 years and I don't think I will ever be able to quit. I have stopped kratom 4 times in a year, I do this to keep my tolerance down, now that doesn't sound like an abusive drug to me. My insurance doesn't cover kratom so I try to keep my spending as low as I can but I'm sure you know that heroin is very easy to get and it's not very expensive. As a citizen I wonder why that is...isn't it your job. Don't you know that it will get worse if you ban kratom. Do you want to help drug cartels with more customers and bigger profits to fund terrorists, just think about the black market receiving from kratom if made illegal. You need to do the right thing and leave kratom alone, the world knows that your numbers are flawed when it comes to kratom. Just do the right thing and stop your scheduling and put more effort into keeping the bad stuff out of our country, be the hero that our children will admire and aspires to be. History will remember this, history will live on, be remembered for the good things that you have done. Keep kratom legal and save lives.  Thank you for your time. Brett Blandino, kratom user.                 
Docket #DEA 442w

documents.commentText:
I am 60 years old and have used kratom for 8 years, for all of those 8 years I have had yearly physicals and blood panels (I am a type 2 diabetic and cancer survivor) all tests are completely normal. I initially used kratom to wean myself off of a physical addiction to the legal and highly addictive opiate agonist, Tramadol, I found that kratom was extremely efficacious in allowing me to stop using Tramadol without the horrible withdrawals that had made quitting unthinkable, in addition, I found the herb to lift my mood (I suffer from depression and anxiety) and it allows me to work, and pay taxes without feeling drugged (again, I would rather not use prescription drugs for depression and anxiety.) 

When I was diagnosed with uterine cancer in 2015 and needed an operation, I stopped using kratom for around a month with no problems or signs of physical dependence. I fact, I quickly ceased using the opioid pain killer prescribed after surgery and switched back to kratom as it is an excellent analgesic without causing the addiction problems of narcotics. To be honest, I find it surprising that anyone would consider that this ancient herb (I am talking about the pure leaf, from a tree that is a member of the coffee family, and similar to the tea leaves we use as a beverage) would even be considered as having "recreational abuse" potential since the effects of the herb is very subtle, and taking too much can be nauseating.

To conclude, the banning of kratom would have a negative impact on my life, as I have suggested, 8 years of almost daily use and I am perfectly healthy and working and feel better than I have in decades, and I find it significant that our close allies, the Canadians, have looked at kratom and have categorized it as a supplement, it is also legal throughout most of the EU. In short, I am a good example of a typical person who has found kratom and has been able to rid themselves of the need for deleterious drugs, and to throw off the shackles of chronic depression. Thank you for allowing me the time to tell my story

documents.commentText:
I do not believe Kratom should be scheduled as a controlled substance. I was diagnosed at age 16 having degenerative disk disease, scoliosis, and sciatica. At first I was suggested to get a back surgery that has a 50% chance of leaving me in a wheelchair, so I decided not to opt for surgery. However, I had to deal with chronic pain problems. 

When I was 21 years old I was sent to a pain specialist. First I was prescribed Hydrocodone, which worked for the pain at first, but left me feeling intoxicated. Then the pain relief went away, and I was bumped up to higher dose, then to a different more powerful drug called Oxycodone, that also made me feel intoxicated, then the amount was increased, eventully I saw a problem and stopped the prescription drugs. The pain relief went away once I took myself off of it. I took myself off because I heard horrible stories about people becoming addicted and how they have to take increasing doses for it to work. It also started causing me stomach problems from the inactive ingredients. I would throw up blood from stomach ulcers almost every day. The doctor said there was no other choices.

 I did weeks of research on the computer, I then switched to plant based supplements to control my pain. I took willow bark which worked ok, but still had a lot of pain, so I added turmeric, which really also helped a lot, stil had pain at times, so I added a plant called devils claw, which also helps with the pain but even with all those, I was still in some pain, even though it had been reduced from 10 pain level to about 4. Which was good but not great. I still couldn't stand for long periods of time and needed a lot of aquatherapy to manage my pain. 

 Then I found out about a plant based supplement called Kratom. The first time I tried it was the first time in my life I had been pain free, for as long as I could remember. I take Kratom now every day and have been for several years, and the amount I take never needs increasing and I have no side effects, it's non-intoxicating, and now I can live a normal life again. Do not try to take this away from me. I shouldn't have to remind you that supplements that have been sold and marketed as a dietary supplement from before 1994 are exempted by the FDA from regulations, in fact there is a store in NYC that has been importing and selling kratom for over 40 years. Not only that, but by prohibiting Kratom you are proving that the DEA is working alongside pharmaceutical companies to prevent people from using natural supplements instead of dangerous pharmaceutical drugs that kill hundreds of thousands of people a year. Please don't use your influence to create harm to people. Your job is to keep people safe, not put them in danger.

documents.commentText: Schedule I drugs are claimed to have no medicinal value. This is outrageously untrue in the case of Kratom. It has value in the control of pain, anxiety, depression, and insomnia, to name a few. Of even more importance, it has the ability to help those truly and hopelessly addicted to narcotics kick that habit without side effects, withdrawals, or getting addicted to some new substance. I and many others can attest to each of these claims. From experience, it is about on par with coffee in terms of its addictiveness and one does not get "high" from even very high doses. The worst effect that can happen is nausea. If the ultimate goal is public health, this decision is going to make us all worse off as a nation. Kratom is a safe alternative with important medicinal uses and has changed the lives of so many Americans. I fear any negative action towards it will only lead to more tragic deaths and cast victims of the opiate epidemic back into the void. We should be looking for positive solutions to addiction, not creating more problems. Kratom is a solution.

documents.commentText:
I live in NJ, a state that has always been a very prevalent place for opiate use, particularly heroin. I have literally lost friends and family members to heroin and opioid addiction. These people that are gone from us forever went through the ringer trying to get clean: courts,rehabs, 12 step programs etc. and none of them worked. 

Many addicts in their quest for sobriety and a normal life chose to switch over to synthetic alternatives such as suboxone only to find even longer and more pronounced withdrawals. As it stands now, there is NO viable answer for opioid dependence by traditional medicine or the institution. The answers we get from them are either highly potent and addictive substitutes in methadone or suboxone, or more jail time. Neither of these is an effective answer for society.

On another hand, we have a natural,legal, and safer plant that grows naturally and has extremely diminished abuse potential when compared to opioids. That plant is kratom. For me personally, it entirely eliminated all cravings for opioids and withdrawal symptoms within minutes of ingestion. Not only that but it also lifted the depression that was hanging over me for months trying to quit opiates and suboxone. For overcoming opiate dependence kratom is a more effective treatment than any pharmaceutical that we have available. I literally have hope for the future and my life back, and kratom was the plant that enabled me to get to this point. This plant can do so much good for others, I don't doubt that if it was more widely used it could greatly reduce the suffering felt by addicts, families, and communities nationwide. 

This plant should be the number one choice for those quitting opiates. It should be available to anyone in the public. I'm not exaggerating when I say it literally got me off of the streets in Paterson as an addict. It can help others too. With this plant we can help addicts get back to society and back to productivity. To ban this substance would be to enable millions to suffer and cause social harm through using heroin and other opioids. I would liken it to treason upon your own people. 

Getting rid of this plant will only enable more heroin users. Heroin is both the most dangerous and most addictive street drug. It's the most evil substance and the most difficult to stop using due to excruciating withdrawals. This plant kratom helped me gain my humanity back, and I want to help the fellow suffering addicts and families get the same help. There is another way that's herbal and inexpensive! Do not ban Kratom!

documents.commentText:
Please stop the nonsense war on drugs. Prohibition does NOT work, it only gives power to a black market.  Legalize, regulate, and tax everything.  Nobody has any authority over what another does to, puts into, or has come out of their own body, PERIOD!

I worked in radiation oncology for over a decade.  It was so disgusting how doctors prescribe one medicine for symptoms of the illness and then a cocktail of other meds to try to offset the side affects of the first med.  I wish I would have kept track of how many times the physician with whom I worked stated that he wished he could prescribe cannabis to help his patients.

Also, I had a dog who suffered from seizures most of his life.  Even with the meds (that are most likely what eventually started to shut down his kidneys) he had seizures.  Now I learn that cannabis extract (without the high) could have helped him much more than the pharmaceuticals....you do not understand how much this infuriates me, especially when I hear the real reasons it is illegal is because of tobacco, alcohol, and pharmaceutical lobbying as well as conservative pricks like Nixon wanting an excuse to arrest hippies and blacks.

ENOUGH IS ENOUGH!
People feel they are being helped by kratom, then LET THEM!  Just make sure what they buy is safe.  If you make it illegal then it will hit the black market and drug dealers will lace it with much worse stuff.

documents.commentText: I have to agree that more study on Kratom is needed, both for regulation and effective, intelligent use. However, if history is any indicator a Schedule 1 designation will not support this direction of inquiry, and I see very little evidence to support the claim that Kratom and its constituents are highly dangerous and have no possible medicinal value. Indiscriminate use of any potentially mind altering substance is never a good idea, but slapping a Schedule 1 classification on the substance seems like rash histrionics given the relative lack of reported problems, and I trust the DEA is capable of engineering a more effective and intelligent framework in which to explore this plant.

documents.commentText:
The DEA should stop any and all consideration of banning the herbal supplement
kratom. There should be no prohibition. While the FDA is looking into it as well, most Americans have never heard of it. Why? Because there's NO REAL PROBLEM with it! Quite the contrary...

Kratom seems like a solution to a number of issues, including various forms of drug addiction and chronic pain. Plus, it can perform the pain-killing work of morphine without dangerously depressing breathing -- the way opioids do.

Here's how Kratom works...
It uses a pathway that mediates many of the undesirable effects of traditional opioids such as constipation, respiratory depression. In fact, this knowledge is spurring additional research by pharmaceutical companies.
http://bit.ly/2c8UTI6

About Kratom, a leading researcher notes...
Thailand is considering legalizing kratom as a safer alternative for meth addicts. U.S. researchers are trying to study its potential to help opiate abusers kick the habit without withdrawal side effects.
http://bit.ly/2c8SI7v

There are anecdotal reports of addiction risk. But it appears the addiction can be broken without withdrawal symptoms. Meanwhile, the painkillers currently being used are more addictive, dangerous, and harder to kick. Yet...

The FDA and DEA both appear ready to ban kratom and effectively kill research to further develop this substance. Is the DEA is running cover for a Big Pharma company that wants to monopolize kratom?

As I consider these actions by the FDA and DEA I'm forced to wonder -- WHAT ARE YOU PEOPLE SMOKING?

documents.commentText:
When pharmaceutical companies are permitted to market drugs that are fast-tracked into the consumer market-place without full and proper testing before such allowances are approved, and when the DEA prepares to ban a natural healing plant that provides numerous health benefits, the disingenuous character of such an arrangement is nothing less than duplicitous.

In the past, not only have certain over-the-counter and prescription drugs been prematurely allowed in the consumer market-place, some of these drugs have had serious and deleterious health effects to such an extent as to be the causal agents of death.

In light of this fact, and in all fairness to the public, a far greater service to the public would be the extension of time that would allow for more in-depth research into the issue.  Autocratic decision-making on the part of the DEA does not belong in a Democratic Republic, and allowing synthetic drugs into the market before fully proving their efficacy and empirical value is a performative contradiction when plans are being made to condemn a beneficent natural substance to Schedule 1 classification.

documents.commentText: Article 1 section 8 of the constitution is very clear about the scope of congress. The federal government was never meant to ban anything and the states should individually decide what is to be legal and what is not. This is why there was a constitutional amendment needed to ban alcohol and again to remove the ban. I'm amazed at the blatant overreach and abuse of power that the citizens allow through all of the little unelected three letter agencies. Just because our so called representatives in congress have abdicated much of their authority to these agencies, that does not give those agencies the the power to legislate through regulations that exceed the constraints of the federal government laid out in the constitution. I do not understand how so many people in places of power within our government sit by and say nothing about how many of these regulations have no validity whatsoever. Kratom and marijuana in particular are far more benign than many of the substances that are legal nation wide and yet just because some of you in the government can personally justify their unconstitutional banning, we're all supposed to sit by and allow this to happen. Millions die from cancer through tobacco, tens of thousands die each year from pharmaceutical pain pills, alcohol destroys people's livers and families, and many antidepressant drugs actually say on the insert that they can cause homicidal or suicidal tendencies... I'm astounded that any of you can sit there with a straight face and tell us that as law abiding, tax paying, adult citizens that we cannot decide what to put into our own bodies. Especially any of you people within the DEA with your recent disgraceful, horrible, deceitful declaration that marijuana has zero medical benefit and must remain a schedule one drug. All of you should be ashamed of yourselves and are horrible human beings if you sit by and don't actively speak out about this. About half of the states have medical marijuana and many are starting to legalize recreational use. 60% of the country says it should be legal when polled and Kratom has been shown to actually help people get off of dangerous opiate pain pill addiction. I for one am tired of you people in the government financially raping me and stealing my money to fight a ridiculous war that you'll never win against a plant. Punish people for their unlawful actions when abusing substances but stop punishing those of us who wish to consume natural plants and herbs from the earth instead of the dangerous and harmful products from the true drug dealers, big pharma. You're all just their puppets ruining society for their monetary gain.  And while you sit here deliberating on yet another unconstitutional ban.... the government has been using US soldiers to guard poppy fields in Afghanistan and letting banks get away with laundering drug cartel money when they've been caught red handed!! You're an absolute and absurd joke and really need to think about what you're doing to society and this world.

I am not an american citizen but I trace your dabate about the ban of Kratom eagerly interested.
That's why I would like to share my very positive experiences I made with this substance. For years I had to suffer under strong spinal pain. I had to take multiple pain relievers like Tramadol constantly. My liver values went worse and worse over the time up to the point that my doctor stopped the prescription of this mediaction. From that point I had to accept my strong pain which decreased my health-related quality of life massively.
Two years ago I discovered Kratom and tried it to relieve my pain on a natural way. Today I can say that this was the best decision of my entire life! I can go through everydays life with almost no pain which is a big advantage for me and my entire family. My blood is being analyzed regularly and even though I'm using Kratom often my liver values are much better than the years before when I had to take Tramadol. Even my doctor is deeply impressed by it's effect.
Some people are concerned about a potential addicition. Of course there is a risk to become addictive to Kratom but from where I stand this chance is very low. I take Kratom almost every two days but when I notice that my pain is not very strong I can easily skip the consumption for a week until my pain gets worse again.
In my opinion the risk of getting addicted to Kratom is much lower than to any other pain reliever.
If you'd ban Kratom you would take millions of people who suffer under strong pain like I do the chance to live a normal life without ruining their health because they have to take other pain relievers.

Best regards from Germany!

RE: Docket No. DEA-442W - my comments

I am a 36-year old Web QA Manager from Virginia. 

My comment is to notify the DEA that I am strongly against any scheduling of the alkaloids mitragynine and 7-hydroxymitragynine which are in the kratom plant.

I started using kratom one year ago after researching natural ways to help with depression. I had been prescribed prescription anti-depressants for many years with little positive effects and a few negative side effects. Kratom has made a positive difference in my battle with depression. I have not personally experienced any negative effects while taking kratom. I strongly believe kratom should remain readily available to the United States public to access without any need for a prescription. 

Thank you for accepting my comment.

documents.commentText:
I am a 46 year old professional software engineer.  A few years ago, I discovered Kratom and have enjoyed a positive experience from this plant.  I've not experienced any negative side effects.

I first tried Kratom to see if it would work for a nagging pain in my side.  It really helped the pain.  Additionally, it left me feeling motivated, focused and clear-headed.  I was able to get physical work accomplished, without issue.  

As a welcome and unexpected side effect, I noticed that it also significantly reduced nasal congestion.  I've suffered from allergies and congestion my entire life.  It was great to finally not have to take pseudoephedrine, which is usually a daily thing for me.

Finally, I am not sure if it has to do with anti-oxidants in the leaves of the plant, but it seems like it may help to prevent colds or lessen the severity and duration.  I am not sure if anyone else has noticed these effects.  In my opinion, that may merit additional research.  Please do not schedule this plant that has such potential and benefits thousands of people in so many ways.
